The House will be aware that, under natural disaster relief arrangements, the Commonwealth meets 50 per cent of the cost of personal hardship relief. Then, above agreed thresholds, the Commonwealth meets 50 per cent and then 75 per cent of the cost of concessional loans and grants, replacement of essential public infrastructure, and counselling. There are many stories of communities coming together to help. I had one reminder of that spirit when I met the workers of ActewAGL who worked day and night for nine days to restore power to the Canberra suburbs where power infrastructure had been destroyed. They were delighted to have had the opportunity of helping their fellow Australians. They were supplemented by people from the coalfields areas of New South Wales and from Victoria. The following notices were given: That this House: Mr Abbott to move: (1) acknowledges that trade apprenticeships continue to have low retention rates and
title: Adjournment The Hawke Labor Government Recognised

speaker: The Speaker
theText: Order! It being 11 their withdrawal. All visitors must withdrawstrategies need to be put in place to improve these outcomes; (2) notes the importance of relevance and quality of training for existing workers as well as new entrants, and that the content and coverage of training needs to keep pace with the rapid rate of technological change; (3) notes that the age demographic changes will mean stagnation of 15 to 24 year olds in the population; alternative pathways such as the VET system are being considered to attract older participants; and (4) acknowledges that training methods may need to broaden the skills of the individual to provide more options for better career prospects. Ms O’Byrne to move: That this House: (1) acknowledges that medical practices and individual general practitioners are advising veteran patients that they will no longer be able to recognise the gold card when charging them for medical services; (2) acknowledges that veterans are entitled to receive adequate and appropriate medical care in view of their service to this country; (3) notes that many practices and practitioners, in particular those with a high percentage of veteran patients, are struggling to provide acceptable levels of medical care and service, given the rebates and fees currently available to them; and (4) calls upon the Government to immediately negotiate with medical practitioners to ensure that an appropriate agreement is in place to enable doctors to provide adequate levels of care to gold card recipients. Mr Danby to move: That this House: (1) recognises the environmental impact the 6.4 billion plastic bags used in Australia annually have on our environment; (2) notes the incredible success of the new plastic bag levy, introduced in Ireland on 4 March 2002; and (3) calls on the Government to introduce a similar plastic bag levy in Australia in order to reduce plastic bag usage and create a recurrent fund for environmental projects. Mr Kelvin Thomson to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 to provide for an extension of the boundaries of the Great Barrier Reef region. The following answers to questions were circulated: Aviation: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport (Question No. 44) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 February 2002: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an article in the Australian Financial Review of 11 May 2001 titled “ACCC shot down over airport price regulation”. (2) Has the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) accepted a Federal Government direction to back Sydney Airport Corporation’s bid to secure an unregulated stream of revenue from non-aeronautical services such as shops and car parking. (3) What cost impacts will this direction have on consumers of (a) aeronautical and (b) nonaeronautical services. (4) Will he furnish a copy of the direction to Parliament; if so, when. (5) What public interest consultation was undertaken in making the direction. (6) Was the Board of Airline Representatives of Australia consulted. (7) What other public interest groups were consulted. (8) Does he agree with the ACCC head, Professor Fels’ prediction that this decision will result in higher prices. (9) What are the policy and moral grounds for the direction to the ACCC. (10) What are the public interest impacts of the decision on (a) consumers of airport services and (b) tenants of privatised airports, particularly service providers such as airline companies, on their profitability. (11) Will the direction have an adverse effect on profitability of airline companies and other service providers due to non-regulation of non-aeronautical services in Australia’s privatised airports. (1) Yes. (2) In assessing charges for aeronautical services at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) in its final decision did not take into account the revenues generated, or costs incurred, in the provision of services other than aeronautical services. (3) An estimation of the effect of the Direction on the calculation of allowable aeronautical revenue was included in the press release issued by the ACCC on 11 May 2001. (4) A copy of Direction No. 22 is publicly available on the ACCC website (www.accc.gov.au). (5) The Government is engaged in on-going consultation with the aviation industry on a variety of matters and is aware of industry views in relation to pricing issues at Australian airports. Upon receipt of Direction No. 22, the ACCC embarked on further consultations with interested parties before the release of its final decision. (6) The BARA provided a submission to the ACCC on SACL’s draft pricing proposal as well as in response to the Commission’s draft decision. (7) As noted in the response to question 5, the Government is aware of a number of interested parties views on airport pricing. The ACCC’s inquiry into the SACL price application involved lengthy consultation that was open to interested parties and the general public. (8) The effect of the ACCC’s decision on charges for aeronautical services is set out in the ACCC’s press release. (9) The Direction was intended to clarify for the ACCC the Government’s view that in assessing prices for aeronautical services at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport the Commission should not take into account the revenues generated, or costs incurred, in the provision of services other than aeronautical services.
title: Notices Ms Burke To Move

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(10) Direction 22, by promoting efficient and commercial operations at Sydney (KSA) Airport is likely to lead to better services for consumers and airlines. (11) Aeronautical related services at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and the privatised airports are subject to prices monitoring under s.27A of the Prices Surveillance Act. Aviation: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport (Question No. 47) Mr Murphy asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 February 2002: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a media release from the Productivity Commission, dated 24 August 2001, titled “Price Regulation of Airport Services” in which the Productivity Commission recommends as its preferred option a five-year period of price and conduct monitoring for Sydney Airport, with no direct control over that period. (2) If so, (a) upon what policy basis is this recommendation based, (b) upon what policy basis and instruments is the existing regulatory regime of price caps and regulation founded, (c) will he table copies of these policy instruments in the House and (d) will he table the policy reasoning that has led to the recommendation by the Commission that a monitoring regime be initiated. (3) Further to the media release and an article at page 56 in the Australian Financial Review of 25-26 August 2001 concerning the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission’s (ACCC) overall ruling on Sydney’s aeronautical charges, (a) what is the policy rationale for the system of dual till pricing and (b) what impact will a dual till pricing system have on charges for consumers. (4) Does the Commission’s judgment conflict with the ACCC’s overall ruling to increase aeronautical charges. (5) What impact will the ACCC’s decision to increase aeronautical charges by 97% have on the second till non-aeronautical tenants, including shop owners, parking station owners and restaurants at Sydney Airport. (6) Will the 97% increase in aeronautical charges decrease turnover for the non-aeronautical tenants at Sydney Airport due to increased airfares and other charges thus economically pricing out prospective consumers of Sydney Airport services. (7) Will the new two-till system enable the prospective bidders for Sydney Airport’s airport lease to increase non-aeronautical tenants’ rents, thus decreasing profitability for those non-aeronautical tenants at Sydney Airport. (8) Will he provide case references for the court actions referred to in the Australian Financial Review article. (9) Are the terms of settlement between the parties in the litigation matters in the public interest and should be disclosed. (10) In which court did the proceedings take place. (11) Were proceedings in the relevant court closed proceedings. (12) Are the terms of the out of court settlement in the public interest and do they warrant public scrutiny. (13) Do the terms of the out of court settlement directly impact on persons not party to the legal proceedings, including the general public and non-aeronautical tenants of Sydney Airport; if not, why not. (14) Upon what policy basis does the Productivity Commission seek to avoid the currently high level of regulatory involvement. (15) Will he seek to challenge the Commission’s findings regarding its judgment or does he agree with the Commission’s findings; if so, why; if not, why not. (16) Why does the Commission consider the current level of regulatory involvement as high. (17) Will he seek advice from the Commission to explain what is the existing policy of the current regulatory regime. (18) Are aeronautical services for Sydney Airport subject to price surveillance and are aeronautical related services subject to price monitoring. (19) Is Sydney Airport subject to pricing regulation under the Prices Surveillance Act. (20) Is Sydney Airport further subject to the current regulations under the Prices Surveillance Act made in 1997. (21) Would the current arrangements of pricing regulation apply only for the first five years of operation of the lease of Sydney Airport and Sydney Basin airports. (22) Further to the statement in relation to terms of reference No. 5 of the Commission draft report titled “Price Regulation of Airport Services”, (a) what is the policy rationale for the premise that the price caps applied to aeronautical services will no longer operate, (b) what is the policy rationale for applying this regulation for only a five year period, (c) what event or milestone date did the Government contemplate in 1997 that predicated a sunset clause to terminate a price surveillance regulatory regime such as the 1997 regulations and (d) were the regulations instituted with a view to the elimination of price capping in 2002; if so, what is the policy basis to eliminate the price capping provisions in 2002. (23) Did he contemplate in 1997 the sale of Sydney Airport by transfer of the airport lease from Sydney Airport Corporation to a private person; if so, at the time of making his prices surveillance regulation that currently regulates Sydney Airport, did he know that the airport would be leased to a private entity or corporate person who is not the current lessee. (24) In 1996 when the then Minister for Transport and Regional Services made his second reading speech on the Airports Bill 1996, was it stated that Sydney Airport would not be sold until Sydney Airport’s aircraft noise problems had been solved. (25) Did he know whether the pricing regulatory regime must accommodate a financial component that satisfies all policy objectives of Government, including solving Sydney Airport’s aircraft noise problems through the full introduction of the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) and the completion of a genuine environmental impact statement (EIS) for Sydney West Airport and the construction of that airport. (26) Does paragraph 8(1)(b) of the Productivity Commission Act state that a general policy guideline of the Commission is to reduce regulation of industry, including regulation by the States, Territories and local government, where this is consistent with the social and economic goals of the Commonwealth Government. (27) Is he able to say whether the LTOP is a Ministerial Direction issued by power given to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services under section 16 of the Air Services Act. (28) Is the LTOP, for the purposes of paragraph 8(1)(b) of the Productivity Commission Act, a social and economic goal of the Commonwealth Government; if not, why not. (29) Is the construction of Sydney West Airport at Badgerys Creek a social and economic goal of the Commonwealth Government, pursuant to paragraph 8(1)(b) of the Productivity Commission Act; if not, why not. (30) Is it reasonable for the Commission to accept submissions at public hearings into the draft report on the Price Regulation of Airport Services, concerning the two relevant social and economic goals of the Commonwealth Government referred to in part (25). (31) Is it reasonable for the Commission to consider these goals when considering the terms of reference to the Price Regulation of Airport Services at Sydney Airport; if not, why not, given paragraph 8(1)(b) of the Productivity Commission Act. (32) Can price regulation be used to administer environmental control of Sydney Airport in meeting the Government’s social and economic goals and fulfilling the LTOP. (33) Does paragraph 8(1)(e) of the Productivity Commission Act state that a general policy guideline of the Commission is to recognise the interests of industries, employees, consumers and the community, likely to be affected by measures proposed by the Commission. (34) Does the Sydney Airport Community Forum (SACF) and its members represent members of the community likely to be affected by measures proposed by the Commission; if not, (a) why not and (b) will he notify the Productivity Commissioner under the powers given him pursuant to subsection 8(2), that the SACF and its members be considered members of the community likely to be affected by measures proposed by the Commission; if not, why not. (35) Is he able to say whether, by virtue of membership of the SACF, members of the SACF constitute part of a statutory committee established under the auspice of the Commonwealth Department of Transport and Regional Services and as such, constitute a formal element of the public interest process of community consultation as established by the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. (36) In fulfilling its obligations under section 8 of the Productivity Commission Act, must the Commission consider environmental and ecological constraints as part of the Act’s general policy guidelines; if not, why not. (37) Will he notify the Productivity Commissioner in writing under the powers given him pursuant to subsection 8(2) that the (a) full implementation of the LTOP and (b) construction of Sydney West Airport before the sale of Sydney Airport as a strategic solution to solving Sydney Airport’s aircraft noise problems, are matters going to the operation of paragraph 8(1)(b) as a social and economic goal of the Commonwealth Government and need to be considered as part of the Commission’s terms of reference in respect to the draft report on Price Regulation of Airport Services; if not, why not. (38) Is the Commission’s scope of inquiry into Price Regulation of Airport Services narrow as it has not been directed to report on whether relevant Government social, economic and other goals are adversely affected, compromised or negated; if not, why not. (39) Is the Commission’s direction of recommendations flawed in that the Commission is not being called upon to identify relevant issues going to social and economic goals. (40) For the purposes of clause 9 of the draft report’s scope of inquiry, do key interest groups and affected parties include the SACF and its members. (1) Yes. (2) (a) The Productivity Commission (PC) stated the reasoning for its recommendations in its inquiry report on “Price Regulation of Airport Services”. This report is available on the PC’s website at www.pc.gov.au. (b) The prices oversight regime is designed to strike a balance between protecting airport users from monopoly pricing and creating the conditions for commercially-driven decisions on the part of the airport operators. The Instruments, which provide the framework for prices oversight at core-regulated airports, are publicly available on the ACCC website at www.accc.gov.au. (c) Refer to the response to 2(b). (d) Refer to the response to 2(a). (3) (a) Direction No. 22 (so-called ‘dual till’ direction) was issued by the Government in order to clarify for the ACCC the Government’s view that in assessing prices for aeronautical services at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport the ACCC should not take into account the revenues generated, or costs incurred, in the provision of services other than aeronautical services. (b) The estimated impact of the ACCC’s decision on charges was set out in the ACCC’s press release of 11 May 2001. (4) No. (5) Aeronautical related services at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport and the other core regulated airports are subject to prices monitoring under s.27A of the Prices Surveillance Act. (6) Refer to response to question (3)(b). (7) Refer to response to question (5). (8) The Commonwealth Government was not a party to the litigation in question. (9) Refer to response to question (8). (10) Refer to response to question (8). (11) Refer to response to question (8). (12) Refer to response to question (8). (13) Refer to response to question (8). (14) Refer to response to question (2)(a). (15) The Government’s response to the Productivity Commission’s inquiry was released on 13 May 2002 and is available on the Treasurer’s website at www.treasurer.gov.au.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(16) Refer to response to question (2)(a). (17) No. (18) Aeronautical and aeronautical related services at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport are subject to price monitoring. Further details are contained in the instruments which implement the prices oversight framework. These are available on the ACCC website. (19) Yes. (20) Refer to response to question 18. (21) Refer to response to question 15. (22) Refer to the PC inquiry report on “Price Regulation of Airport Services”, 23 January 2002, and the Government’s response to the report, 13 May 2002. (23) The sale of Sydney Airport was contemplated in 1997, however the timing of the sale was not confirmed until 2001. As you would be aware, in September 2001 the Government decided to defer the sale until 2002. (24) The second reading speech on the Airports Bill 1996, stated that the Government’s election commitments included that Sydney and Sydney West would be withdrawn from the airport leasing process until there is a solution to the aircraft noise issues there. (25) The pricing regulatory regime was not designed to achieve the Government’s policy objectives on aircraft noise and Sydney West Airport. (26) Paragraph 8(1)(b) of the Productivity Commission Act states that in the performance of its functions, the Commission must have regard to the need to reduce regulation of industry (including regulation by the States, Territories and local government) where this is consistent with the social and economic goals of the Commonwealth Government. (27) Yes. The LTOP is a Ministerial Direction issued by power given to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services under subsection 16(1) of the Air Services Act. (28) The Government remains fully committed to sharing the noise generated by Sydney Airport. It is clear that under the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) aircraft noise is being shared much more fairly than under the previous Labor Government’s regime. The Plan has re-opened the east-west runway, introduced a much greater spread of flight paths, and provided communities periods of respite through rotating the use of runways. (29) The Government has concluded, after lengthy and careful consideration, that Sydney Airport can continue to meet the growing level of air travel demand and that it would be premature to build a second major airport for the city. (30) The PC concluded its report on 23 January 2002. (31) Refer to response to question 30. (32) There are a number of regulatory controls already enshrined in Commonwealth legislation which ensure that Sydney Airport is operated in an environmentally acceptable manner. The Sydney Airport Curfew Act 1995 imposes a curfew on the Airport. The Sydney Airport Demand Management Act 1997 ensures that no more than 80 movement slots are allocated in any one hour. The Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) for Sydney Airport, which is implemented under a Ministerial Direction issued under the Air Services Act 1995, ensures that the noise is shared and that the east-west runway is used to the greatest practical extent. The Air Navigation (Aircraft Noise) Regulations require individual aircraft to meet specified noise standards. (33) Paragraph 8(1)(e) of the Productivity Commission Act states that in the performance of its functions, the Commission must have regard to the need to recognise the interests of industries, employees, consumers and the community, likely to be affected by measures proposed by the Commission. (34) Refer to response to question 30. (35) Yes. (36) Paragraph 8(1)(i) of the Productivity Commission Act states that in the performance of its functions, the Commission must have regard to the need to ensure that industry develops in a way that is ecologically sustainable. Where appropriate, this may extend to considering environmental and ecological constraints. (37) No, as the Productivity Commission has completed its review of Price Regulation of Airport Services. (38) No. In addition to the matters specified in its terms of reference, the Commission must have regard to a range of social and economic factors in carrying out its public inquiry functions under the Productivity Commission Act 1998. These include: the need to facilitate structural changes in the economy and to avoid social and economic hardships arising from those changes; a recognition of the interests of industries, employees, consumers and the community likely to be affected by the measures proposed by the Commission; and a need to increase employment and promote regional development. (39) Refer to response to question (38). (40) Yes. Immigration: Ship Jumpers (Question No. 348 amended answer) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 2002: (1) In 2000-2001, what has been the cost to shipping companies for ship jumpers who are in detention centres. (2) What was the cost to each shipping company to return ship jumpers back to their country in 2000– 2001. (3) What has been the average time ship jumpers have remained in detention. (4) How many ship jumpers in 2000-2001 lodged immigration applications. (5) In 2000-2001, how many unauthorised ship jumpers had successful migration outcomes and of these, (a) how many were successful protection visa applications and (b) from which countries did they originate. (6) Is it still the case that crew entering Australia by ship are covered under the Special Purpose Visa. (7) Is there a requirement by Australian Customs Service officers to notify his Department of all ship entries and the number of crew on each ship. (8) What, if any, checks are carried out by his Department regarding character issues of any crew on ships. (9) Are any checks carried out against his Department’s movement alert list; if not, why are they exempt. (10) How many migration applications by ship jumpers in the last three financial years were rejected on grounds of character. (11) How many applications for the period 1 July 1996 to May 2001 had successful protection applications and what were the nationalities of these people. In substitution for the answer which appeared in Hansard page 4770 of 27 June 2002: (1) Under the Navigation Act 1912, as opposed to the Migration Act 1958, shipping companies are responsible for the costs of removing crew who desert their vessels. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) does not record data on the cost to each shipping company of removal of deserters. (2) See answer to part (1) above. (3) The average time deserters remained in detention in Australia in 2000-2001 was 55 days. (4) In 2000-2001, 3 deserters lodged protection visa applications. (5) Of the 3 deserters who lodged protection visa applications in 2000-2001, (a) 1 was successful and (b) the applicant was a PRC citizen. (6) Yes, crew of non-military ships entering and departing Australia during the course of their voyage are taken to hold Special Purpose Visas. (7) There is no requirement under the Customs Act to notify DIMIA of all ship entries and the number of crew on each ship. However, the Australian Customs Service (ACS) checks details of all crew and passengers on each ship entering Australia against ACS and DIMIA alert lists and reports to (8) ACS checks all crew and passenger lists against ACS and DIMIA alert lists, reports any persons of concern to DIMIA and seeks direction before the vessel enters an Australian port. (9) See answer to (8) above. (10) The Department does not keep separate data on deserters whose visa applications have been rejected on character grounds. (11) For the period 1 July 1996 to May 2001, 9 deserters were granted protection visas in Australia; of these 4 were from Iran, 1 from Algeria, 1 from Turkey, 1 from PRC and 2 were stateless persons. Australian Accounting Standards Board (Question No. 371) Ms Burke asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 May 2002: (1) What role does the Accounting Standards Board have in the setting of standards for the accounting industry. (2) Do the standards developed and approved by the Accounting Standards Board apply to the insurance industry. (3) Following the collapse of (a) United Medical Protection (UMP) and allegations that the accounting practices used by UMP were other than standard within the industry and (b) HIH, has the Accounting Standards Board undertaken investigations into this matter; if not, why not; if so, (i) what investigations were carried out (ii) what conclusions have been drawn from those investigations and (iii) have the results and conclusions been communicated to the accounting and insurance industries. (1) The functions and powers of the Australian Accounting Standards Board (AASB) are set out in section 227 of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 2001. The AASB makes accounting standards for entities required to prepare financial reports under the Corporations Act 2001, as well as for public sector and not-for-profit entities. (2) Entities such as registered general insurers, registered life insurers and medical defence organisations (MDOs) would generally be reporting entities under the Corporations Act and therefore are subject to accounting standards.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Dimia If There Are Any Persons Of Concern On A Ship

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(3) (a) (i) The AASB’s Urgent Issues Group (UIG) examined issues related to the recognition of claims by MDOs, including claims incurred but not reported (IBNR), that is, liabilities arising from incidents in relation to which a claim has not yet been notified, during 2001. (ii) In June 2002, an Abstract was agreed by the AASB requiring MDOs to account for IBNR liabilities. (iii) Yes. (b) The AASB will consider the need to review AASB 1023/AAS 26 in the light of any further information that may emerge from the HIH Royal Commission or any relevant Royal Commission recommendations. The AASB plans in any event to review its insurance standards in the process of contributing to the development of a standard on insurance by the International Accounting Standards Board. Education: Advanced Diploma of Interpreting and Translating (Question No. 658) Ms Gillard asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) How many students graduating from the Advanced Diploma of Interpreting and Translating to date have been granted a Graduate Skilled Temporary Visa, subclass 497. (2) Is he aware that the Advanced Diploma of Interpreting and Translating gives graduates a professional accreditation as awarded by the National Accreditation Authority for Translators and Interpreters, yet overseas graduates of this course cannot be granted a Graduate Skilled Temporary Visa, subclass 497 as the course has not been undertaken in English. (3) Does an anomaly exist in that the overseas graduates in the Advanced Diploma of Interpreting and Translating, requiring an advanced level of bilingual proficiency to graduate, are unable to be granted a Graduate Skilled Temporary Visa, subclass 497 as the course has not been undertaken in English. (4) Will he review the Graduate Skilled Temporary Visa, subclass 497, to enable overseas students graduating from the Advanced Diploma of Interpreting and Translating to apply for this visa category considering it is impossible to produce bilingual professional translators completing courses in English only. (1) The Department has no record of an overseas student having been granted a Graduate Skilled Temporary Visa after graduating from an Advanced Diploma of Interpreting and Translating course. (2) The onshore General Skilled Migration (GSM) program was introduced on 1 July 2001. It enables eligible overseas students to be exempted from the recent work experience requirement if they demonstrate that they completed a degree, diploma or trade qualification in Australia with the medium of instruction in English. It is correct that to date the Adelaide Skilled Processing Centre has been refusing GSM applications from overseas students who have an Advanced Diploma in Interpreting and Translating from an Australian institution because they do not meet the ‘all instruction in English’ requirement. (3) The policy intention was to maintain the integrity of the GSM program by excluding overseas students who gain tertiary qualifications in Australia in a Language Other Than English (LOTE), in particular, those gaining qualifications in their mother tongue. It was not the policy intention to exclude interpreters and translators who have a pre-existing advanced level of proficiency in the English language. I agree that it is not appropriate to exclude such persons from the GSM program because they do not meet the ‘all instruction in English’ requirement. (4) My Department has reviewed the policy in relation to Advanced Diploma of Interpreting and Translating courses. I have agreed that such courses meet the requirement that all instruction be in English, for the purposes of the GSM program. Science: Stem Cell Research (Question No. 662) Mr Murphy asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Is the Research Involving Embryos and Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002 ostensibly a Health portfolio matter; if not, why not; if so, why was it not introduced by the Minister for Health.
title: Dimia If There Are Any Persons Of Concern On A Ship

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) Is it his understanding that both the Government and Opposition parties in the House of Representatives and in the Senate have agreed that this bill be determined by a conscience vote; if so, what is his definition of a conscience vote. (3) Is he aware that on Sunday, 11 August 2002, there was a public meeting at the Wesley Theatrette, 220 Pitt Street Sydney, attended by in excess of one thousand members of the public; if so, has he been issued a transcript or video/audio tape of the proceedings at that meeting. (4) In light of the overwhelming evidence against the experimentation on human embryos, will he now declare his opposition to this bill and recommend to his parliamentary colleagues and all Members of Parliament in both Houses to do likewise; if not, why not. (5) Does the bill define the term ‘human embryo’; if so, is a human embryo a human being; if not, why not. (6) In introducing the bill, did he state that he could not find a sufficient moral difference between allowing embryos to succumb in this way and destroying them through research that might advance life-saving and life-enhancing therapies. (7) What life-saving and life-enhancing therapies does he refer to with respect to embryonic stem cell research. (8) In light of the overwhelming evidence presented by the various speakers at the Wesley Theatrette on 11 August 2002, are the real gains in medical science in the discovery of the life-saving and lifeenhancing therapies to be found in adult stem cell research; if not, why not. (9) Is he able to say which medical, chemical and other corporations have an interest in this bill; if so, who are those corporations and what are their interests. (10) Which sectors of the Australian and international economy will benefit financially from the introduction of this bill. (11) Has adult stem cell research demonstrated substantial medical advancements in the treatment of (a) regeneration of tissue from heart attack sufferers, (b) paraplegia from damaged spinal chords, (c) sickle cell anaemia, (d) insulin dependant diabetics, (e) regeneration of immunity systems, (f) eye damage and (g) brain cell re-implantation in the partial treatment of symptoms of Parkinson’s disease. (1) Yes. The Bill is a Health portfolio matter. The Minister for Ageing, the Hon Kevin Andrews MP, has portfolio responsibility for this matter. I introduced the Prohibition of Human Cloning and Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002 into the parliament to stand by my commitment to the Council of Australian Governments agreement of 5 April 2002 to introduce Commonwealth legislation by June 2002. The Minister for Health and Ageing has introduced the two new bills, the Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002 and the Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002 into the Senate. (2) I have allowed the Government a conscience vote on splitting the original Bill and subsequently on the Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002 and the Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002. I understand that the Opposition did the same. A conscience vote, or a free vote, occurs when a party has no particular policy on a matter or when a party feels that members should be permitted to exercise their responsibility in accordance with their conscience. A conscience vote is one in which a member is able to vote based on his or her own values rather than party lines. (3) Yes; no transcript or video/audio tape has been drawn to my attention. (4) No. I support the Research Involving Embryos Bill 2002 because I do not consider there is a sufficient moral difference between allowing embryos to succumb and destroying them through research and because I have been advised that ongoing research into both adult and embryonic stem cells will allow all potential therapies to be explored. I have allowed a conscience vote on this issue and therefore have not recommended members vote in a particular way. (5) Yes. Human embryo is defined as a live embryo that has a human genome or an altered human genome and that has been developing for less than 8 weeks since the appearance of 2 pro-nuclei or the initiation of its development by other means. In relation to whether a human embryo is a human being, as I said in my summing up speech of the second reading debate in the House, “there is no one christian tradition that instructs us as to where life starts”. (6) Yes.
title: Dimia If There Are Any Persons Of Concern On A Ship

speaker: Mr Howard
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(7) I have been advised that research on both adult stem cell and embryonic stem cells could lead to life-saving and life-enhancing therapies for diseases such as diabetes, Parkinson’s disease and Alzheimer's disease. (8) I am advised that there have been significant developments recently in research using adult stem cells, however, I have also been advised that we need to pursue both embryonic and adult stem cell research to maximise our chances of discovering cures to diseases. (9) The Bill provides a framework for research. I cannot say what this leads to in terms of the potential interest of medical, chemical or other corporations in subsequent commercial applications. (10) In finding cures and treatments for disease, medical, scientific and research organisations would be required to carry out extensive research and commit a large amount of resources. Those organisations that do find cures and treatments for disease may benefit financially from their work. (11) (a) to (g) I understand that a range of studies, in both adult and embryonic stem cells, using both human and animal tissues has demonstrated the potential of stem cells for the development of therapies for a range of diseases. Aviation: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport (Question No. 664) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) How many breaches of the Sydney Airport curfew have occurred since 1 October 1998. (2) What are the times and dates of breaches since 1 October 1998. (3) What is the name of the airline company and type of aircraft responsible for each breach since 1 October 1998. (4) Have any fines associated with these breaches been visited on the airline companies; if so, what are the full details, including the names of the airline companies and the time and date of each breach incurring a fine; if not, why not. (5) Will he ensure that all airline companies are fined where a breach of the Sydney Airport curfew occurs which is due to the fault of the airline company; if not, why not. (1) There have been nine breaches of the Sydney Airport Curfew since October 1998. (2) to (4) Details of the nine breaches are as follows: Date Time Name of airline Type of aircraft Fine9 February 1999 11:30pm KLM/Alitalia Boeing 747 Nil 27 February 1999 01:43am Thai Airways Boeing 747 $10,000 27 January 1999 04:37am Capital Jet Charter Cessna Citation525 Nil 21 February 1999 00:19am Capital Jet Charter Cessna Citation525 Nil 21 February 1999 01:12am Capital Jet Charter Cessna Citation525 Nil 18 March 1999 05:26am Capital Jet Charter Cessna Citation525 Nil 24 March 1999 05:21am Capital Jet Charter Cessna Citation525 Nil5 May 1999 11:13pm Olympic Airways Boeing 747 Nil 26 June 2000 11:30pm Lauda Air Boeing 777 $10,000 My Department pursues each breach, depending on advice from the Director of Public Prosecutions, and the outcome of each case, as the Honourable Member is aware, is a matter for the Court’s decision. (5) As indicated in the answer to (4), this is a matter for the Director of Public Prosecutions and the relevant Court.
title: Dimia If There Are Any Persons Of Concern On A Ship

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Australian Bicycle Council: National Strategy (Question No. 686) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Has his attention been drawn to objectives 2.1, 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, 4.1, 4.2, 4.3, 4.5, 5.1, 5.4 and 6.4 of Australia Cycling: The National Strategy and the attribution of responsibility to the Commonwealth Government for their implementation. (2) To what extent has development occurred on policies, planning procedures, regulations and initiatives at a Commonwealth level to achieve this strategy aim. (3) To what extent has development occurred on the creation of an integrated cycling network, within and between communities, and the development of a national standard for such a cycling network. (4) How many new and renovated public and private developments, including end-of-trip facilities for cyclists, have been undertaken since the commencement of the National Strategy and where are they located. (5) On which buildings, transport nodes and public places have end-of-trip facilities for cyclists been fitted. (6) Has development occurred on a national public communication strategy to improve the awareness of all (a) road users on how they can better share roads and (b) path users on how they can better share paths; if so, (i) what is the extent of the development, (ii) has the strategy been implemented and (iii) what measures prove community awareness of the strategy. (7) Are cycling aspects taken into consideration during road safety audits and blackspot identification; if so, (a) what cycling factors are considered, (b) who is responsible for considering these factors and (c) where is this consideration documented. (8) Has development occurred on road users behavioural programs or initiatives to improve cyclist safety; if so, (a) what is the extent of the development, (b) how is it being implemented and (c) what measures are there to indicate success. (9) Has development occurred on a national marketing strategy to promote cycling and its benefits; if so, (a) what is the extent of the development, (b) at what cost to the Commonwealth and (c) what measures are there to indicate success. (10) Has data been collected and or research commissioned by the Commonwealth providing information to assist decisions made about cycling issues; if so (a) what does the data or research reveal, (b) where can the information be accessed and (c) what cost has been incurred by the Commonwealth in this data collection and research. (11) What community education programs have been implemented aimed at encouraging adults to cycle and what has been the cost to the Commonwealth of the programmes. (1) Responsibility for the overall implementation of Australia Cycling, rests primarily with the State, Territory and Local Government authorities, which are best placed to determine local solutions and funding requirements. The Commonwealth also acknowledges a shared responsibility with the States and Territories for some of the strategy’s specific objectives. Its contributions to these are coordinated through the Australian Bicycle Council (the Council), which is the body that was established to oversee implementation of the strategy on behalf of all jurisdictions. The Commonwealth also provides the Secretariat to the Australian Bicycle Council. (2) The Commonwealth continues to support development of policies, regulations, planning and procedures that support the National Strategy through its participation in the Australian Bicycle Council. Relevant portfolios also contribute to policy areas such as road safety and sustainable transport, which support the objectives of the National Strategy. For example the Commonwealth is committed to making improvements to road safety awareness and supports the National Road Safety Strategy 2001 to 2010, which commits all governments (Federal, State and Territory) to achieving better safety outcomes for road users, including cyclists. The Department of Transport and Regional Services (DOTARS) has also arranged for a representative of the Australian Greenhouse Office to provide a presentation on their Travel Demand Programme at the July meeting of the Australian Bicycle Council. This provided an opportunity for
title: Dimia If There Are Any Persons Of Concern On A Ship

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:the Council to identify synergies between Australia Cycling and activities at the Commonwealth level. In addition DOTARS has also recently amended the Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme so that cyclists are also eligible for a rebate for the costs of shipping their bicycle by ferry between the mainland and Tasmania. This decision supports Objective 2 of Australia Cycling by ensuring cycling is valued appropriately in policies and planning. (3) The Australian Bicycle Council has been working to highlight the need to develop nationally consistent standards for the use of coloured bicycle lanes and the development of appropriate signage for bicycle paths. The Commonwealth does not have jurisdiction over the development of cycle ways as State, Territory and Local governments are responsible for the planning and regulation of local roadways including cycling networks. However the Commonwealth continues to support the development of policies to support integrated cycle ways through its participation in the Council. (4) The Commonwealth supports objective 3 of Australia Cycling to promote end-of-trip facilities that encourage increased cycling. However the development of local roads and cycle ways including the establishment end of trip facilities for cyclists are the responsibility of State, Territory and Local governments (in particular Planning and Road Traffic Authorities) and private developers. (5) The Commonwealth does not keep records of all the buildings in Australia that have end-of-trip facilities for cyclists. (6) (a) and (b) The Council has determined its priorities for the implementation of the strategy and has at this stage not commenced development of a communication Strategy for road and path users as these objectives are largely being met by State Governments. For example, there have been Share the Road campaigns in SA, WA, QLD and NSW. In addition Bikewest in WA produced a leaflet called ’Using Shared Paths with Courtesy and Safety’ and the NT has produced a brochure on cycling on the road which included cyclists rights and obligations on the road and how to use shared paths. As mentioned above the Commonwealth also supports road safety measures under the National Road Safety Strategy. The aim of the ten-year strategy is to reduce the national road fatality rate by 40% through the implementation of successive National Road Safety Strategy Action Plans. Priority safety measures for cyclists identified in the current 2001 and 2002 Action Plan include targeted promotion of helmet use, support for school-based education programmes and increased cycle paths and lanes. (7) Yes. (a) The factors to be considered in the assessment of hazardous road locations are outlined by Austroads, the Association of Australian and New Zealand road transport and traffic authorities, in a range of published guides to traffic engineering practice. Of particular relevance are Austroads’ ‘Road Safety Audit’ (Austroads Publication No. AP-30/94 or AP-G30/02), Guide to Traffic Engineering Practice Part4 – Road Crashes (AP-11.4/88) and Guide to Traffic Engineering Practice Part 14 – Bicycles (AP-11.14/99). (b) The responsible road authority. (c) The responsible road authority would typically hold a site assessment and/or Road Safety Audit report. (8) Yes (a) The National Road Safety Strategy Action Plan 2001 and 2002 recognises that bicycle safety will benefit from measures aimed more directly at car drivers, such as alcohol control and speed management initiatives. A key example is the progressive introduction of 50 km/h urban speed limits, which is providing improved safety and amenity for cyclists in many jurisdictions. (b) A proposal to lower the default urban speed limit specified in the Australian National Road Rules to 50 km/h is being developed for submission to Ministers of the Australian Transport Council. The ATSB provided funding of $30,000 in 2000-2001 and advice to assist with the preparation of a comprehensive regulatory impact statement supporting the proposal to introduce 50 km/h urban speed limits. (c) The success of the National Road Safety Strategy will be based on overall long-term reductions in National Road Toll Statistics. State, Territory and local governments are also undertaking individual programs. (9) The Council is undertaking a number of actions to market and promote the benefits of cycling including: Developing a set of key messages that will be used to promote cycling and its benefits. The messages will target key occupational groups such as the police force, town planners and the members of the health profession; Upgrading the Council website to provide more comprehensive progress updates on the status of implementation of the National Strategy and other relevant cycling events; The Council is undertaking a study of national cycling data that will assist in identifying cycling trends. Among other things its is expected the outcomes of this study will assist the Council to more effectively target relevant sectors of the community in promoting cycling; and Developing a banner stand to be used at the Bicycling Australia Show and future events to promote cycling and the National Strategy. (b) DOTARS bears the costs of maintaining the Council website and is also funding the development of a banner stand that will be used to promote the National Strategy at the Australian Bicycle Show and relevant events in the future. (c) The performance measure formally under Strategy 5.1 of Australia Cycling is the community reports increased knowledge about the benefits of cycling. (10) The Council is undertaking a study of national cycling data to identify and compare trends in bicycle use between states and territories and address inconsistencies in data collection methodologies through the development of appropriate guidelines. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau also collects national data on bicycle road fatalities to assist policy makers to monitor safety trends for cycling. (a) The National Cycling Data study indicates some inconsistencies in the data collection methodologies applied between states and thus the results obtained. The Council is developing a discussion paper that will highlight this issue and make recommendations to address this problem in the future. (b) The ATSB data is published in the Road Fatalities Monthly Bulletin and the Road Fatalities Australia Statistical Summary. (c) The Commonwealth bears the expense of maintaining the ATSB data on cycling road fatalities. The expense of the National Cycling Data Study is shared by all jurisdictions. However the Commonwealth Department of Health and Ageing provided the funding for the original guidelines. The Council also undertook a project with Austroads funding to develop guidelines on Forecasting Demand for Cycling Facilities to assist providers in determining future development needs. (11) Relevant State, Territory and Local government authorities are responsible for community education programmes aimed at encouraging adults to cycle. A key example is the adult riders’ course developed by CyclingSouth in conjunction with the Hobart City Council. There are no costs to the Commonwealth associated with such programmes. Immigration: Asylum Seekers (Question No. 692 amended answer) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 2002: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 348 (Hansard, 27 June 2002, page 4770) concerning ship jumpers, who met the cost of detention and removal of the 18 crew members who deserted their vessels in 2000-2001. (2) Were there incidents of people jumping ships in 2001-2002; if so, (a) how many people did so, (b) what was the cost of detention and removal of these people, (c) how many of these people lodged immigration applications and (d) what was the (i) nature, (ii) outcome and (iii) country of origin of each applicant. (3) How many ship jumpers have been granted protection visas each year from 1996-97 and from July 2000 to May 2001, and of these, are there still some in progress and not finalised. (4) For each of the last 10 financial years, (a) how many ship jumpers were there and (b) what payments under the Migration Act were made by shipping companies for the cost of detention and removal of each ship jumper. (5) Is there a requirement under the Customs Act to notify his Department of all ship entries and the number of crew on each ship; if not, what action has his Department taken to change this in light of the terrorism attacks of 11 September 2001 and the need to protect Australia’s borders. In substitution for the answer which appeared in Hansard page 7075 of 23 September 2002: (1) Shipping companies are responsible for costs associated with removal of crews who desert their vessels. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) does not record data on the cost to each shipping company of detention and removal of deserters. (2) Yes. (a) 43. (b) $22,200. (c) 30. (d) (i) 28 Protection Visa applications; 1 Bridging VisaE (BVE) application; 1 Special Category Visa (SCV) application (ii) 15 Protection Visa applications refused; 1 BVE granted; 1 SCV granted; all other applications continue to be processed (iii) Of the persons refused Protection Visas 10 were from Bangladesh, 2 from India, 2 from Iran and 1 from Egypt; the 1 SCV applicant was from New Zealand; the 1 BVE applicant was from Sri Lanka; of the persons whose applications are still being processed 4 are from Iran, 3 from Egypt, 3 from Turkey, 1 from Bangladesh, 1 from Myanmar, and 1 from Pakistan. (3) Statistical reports on deserters are not available prior to October 2000 when new procedures for the recording of deserters were put in place. Of the persons who deserted ship between July 2000 and May 2001, 1 was granted a protection visa, and there are no unfinalised protection visa applications from that time. (4) See answer to (3) above. (a) 2001-02 43 deserters; 2000-01 69 deserters; and 1999-00 65 deserters (b) DIMIA does not record data on the cost to each shipping company of detention and removal of deserters. (5) There is no requirement under the Customs Act to notify DIMIA of all ship entries and the number of crew on each ship. However, the Australian Customs Service (ACS) checks details of all crew and passengers on each ship entering Australia against ACS and DIMIA alert lists and reports to events of 11 September 2001, and continue to be enforced. Civil Aviation Safety Authority (Question No. 790) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 20 August 2002: (1) How many actions were exercised by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) under Civil Aviation Regulation 269 (CAR 269) in each of the past five years. (2) In how many actions was no further action taken. (3) How many actions resulted in CASA recommendations to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) for further legal action or prosecution action against operators. (4) Of those recommendations to the DPP for further legal action or prosecutions, how many were proceeded with, and of these, how many resulted in successful prosecutions, failed prosecutions or were withdrawn. (5) How many were appealed and what was the outcome.
title: Dimia If There Are Any Persons Of Concern On A Ship

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(6) For each prosecution or legal action, what sum was spent by the commonwealth for each case and what was the cost for each agency involved. (7) For each prosecution or legal action, what sum (a) was recouped from prosecuted operators and (b) did the Commonwealth pay in costs to operators. (8) With respect to CASA’s power to cancel, suspend or vary aviation operators’ certificates under CAR 269, what is the internal CASA process taken to establish the veracity of a planned action before it is proceeded with. (9) At what level of management are decisions under CAR 269 determined. (10) Is each stage of a planned action recorded; if so, where is the file held and is it subject to Freedom of Information procedures; if not, why not. (11) Does the decision making process assess the impact of an action under CAR 269 on the reputation or viability of an operator, or is safety the only consideration. (12) If an action is not proceeded with, or is subsequently stopped or withdrawn, does CASA apologise to the operator or issue any public notice advising that the action will not proceed and offer reasons why; if not, why not. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has provided the following advice. (1) The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) does not centrally record each action exercised by CASA under Civil Aviation Regulation (CAR) 269. To extract the requested information would require a review of each action commenced by the CASA within the last five years to determine if the action was exercised using CAR 269. CASA is unable therefore to provide the requested information without a significant input of resources. (2) See1 above. (3) Over the five-year period, 123 matters were referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). (4) Over the five-year period the DPP commenced prosecution action in 67 matters. 21 matters were withdrawn and 58 convictions were recorded. These figures do not amount to 67 referred actions, as some matters that are recorded as being finalised during the period were in fact referred to the DPP prior to the 5-year period. Similarly, some matters that are recorded as being referred to the DPP during the 5-year period are still awaiting assessment. The situation is summarised below. Referred to DPP Summons signed Finalised Withdrawn Acquitted Convicted 1998 12 6 11 5 1999 21 12 30 3 2000 39 19 34 5 17 2001 35 21 41 11 3 27 2002* 16 9 11 2 0 9 Total 123 67 127 21 3 58 * Figures for 2002 are for the period 1 Jan to 31 July 2002 (5) Appeals are handled by the DPP. CASA does not maintain records of the outcome in these cases. (6) (7) Costs of prosecutions and other DPP action are matters for the DPP. (8) Action to cancel, suspend or vary Air Operator’s Certificates is not taken under CAR 269. Such action is taken under sections 28BA, 28BB and 28BC of the Civil Aviation Act. The process followed by the Authority when cancelling, suspending or cancelling an Air Operator’s Certificate is detailed in the Compliance and Enforcement Manual. This manual is available on the CASA website at wwww.casa.gov.au. (9) Delegations under CAR 269 are restricted to General Manager, or higher, level. (10) Yes. Each stage is recorded on a CASA In-Confidence file at the office where the action was commenced. The General Manager, General Aviation Operations also commences a CASA InConfidence file in the event the action results in a recommendation to the General Manager for cancellation, suspension or variation of the licence against which the action was commenced. CASA records are subject to Freedom of Information procedures in accordance with the requirements of the Freedom of Information Act.
title: Dimia If There Are Any Persons Of Concern On The Ship These Procedures Were In Place Prior To The

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(11) CASA is required to exercise its powers and perform its functions in accordance with the requirements of the Civil Aviation Act 1988. Under sub-section 9A(1) of the Act, CASA must regard the safety of air navigation as the most important consideration when exercising its powers and performing its functions. (12) Before taking action under CAR 269, CASA is required to issue a Show Cause notice. CAR 269 requires that the person receiving a Show Cause notice be given a reasonable opportunity to show cause why CASA should not take the proposed action. In the event that a person provides acceptable reasons why it would be inappropriate for CASA to take the proposed action, CASA will not proceed with the action. CASA will advise the person of its decision and the reasons for the decision. This process is not a public process and CASA does not generally publicise that it has issued a Show Cause notice to a person. It would therefore be inappropriate for CASA to issue any public notice that it is not proceeding with a particular show cause action. Whether or not CASA apologises to the person concerned depends upon the circumstances of each case. Communications, Information Technology and the Arts: Staffing (Question No. 801) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 20 August 2002: (1) How many (a) full time permanent staff, (b) part time permanent staff, (c) full time contract staff and (d) part time contract staff were employed by (i) the Minister’s Department and (ii) agencies within the Minister’s portfolio as at (A) 30 March 1996 and (B) 30 June 2002. (2) For each category of engagement referred to in part (1) and employed by (a) the Minister’s Department and (b) agencies within the Minister’s portfolio, where were such persons located in (i) 30 March 1996 and (ii) 30 June 2002. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (A) The information sought by the honourable member in relation to part (1) (A) and part (2)(i) of his question is not readily available and I am not prepared to authorise the use of the resources that would be required to provide that information. I am able to inform the honourable member, however, that data on APS staffing as at 30 June 1996 is contained in the Australian Public Service Statistical Bulletin 1995-1996 which is publicly available. The honourable member should be aware, however, that changes in APS functions and administrative arrangements between 1996 and 2002 may render direct comparisons between the data for those years invalid. (2)(i) See (1) (A) above. The following portfolio agencies have answered all other parts of the question; The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Communications Authority, Australian Broadcasting Authority, Telstra, Australia Post, Their answers are presented in tabular form below.

Aviation: Maroochydore Airport (Question No. 826) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 20 August 2002: (1) Has the Minister been contacted by Freedom Air in relation to a proposal to conduct flights from New Zealand to Maroochydore Airport; if so, when and what was the Minister’s response. (2) What aviation and customs related charges are imposed by the Commonwealth or Commonwealth agencies on a foreign airline landing at Maroochydore airport. (3) How do these costs compare with the costs for a foreign airline to conduct the same flights to Brisbane airport or Cairns airport. (4) Are there any infrastructure, technical or policy barriers to the operation of foreign airline operations to Maroochydore airport; if so, what are they and what sum would they cost to provide. (1) No. (2) Aviation charges imposed on airlines by Airservices Australia at Maroochydore Airport are for Terminal Navigation Charges (TNC) only. The cost for international and domestic services are the same. (3) Airservices Australia has advised that charges for B737-300 aircraft (56,740 kg maximum take off weight) at Maroochydore, Brisbane and Cairns airports are as follows: Tower Airservices Terminal Navigation Airservices Aviation Rescue and Fire Charge (TNC) Charge per tonne Fighting (ARFF) Charge per tonne landed landed (incl GST) (Incl GST) Maroochydore $7.42 N/A Brisbane $4.96 $1.46 Cairns $8.75 $3.83 (4) From the perspective of the Department of Transport and Regional Services there are no policy barriers to the operation by foreign airlines of international flights to Maroochydore Airport. In respect to the rights of foreign airlines to operate international flights to Maroochydore, the Government’s regional package allows unrestricted access to regional international airports. The regional package is being included progressively in air services arrangements with our bilateral partners. Airports may be designated as international where facilities are available for the formalities incident to customs, immigration, quarantine and other requirements in connection with the arrival in or departure from Australian territory of aircraft. The provision of such facilities is a matter for discussion between these agencies, the airport operator and the airline. Prior to commencement of any international services, Maroochydore Airport would be required to discuss implementing a checked baggage screening program with the Department of Transport and Regional Services.
title: Dimia If There Are Any Persons Of Concern On The Ship These Procedures Were In Place Prior To The

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Shipping: Foreign Seafarers (Question No. 828) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 21 August 2002: (1) Is he able to say whether the productivity level of 25 Ukranian seafarers is equivalent to that of 17 Australian seafarers aboard the CSL Yarra. (2) Is it detrimental to Australia’s security to have Australian merchant ships crewed by foreign seafarers. (3) In times of conflict would Australia’s economic independence be affected without an Australian flagged and crewed fleet. (4) Did Australia use foreign ships to take personnel and materiel to East Timor in 1999; if so, why. (1) CSL makes the commercial decisions in respect of the number of crew and its productivity. CSL, like other ship operators, are required to meet international standards of safety and marine environment protection. The port state control program administered by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority is aimed at ensuring compliance with those standards. (2) Merchant ships with foreign crew members come to Australia to carry our international trade. The Government is working with the International Maritime Organization (IMO) on developing an International Ship and Port Facility (ISPS) Code. This will mean that all ships and ports involved in international trade will be subject to strong security measures, and those that are not compliant with the Code will be prevented from trading. (3) On all advice to me, no. (4) The logistics for the East Timor operation were organised by the Department of Defence. I am advised, however, that both Australian and foreign vessels were used according to the capability and availability of the vessels for the requisite tasks on a strictly commercial basis. North-West Shelf Venture: Revenue (Question No. 850) Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 August 2002: (1) What are the revenue implications for the Commonwealth of the decision of the North West Shelf Venture partners to allow the China National Offshore Oil Company equity in the project. (2) What are the revenue implications for the Commonwealth of the decision to give China exclusive rights to ship liquefied natural gas from Australia to China. The decisions of the North West Shelf Venture partners to allow the China National Offshore Oil Company (CNOOC) to take equity in the project and participate in shipping LNG arise from a commercial agreement. The Government is not party to the agreement and therefore cannot quantify the revenue implications. (2) Has work been undertaken in the electoral division of Wills; if so, what percentage has been completed; if not, when will it be completed. (3) How frequently is the addresses register updated in the electoral division of Wills. ourable member’s question: (1) The Physical Address Register Verification Project does involve Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) staff physically verifying addresses. However, the AEC has not undertaken to visit every address in each division. A pilot Physical Address Register Verification exercise was undertaken in Tasmania resulting in a recommendation that only addresses with street numbering be considered for verification in this manner. Some verification work has also been undertaken in New South Wales and Western Australia. The AEC will be undertaking an evaluation of the Physical Address Register Verification before deciding whether to extend the process nationally. (2) No Physical Address Register Verification work has been undertaken in the Division of Wills and at this stage there are no plans or funding to undertake this exercise in the immediate future. (3) The Address Register is updated in every Division, including the Division of Wills, every time an enrolment form is received for an address that is not included on the Address Register. However, new addresses are only added after the address has been checked as being valid. In most cases, divisions would up date the Address Register each day. Agriculture: Dairy Regional Assistance Program (Question No. 944) Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 23 September 2002: (1) What is the total sum allocated to the Dairy Regional Assistance Program. (2) What projects have been funded under the program and what sum did each receive. (3) In what Local Government Areas are these projects located. (4) What projects have been awarded to (a) not-for-profit organisations and (b) private enterprise. (1) $65 million. (2) Refer Attachment A. (3) Not Applicable. The programme does not collect project information by Local Government Area. (4) Refer Attachment B. Australian Defence Force: Defence Housing Authority (Question No. 961) Mr Edwards asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 September 2002: (1) Is the Defence Housing Authority (DHA) planning to make substantial special dividends to the Government instead of improving stock numbers, quality of housing and improvements in singles accommodation; if so, why. (2) Has $84 million in DHA property value been surrendered to the Government for the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust. (3) What difficulties are anticipated as DHA disengages from pre-1996 leases and what strategies are and will be implemented to overcome these difficulties. (4) How many staff does DHA employ, what is the State and Territory breakdown of that staff and what was the corresponding figure for each of the previous 6 years. (5) When is it anticipated to present the proposed amendments to the DHA legislation to Parliament. (6) What are the anticipated risks in the over-reliance on private investor leasing arrangements and what contingencies have been implemented to cover these risks and ensure they are properly managed. (7) What are the salary levels of the Chairman and Director of the DHA and what are the individual areas of expertise they bring to DHA. (8) Is she aware of the concerns of Australian Defence Force families about the continued run down of DHA owned housing stock and what is the Government doing to either halt the run down or address these concerns. (9) What are the repair and maintenance budgets for DHA housing for each financial year from 19992000. (10) How many individual business units exist within DHA and for each, (a) where they are located, (b) how many staff does each have, (c) how many clients does each serve and (d) are they run as separate organisational delivery and profit centres; if so, how (i) are they managed and (ii) are profits distributed. (11) Will she table a copy of the services agreement with her Department under which it is claimed price and risk sharing arrangements, services and payments are being made. (12) Given that the total value of properties being managed by DHA on behalf of Defence is approximately $3.8 billion, of which $1.4 billion is owned by DHA, what is the breakdown of ownership of the remaining $2.4 billion. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s questions is as follows: (1) No. (2) Yes (3) DHA seeks to convert 30% of pre-1996 leases to post-1996 leases and replace the remainder of houses required by new stock. The main problem that could arise would be an inability to persuade sufficient lessors. Should this occur, DHA will increase its plans to acquire new stock including direct leasing and increase reliance on rental allowances. (4) 658 staff as at 30 June 2002. The distribution of staff members by State and Territory, and the corresponding figures for previous years were: Date ACT NT QLD NSW VIC TAS SA WA TOTAL 30 June 2002 294 45 96 134 39 2 20 28 658 30 June 2001 204 28 65 97 27 2 16 20 459 30 June 2000 113 21 49 55 22 2 13 15 290 30 June 1999 84 16 42 51 18 1 14 13 239 30 June 1998 84 21 45 63 26 1 12 14 266 30 June 1997 74 22 50 62 33 2 13 13 269 30 June 1996 75 22 50 75 50 3 12 15 302 * Note: ACT staff numbers include Head Office employees (5) It is not possible at this time to indicate a time frame for their presentation to Parliament. (6) Over reliance on private investor leasing would increase DHA’s risk of not having access to sufficient properties in the event that lessors refuse to renew the leases. DHA mitigates this risk by owning certain properties close to military bases where land is not available to replace the houses, and by continually reviewing its reliance on private investor leasing in the light of demand and market conditions. (7) Salary details for Directors are determined and published by the Remuneration Tribunal. Profiles of Directors are published in the DHA Annual Report. (8) DHA regularly consults the Australian Defence Force families on housing needs and it is represented on the DHA Board by the Defence Families of Australia Convener. DHA is continually improving the quality of its stock and its planned increased reliance on private investors through the Sale and Leaseback Program is important in this regard. DHA modifies its risk as indicated in 6 above. (9) 1999/2000 $21.3 million 2000/2001 $29.1 million 2001/2002 $30.7 million 2002/2003 $33.6 million (10) Business Units within DHA: (a) Defence member services: Tenancy Management Property Management Relocation Services Home Owner (b) Sales and Development. (c) Investment Management. All business operations are managed through DHA’s Head Office located in Canberra with regional operations carried out through regionally based Housing Management Centres. As the majority of DHA staff carry out activities for each business line, staff numbers by business line cannot be provided. These business lines are run as profit centres, however, dividend distributions to the Government are made out of DHA’s consolidated corporate results rather than from the business lines. (11) No. The document is Commercial-In-Confidence. (12) The ownership of the $2.4 billion of stock under management is by private investors who lease their houses to DHA on long-term lease arrangements. Health: Breast Cancer (Question No. 966) Ms Vamvakinou asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 14 October 2002: (1) What was the level of partial and radical breast mastectomy in terms of (a) the number and (b) percentage of total breast cancer patients in (i) 1996, (ii) 1997, (iii) 1998, (iv) 1999, (v) 2000 and (vi) 2001 on a national and State and Territory basis. (2) What was the level of breast reconstruction in terms of (a) the number and (b) percentage of total breast cancer patients in (i) 1996, (ii) 1997, (iii) 1998, (iv) 1999, (v) 2000 and (vi) 2001 on a national and State and Territory basis. (3) What were the waiting times for breast prostheses or forms for patients following a partial or radical mastectomy in (i) 1996 (ii) 1997 (iii) 1998 (iv) 1999 (v) 2000 and (vi) 2001 on a national and State and Territory basis. the honourable member’s question: (1) (a) The most recent data specifically on the number of mastectomies can be derived from the National Hospital Morbidity Database, which provides information about the number of breast mastectomies and all subclassifications for the years 1996-2000. The data collection focuses on hospital procedures rather than individual patients. The following table gives nationally the total number of mastectomy procedures performed, for separations with a diagnosis of primary or secondary neoplasm of the breast (female breast cancer only): 1996 1997 1998 1999 2000 2001 (six months only) 5982 6347 6539 6556 6541 3051 From the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. Additional data can be found at the following website: www.aihw.gov.au. Data from the year 2001 is not yet available. (b) (i-v) Data published in Surgical management of breast cancer in Australia in 1995 (Hill et al.) found that approximately 49 per cent of women with breast cancer had mastectomy surgery. Women with early breast cancer from non-urban areas were more likely to have a mastectomy (54 per cent) compared to women with early breast cancer from urban areas (44 per cent). This is the
