theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer toonly comprehensive published national data available on breast cancer treatment patterns. It describes each incident of breast cancer notified to cancer registries throughout Australia between April and September 1995. (b) (vi) A direct request would need to be made to each State and Territory cancer registry to obtain any data broken down by State and Territory classification. (2) (a) The most recent data on the number of breast reconstructions can be derived from the National Hospital Morbidity Database, which provides information about the number of general breast reconstructions for the years 1996-2000. Some of the coding systems in use, however, do not specify breast reconstruction following mastectomy. The data are available on a national basis, through the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare at www.aihw.gov.au. Data for the year 2001 is not yet available. (b) (i-v) Data published in Surgical management of breast cancer in Australia in 1995 (Hill et al.) shows women under 50 years of age were more likely to have breast conserving surgery compared with women over 50 years of age. Fifteen per cent of women under 50 years of age with early breast cancer were planning to have or had had a reconstruction. Four per cent of women 50 years of age and over with early breast cancer were planning to have, or have had a reconstruction. Women with early breast cancer from urban areas were more likely to have breast-conserving surgery (56 per cent) compared to women with early breast cancer in non-urban areas (46 per cent). This is the only comprehensive published national data available, describing each incident of breast cancer notified to cancer registries throughout Australia between April and September 1995. (b) (vi) A direct request would need to be made to each State and Territory cancer registry to obtain the data on a State and Territory basis. (3) (i-vi) National data on waiting times for breast prostheses or forms for patients are not collected. State and Territories are responsible for the provision of breast prostheses and a direct request would need to be made to each State and Territory to obtain the information requested. Australian Defence Force: Employment (Question No. 973) Mr Danby asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 October 2002: (1) Are members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) unable to get employment in other Government agencies until they have received a discharge certificate. (2) Is it a fact that in the past members of the ADF could take long service leave and complete police training, then discharge or return to the ADF if their police training was unsuccessful. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Section 20 of the Public Service Act 1999 confers on each Agency Head the rights, duties and powers of an employer with respect to APS employees within that Agency. Therefore, within the legal framework supplied by the PS Act, each Agency Head is able to establish certain conditions of employment and service for the Agency’s employees. It is not known what policies other Commonwealth agencies may have implemented with respect to engaging ex ADF personnel in APS positions prior to discharge from full time service becoming effective. In Defence, up until 29 April 2002, it was possible for a discharging ADF member to be engaged in an APS position before the member’s discharge became effective. The member could proceed on paid leave to commence civilian employment while the discharge was being processed. However the policy was changed on the decision of the Secretary and the Chief of the Defence Force, because the Commonwealth Ombudsman questioned the probity of the arrangement whereby an ADF member could be doubly accruing certain Commonwealth employment benefits. If other Commonwealth agencies have implemented similar policies it is because of decisions made within their respective agencies – it is not possible for Defence to impose its policy on other Agencies as each has certain autonomy with respect to employment within the legal framework. (2) I am unable to comment on the employment practices of the various police agencies, both at the State and Federal level. However, members of the ADF have certain obligations under Defence Instruction (General) (DI(G)) Personnel (PERS) 25-2 Employment and Voluntary Activities of Australian Defence Force Members in Off-Duty Hours requiring all ADF members to seek prior approval from their commander before engaging in outside employment in off-duty hours, including during periods of leave. A permanent member of the ADF who is on long service leave, must obtain approval in writing in accordance with DI(G) PERS 25-2 before engaging in paid employment outside the ADF in off-duty hours. The policy lists those occasions where approval is not normally to be given, for example, where the employment would create a conflict of interest with the member’s public duty, where it would interfere with the member’s efficiency or where the employment could bring the ADF into disrepute. ADF members, upon fulfilling their obligations under DI(G) PERS 25-2 Employment and Voluntary Activities of Australian Defence Force Members in Off-Duty Hours, would be able to engage in employment dependant upon the employment practices of the engaging organisation. Of course, ADF members are entitled to return to Defence once their long service leave has expired. Aviation: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport (Question No. 978) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 October 2002: (1) Further to the answer to part (8) of question No. 610 (Hansard, 23 September 2002, page 6800), does the privatisation of Sydney Airport mean that there is now commercial pressure to relinquish statutory controls over aircraft movements during both curfew and non-curfew periods at that airport; if so, what is that pressure from the airport lessee company or any other person; if not, why not. (2) Is the same commercial pressure on non-aeronautical services at Sydney Airport that led to the elimination of the pricing surveillance regulatory regime at that airport, the same commercial pressure that will see the aircraft movement and hence the aircraft noise regulatory regime weakened in the future. (3) Does the net effect of privatisation of ownership of Sydney Airport mean the taking away of public ownership of the direct management of Sydney Airport as both landlord and land manager. (4) Does taking away effective management and land interest at Sydney Airport mean the loss of the most effective environmental management device of all, that is, actual ownership of the land; if not, why not. (5) With the passing of title in the airport lease to a private company, is the ability to effectively manage Sydney Airports aircraft noise problems relinquished with the passing of that title; if not, why not. (1) No. The sale of the airport does not change the Government’s aircraft movement cap or noise management policies in any way – the Government retains full regulatory control. Sydney Airport will continue to be subject to the 80 aircraft movements per hour planning cap, the curfew from 11pm to 6am and the noise sharing policy implemented through the Sydney Airport Long Term Operating Plan. (2) The Productivity Commission was asked in December 2000 to examine whether there was an ongoing need for price regulation of airports. The Commission’s final report was provided to the Government on 25 January 2002. The Government accepted the Commission’s recommendation that Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth, Adelaide, Canberra and Darwin airports be subject to price monitoring for five years commencing 1 July 2002. The Government has reserved the right to reimpose price controls if it is found that airport operators were abusing their market power by unjustifiably raising prices. See also the answer to (1) above. (3) and (4) As a leased Federal airport, Sydney Airport remains a Commonwealth place and continues to be subject to the provisions of the Airports Act 1996. The Act is the basis of a comprehensive regulatory regime for land use, planning, building controls and environmental management, which is administered by the Commonwealth. (5) No. See answer to (1) above.

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Aviation: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport (Question No. 980) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 October 2002: (1) In his responses to part (2) of question No. 629 (Hansard, 23 September 2002, page 6802) and part (8) of question No. 610 (Hansard, 23 September 2002, page 6800) did he state that he has given an assurance that the Government had no intention of changing its noise policy and residents of Sydney could be confident that the sale of Sydney Airport will not change the Governments noise policy in any way but states that a Government cannot bind the actions of a future government; if so, are these statements contradictory. (2) If so, is it a fact that he cannot and could never give, such an assurance as no Minister nor any Government can bind the actions of a future Government, including this current Government; if not, why not. (1) and (2) The Government’s aircraft noise policy in relation to Sydney Airport was clearly stated at the time of the Airport’s sale. Health Insurance: Medibank Private (Question No. 985) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 14 October 2002: (1) Has the Minister seen a report by Mark Metherell titled “Medibank loss comes at a 13% premium” on page 3 of the Sydney Morning Herald on 28 September 2002. (2) Do many members of Medibank Private face a premium increase of up to 6%, taking the average increase to about 13% for the year, following the Government’s decision to allow the fund to cut discounts; if not, why not. (3) Has the Minister’s attention been drawn to the statement by Nicola Ballenden of the Australian Consumers’ Association that the discount cuts were a premium increase by any other name. (4) Why did Medibank Private make a record $175 million dollar loss in the last financial year. (5) Can the Minister guarantee that the Government will not sell Medibank Private; if so, how; if not, why not. the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes. (2) Medibank Private estimates that 95% of its members (2,650,929) will be affected by the removal of discounts of between 4% and 6%. (3) Yes. (4) Medibank Private released their Annual Report for the financial year 2001-02 on 27 September 2002. This document is available publicly and contains full disclosure of their financial results. (5) The Minister for Finance and Administration is responsible for the scoping study on the possible sale of Medibank Private as announced in the 2002-03 Budget. The Government has not made any decision to sell Medibank Private. (2) What checks has his Department carried out to verify that Australian trained graduates were not available to fill the positions which were the subject of the nominations.

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to(3) Is he aware that qualified Australian cardiothoracic surgeons cannot obtain employment with Australian hospitals in their specialist field. (1) In the 2000-01 and 2001-02 financial years and the first quarter of 2002-03 the Department approved six nominations under the Employer Nomination Scheme for specialist surgeons. The five occupations covered by the six nominations were Neurosurgeon, Orthopaedic Surgeon, Burns Injury Specialist, Associate Surgeon (specialising in abdominal surgery) and Associate Professor of Surgery. Nominations for cardiothoracic surgeons, if there were any under the Employer Nomination Scheme, do not appear to have been recorded as such during 2000-02 or 2002-03 to date. It is possible cardiothoracic surgeons may have entered under other categories, including non-skill related categories such as spouses. (2) Under the Employer Nomination Scheme, labour market testing of the vacant position is required unless the occupation is in short supply at a national level. Occupations on the Migration Occupation in Demand List (MODL) therefore do not require labour market testing. Under this visa class, certification from state or territory health authorities that the occupation is in shortage such as in an “area of need” is required. Labour market testing generally involves placing advertisements in metropolitan and national newspapers and relevant professional journals and lodgement of the position with a Job Network member or other large recruitment agency. The labour market testing must be undertaken in the six months immediately before lodging the nomination. The employer must provide documentary evidence of the labour market testing undertaken, details of any unsuccessful applicants and reasons for not selecting each of the persons. (3) The Australian Medical Workforce Advisory Committee reported on “The Cardiothoracic Surgery Workforce in Australia – Supply and Requirements 2000-2011” in April 2001. The report concluded that: “the cardiothoracic surgery workforce is adequately meeting current requirements. To ensure requirements continue to be met, the Working Party recommends that the number of trainees entering the advanced cardiothoracic surgery trainee program be maintained at approximately five per year. In recent years an average of five trainees graduated from the training program each year.” Industry, Tourism and Resources: Program Evaluations (Question No. 990) Dr Emerson asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 14 October 2002: (1) What were the outcomes of the evaluations of the Innovation Investment Fund (IIF) and the Commercialising Emerging Technologies (COMET) program that were conducted on behalf of his Department in 2002. (2) What were the specific findings of the evaluations for (a) the Innovation Investment funds program and (b) the COMET program. (3) What is the Government’s response to these evaluations. (4) Are the evaluations publicly available; if not, are there plans to make them publicly available. (5) How many rounds of funding have been offered under COMET since the program commenced. (6) When did each round occur and what sum of money was approved in each round. (8) Of the additional COMET business advisers announced in July 2001, how many have been appointed? (9) Will the number of business advisers be increased from 10 to 17 as announced in July 2001; if so, where will they be located, if not, why not? Health: Outer Metropolitan Doctors Scheme (Question No. 996) Mr Brendan O’Connor asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 15 October 2002: (1) What is the Government doing to arrest the critical shortages of doctors in the outer metropolitan areas of Melbourne. (2) What incentives will the Government provide doctors to locate in Melton and Sunbury. (3) What assistance will be provided to existing medical services to enable them to attract sufficient doctors. the honourable member’s question: (1) The 2002-03 Federal Budget allocated $80 million over four years to establish the More Doctors for Outer Metropolitan Areas Measure to increase the number of medical practitioners working in the outer metropolitan areas of the six State capital cities. Three programs were outlined to meet the Government’s commitment to outer metropolitan areas. These were: allowing specialist trainees and medical researchers to work in supervised general practice programs in outer-metropolitan areas under the Outer Metropolitan Workforce Shortage (Specialist Trainees and Medical Researchers) Program; requiring doctors undertaking the ‘general stream’ of the general practice training program to undertake a placement in designated outer-metropolitan areas as part of the Outer Metropolitan GP Registrars Program; and allowing non-vocationally recognised medical practitioners who undertake a vocational recognition program and who agree to work in designated outer metropolitan areas to become eligible for higher Medicare rebates as part of the Outer Metropolitan (Other Medical Practitioners) Relocation Incentive Program. The first two programs are scheduled for implementation in early 2003, while the third program is scheduled for implementation later this year. (2) Practices in both Melton and Sunbury will be eligible for the More Doctors for Outer Metropolitan Areas Measure. (3) The Department will be writing to all known eligible practices under the More Doctors for Outer Metropolitan Areas Measure, informing them of the three programs and providing details on how they can participate. It is proposed that assistance will be provided to eligible practices to help locate eligible medical practitioners. The Department also proposes to provide eligible medical practices with suitable support to facilitate a smooth transition for new doctors to outer metropolitan practices. These support arrangements are being developed in conjunction with established medical organisations. In addition, practices in the designated outer metropolitan areas will be eligible for assistance to become Royal Australian College of General Practitioner accredited training practices, which will encourage more practices in areas of doctor shortage to participate in the training of General Practice Registrars. theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the ArtsITOL is a Commonwealth Government program, administered by the National Office for the Information Economy. ITOL provides competitive grant assistance for the development of collaborative projects for the trial and adoption of business-to-business (B2B) e-commerce solutions. ITOL encourages industry groups and small business to identify and adopt commercial uses of the Internet. ITOL is a catalyst for industry groups to work collaboratively to solve common problems on an industry wide basis, rather than working individually and developing multiple solutions and in some cases unnecessarily duplicating efforts. Research& Evaluation No funding has been provided by Research& Evaluation to any of these organisations. However, seed funding was provided under the Strategic Initiatives Programme (SIP) in relation to the establishment of the Rural Education Forum Australia (REFA). As REFA was not incorporated a funding agreement was made with Nationwide Farmers Inc (NFA) on the basis that NFA would forward payments to the REFA on the achievement of agreed milestones. The NFA is a subsidiary company within the National Farmers Federation. The first payment of $115,560 was made to Nationwide Farmers Inc (NFA) on 30 June 2002. The NFA was not providing a paid service to the Commonwealth. Rather it was acting as a conduit to receive funds into a trust account for an interim period until REFA became an incorporated body and was able to accept the funds itself. Since this time REFA has become incorporated and NFA has passed the payments to REFA accordingly. An exemption from tender was provided on the grounds that NFA was not providing a paid service to the Commonwealth in receiving funds and passing them on to REFA. speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer toDefence: Navy/Reserve News (Question No. 1030) Mr Danby asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 October 2002: (1) Is the Director-General Reserves Navy unable to continue forwarding gratis copies of Navy/Reserve News to former members of the Navy Reserve. (2) If this decision has been made due to budgetary constraints, what are these constraints. (3) Were other funding measures considered before the subscription fee was introduced. (4) If other funding measures were considered, what were they and why were they not implemented. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Gratis copies of Navy/Reserve News will continue to be forwarded to all Navy Reserve members, both active and inactive. This arrangement is discontinued once Naval Reserve members retire from the Naval Reserve or otherwise cease to be a Naval Reserve member, with the exception that a limited number of retired senior officers have received and will continue to receive complementary copies. Copies of Navy/Reserve News are otherwise available to any member of the public, including former Naval Reserve members, by subscription. (2) There have been some recent budgetary considerations associated with Reserve News distribution. These are as follows: (a) Prior to 28 May 2001 Reserve News was produced and mailed out to Naval Reserve members on a four-weekly basis. From this date, Reserve News was produced fortnightly, together with the fortnightly produced Navy News and mailed-out fortnightly. (b) In December 2001, production of Reserve News reverted to a four-weekly cycle, but a fortnightly mail-out to Naval Reserve members continued, with a copy of Reserve News being included with every second edition of Navy News. (c) In an effort to rein in the increased distribution costs of a fortnightly mail-out, a four-weekly mail-out containing two consecutive issues of Navy News (one of which includes Reserve News), commenced in September 2002. (d) The initial fortnightly mail-out did result in a greater than planned draw down of available FY 2002/03 Reserve News funds, requiring some internal re-allocation. This re-allocation has been made and production and distribution of Reserve News for the remainder of FY 2002/03 on the basis described in sub-paragraph (c) above is assured. (3) A subscription fee for Navy/Reserve News only applies in the circumstance outlined in paragraph (1). This has always been the case. Means to provide a wider gratis distribution of Reserve News to the community generally and to employers is currently being investigated. This is in line with the recent Government initiated program of enhancements to the Australian Defence Force Reserves. (4) As it is not planned to introduce a general gratis distribution of Navy/Reserve News to former Naval Reserve members, no additional funding measures are necessary for this purpose. Health and Ageing: Accommodation Places (Question No. 1032) Ms Jackson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 21 October 2002: (1) Which postcodes or suburbs fall within the South-East Metropolitan Aged Care Planning Region of Perth. (2) On the most recent data, how many residential aged care beds are there in South-East Metropolitan Aged Care Planning Region of Perth. (3) On the most recent data, how many high care and low care residential beds are there in each of the postcodes or suburbs in the South-East Metropolitan Care Planning Region of Perth. (4) On the most recent data, how many of these high care and low care beds, in each of the postcodes or suburbs, are in use. (5) On the most recent data, how many high care and low care beds, in each of the postcodes or areas, have been allocated to the South-East Metropolitan Aged Care Planning Region and are yet to be occupied. (6) Is he aware that 50% of older Australians have to wait more than 1 month and 25% have to wait 3 months or longer to enter a residential aged care home; if not, why not. (7) In each postcode or suburb in the South-East Metropolitan Aged Care Planning Region of Perth, how long do people have to wait for a residential aged care place. (8) Does he intend to implement a key recommendation of the 2001 Two Year Review of Aged Care Reforms and review the indicators of demand for residential and community care; if so, when; if not, why not. (9) Is it government policy that Australians who require residential aged care should be able to access this care in their local community; if not, why not. (10) Can he explain in detail what he means when he states that one of the Government’s major priorities in aged care is to ensure that older Australians are able to access residential aged care. (11) Do Australians residing in the postcodes of 6108, 6107, 6109 and 6110 in the City Of Gosnells in Perth have to move to the postcode areas of 6151 and 6100, some 30 minutes away by car within the South-East Planning Region, to access residential aged care beds; if so why. (12) Is it important for aged people requiring care to be able to access that care within their own local community; if not, why not. (13) Will he rectify the problem of the shortage of residential aged care beds in the City of Gosnells; if so, when; if not, why not. the honourable member’s question: (1) As postcodes and suburbs can overlap Aged Care Planning Regions they are not used in the calculation of aged care provision in a region. An aged care home which is in one postcode area may not be part of the same Aged Care Planning Region as other homes in the same postcode area. Aged Care Planning Regions are based on groupings of Statistical Local Areas (SLAs). In answering the question, place numbers in each SLA will be provided. The SLAs that make up Metropolitan South East Aged Care Planning Region, Western Australia, are: Armadale (C), Belmont (C), Canning (C), Gosnells (C), Serpentine Jarrahdale (S), South Perth (C) and Victoria Park (T). (2) At 30 June 2002 the total number of allocated residential aged care places in Metropolitan South East was 2,909. (3) Allocated Aged Care Places by SLA. speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to(5) Provisionally Allocated Aged Care Places by SLA. June 2002 SLA High care Low care Total Armadale (C) 11 11 Belmont (C) Canning (C) Gosnells (C) 20 53 73 Serpentine Jarrahdale (S) South Perth (C) 3 22 25 Victoria Park (T) Region Total 23 86 109 (6) The Department of Health and Ageing does not collect or keep information on waiting period, the length of time from the date a person chooses or actively seeks to enter residential aged care and the date they actually enter residential aged care. The Department does keep information on entry period, the period of time elapsed between the date a person receives an Aged Care Assessment Team (ACAT) approval for eligibility to enter residential aged care and the date the person actually enters an aged care home. There are a number of factors that impact on the period of time that elapses between the date a person receives an ACAT approval for eligibility to enter residential aged care and the date the person actually enters an aged care home. In May 2002 the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (AIHW) published a report, Entry Period for Residential Aged Care. The report is a statistical analysis of the elapsed time between an assessment of eligibility for residential aged care and the date of actual entry to residential aged care. The report examines but rejects the use of entry period as a proxy for waiting time and, by implication, as a measure of the accessibility of aged care services. The analysis shows that the supply of services in any particular region has a negligible effect on entry period. An important determinant of a short entry period, the AIHW found, is whether the resident had an ACAT assessment performed in hospital rather than when they were living at home. A longer entry period is also strongly related to whether the resident had previously used a Community Aged Care Package (CACP) or residential respite care. As part of the 1997 Aged Care Structural Reforms, the validity of an ACAT approval for high care admission was extended from ninety days to one year. People do not have to act immediately following ACAT approval for admission to residential care. They have time to visit different homes, consider their options, settle their affairs and make arrangements with the home of their choice before they enter care. As the AIHW report confirmed, increased availability of community care and respite care has a significant effect in delaying entry to permanent care. People are able to remain in the community for longer after they have been assessed by an ACAT as eligible for residential care. On average, recipients of CACPs remained in the community fifteen months longer than other residents did before they entered residential care. Similarly, respite care recipients remained in the community longer. (7) See answer to question six. (8) The Department continues to implement this recommendation. The above-mentioned AIHW report is part of this process. The AIHW was contracted in October 2001 to undertake a multivariate statistical analysis of entry periods to residential aged care. The AIHW was also asked to comment on whether ‘entry period’ is a robust performance indicator of accessibility for the aged care system. As mentioned above, this report was published in May 2002. (9) Yes. (10) The Commonwealth Government is committed to ensuring that frail older Australians have reasonable access to quality residential and community care which will enable them to live in dignity. To ensure an equitable distribution of residential aged care places and CACPs, the Government uses a comprehensive planning framework which aims to provide 100 residential aged care places and CACPs for every 1,000 people aged seventy years and over. This benchmark helps achieve a more equitable distribution of places to regions. This planning framework applies across the whole of Australia in both city and country areas. (11) People assessed as eligible for residential aged care base their choice of an aged care home on a number of factors. These factors include whether an aged care home offers extra services, the location of an aged care home in relation to family or friends, and the accreditation and certification status of an aged care home. (12) Yes. Refer to the answer to question ten. (13) Metropolitan South East Aged Care Planning Region has an aged care which exceeds the benchmark figure of 100 residential aged care places and CACPs for every 1,000 people aged seventy years and over. Australian Defence Force: Fitness Standards (Question No. 1034) Mr Edwards asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 October 2002: (1) How many currently serving Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel have been injured undertaking fitness tests since 1998. (2) What measures have been introduced to prevent the loss of experienced ADF members with 6 years or more service due to injury associated with fitness testing. (3) Have new fitness tests been introduced for Defence force job applicants. (4) Will the new fitness standards preclude some women from military roles that they currently perform. (5) Will the new fitness standards open the way for women to enter into combat roles provided they meet the fitness requirements. (6) Have changes to medical and fitness requirements for instructors involved in the cadet scheme resulted in losses of experienced staff. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Injuries related to physical fitness testing in the ADF are not recorded separately and are therefore not available. (2) No specific information is available to suggest that there has been a loss of experienced ADF members as a result of injury associated with fitness testing. (3) All ADF applicants are required to pass a physical fitness assessment (PFA) prior to enlistment. The PFA for the Army was introduced in 1997 and for the Navy and the Air Force in August 2001. The introduction of minimum fitness standards has been a significant factor in the marked reduction in injury rates in recruit training units. (4) A Physical Employment Standards Project is currently underway. The aim is to analyse the ergonomic, human performance and physical capacity requirements for all combat arms in order to develop gender-free, task-based, physical employment standards. The key outcomes are to reduce injuries, provide a more direct linkage of training strategies to the actual tasks being undertaken and inform a range of human resource activities. Until the study is completed and the data analysed no consideration of the possible exclusion of either male or female personnel who do not meet these physical employment standards will be undertaken. (5) Physical competencies are not the only factors that need to be taken into account when considering women for combat roles. A comprehensive range of issues likely to impinge on the effective integration of women into the combat arms needs to be considered in any subsequent policy deliberations. These issues include operational requirements, habitability aspects, medical issues, occupational health and safety issues, posting requirements, social and demographic aspects, psychological issues, fraternisation and personal relationships, overseas military experiences and research, resource implications and community attitudes. (6) Cadet instructors do not have to meet any specific physical fitness standards nor have there been any recent changes to medical standards. Roads to Recovery Program (Question No. 1039) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 22 October 2002: (1) Further to the diagram on page 6 of the Roads to Recovery Program annual report 2001-2002, what are the actual dollars and percentage of total funds used for (a) general maintenance, (b) reconstruction, rehabilitation, widening, (c) sealing, (d) bridges, (e) traffic improvement, (f) constructing a new road, (g) sheeting/resheeting, (h) resealing, (i) drainage, (j) bicycle paths, (k) footpaths and (l) other. (2) Also further to the diagram, what is the actual percentage of funding directed to each Roads to Recovery key outcome, including (a) road safety, (b) improved access for heavy vehicles, (c) economic development, (d) traffic management, (e) equity, (f) access to remote communities, (g) access to international facilities, (h) asset management, (i) amenity, (j) improvements of school bus routes, (k) promotion of tourism and (l) improved recreational opportunities. (3) Can a project example be provided for each outcome referred to in part (2). (4) Was there a measure that included the number of jobs created as a result of the Roads to Recovery expenditure, if so what is it and what are the findings; if not, why not. (5) Further to the comments on page 7 that 244 councils will be shielded from the funding changes announced in the May 2002 Budget rephasing of Roads to Recovery funds, (a) how many and which councils were not shielded from the funding changes announced in the May 2002 Budget, (b) by what sum was each such council affected by the funding changes and (c) how long will the rephasing delay the full receipt of each councils allocation. (1) The diagram on page 6 to which this question refers is derived from an analysis of all projects listed by councils for funding as at 30 June 2002. Category $m % 1 General maintenance 7.4 1.1 2 Constructing a new road 49.2 6.7 3 Reconstruction, rehabilitation, widening 339.9 46.6 4 Sheeting/ Resheeting 51.5 7.2 5 Sealing 98.3 12.9 6 Resealing 73.2 9.7 7 Bridges 51.0 6.9 8 Drainage 36.2 4.6 9 Traffic Improvement 15.5 2.2 10 Bicycle paths / Footpaths 12.5 1.7 11 Studies (strategic plans, EIS) 1.3 0.2 12 Other 3.2 0.4 Total 739.2 100 (2) Councils must submit an annual report on their use of Roads to Recovery funding. As part of this report, councils must provide an estimated percentage of Roads to Recovery expenditure against each of the key outcomes listed. The diagram on page 6 to which this question refers relates to the information provided in the 2000/01 annual reports, at which time programme expenditure totalled $150 million.
title: Company Name 1996 97 1997 98 1998 99 1999 2000 2000 01 2001 02 2002 03

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Outcomes Estimated % of Roads to Recovery expendiAsset Management 30 Road Safety 23 Improved access for heavy vehicles 10 Amenity of nearby residents 7 Economic development 6 Improvements of school bus routes 6 Traffic management 4 Promotion of tourism 3 Equity of access (remote areas) 3 Other3 Access to remote communities 2 Access to intermodal facilities 1 Improved recreational opportunities 1 (3) As the analysis does not involve the listing of individual projects against each outcome, this information is not available. (4) Neither the Roads to Recovery Act 2000, the Programme Conditions or Guidelines require Councils to give details of employment generated by the Programme because this is not a stated objective of the Programme. However, there is some evidence that the Programme has been a substantial employer, especially in rural and regional areas. (2) What can the Minister do to assist the States in the education of Australian citizens, particularly our youth, of the ramifications and cost to the Australian community of all types of fires caused by arson. (1) The Department of Education, Science and Training does not have any statistical information on bushfires arising from arson. (2) As Commonwealth Minister for Education, I am aware that I need to do my part in assisting the teaching profession to guide young Australians to become good citizens, for example in respecting laws made to protect the community from arson. Providing effective civics and citizenship education is a key to maintaining a strong and vital society in the future. From 1997 to 2000 this Government invested $18 million in civics and citizenship education through the Discovering Democracy programme, particularly to develop quality curriculum resources. A further $13.6 million is extending the programme to June 2004 so that teachers receive professional development to fully embed the programme in schools. The report Citizenship and Democracy Australian Students Knowledge and Beliefs The IEA Civic Education Study of Fourteen Year Olds (Australian Council of Educational Research and University of Canberra) which was commissioned by my Department and published in 2001 indicated that while four out of five young Australians appreciate living in a vibrant, free, independent and democratic society, there are a number of young people who are alienated from society. Education is as much about building character as equipping Australia’s young people with skills. All Education Ministers agree to the National Goals for Schooling in the Twenty-First Century including Goal 1.3 about students accepting responsibility for their own actions. I have commissioned a Values Education Study, which was supported by all State and Territory Ministers of Education at the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs meeting in July 2002. Over 600 school applications have been received for grants in response to this study. Many of these schools are working with disengaged youth and are keen to have help in overcoming students’ antisocial behaviour. In early December, I announced the successful schools that will receive up to $7,000 to help them to develop and implement values education in their school. Bushfires (Question No. 1060) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 22 October 2002: (1) Is it a fact that some 70% of bushfires are the result of arson. (2) What can the Minister do to assist the States in the education of Australian citizens, particularly our youth, of the ramifications and cost to the Australian community of all types of fires caused by arson. (1) While a significant proportion of bushfires or wildfires are suspected to be the result of arson, a consistent national approach to the collection and analysis of bushfire data has not been established. I understand that work is being undertaken by the fire authority members of the Australasian Fire Authority Council to establish the framework for the provision of information of this nature to the Productivity Commission.
title: Phiac Private Health Insurance Administration Council

speaker: Dr Nelson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Phiac Private Health Insurance Administration Council

speaker: Mr Tuckey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) There is no doubt that arson is a significant cause of bushfires in all jurisdictions in Australia. In recognition of that, all fire agencies have in place some form of program aimed at reducing the incidence of arson, and most programs focus on juveniles. Primary responsibility for firefighting and crime prevention rests with the States and Territories. In many respects, programs aimed at reducing the incidence of arson fall within the realm of crime prevention and are the responsibility of State and Territory Police Forces, emergency services or National Parks and Wildlife, depending on functional arrangements within the jurisdiction. In terms of more general assistance, Emergency Management Australia, a Division of the Attorney General’s Portfolio, provides funding assistance on behalf of the Commonwealth to improve community awareness of the risks posed by natural and technological hazards. School education, and warning systems and the community are themes under this funding programme. States seeking Commonwealth assistance for specific arson reduction programs can submit proposals to Emergency Management Australia and those proposals will be considered in competition with other disaster mitigation projects for available funding. Notwithstanding the above and its serious implications, statistics arising from the Select Committee investigation into the 01/02 fires in NSW indicate very clearly that 750,000 hectares of NSW National Parks were destroyed by fire and only 2000 hectares of State Forests; this compared to the ratio of the total land areas managed by the two agencies, which was approximately 2 to 1 respectively. In my view, the failure of National Parks and Wildlife Services to practise recognised hazard reduction was a major cause of the magnitude and scope of the fires whatever the initial means of ignition. I condemn both acts of deliberate and or indiscriminate ignition of such fires but forestry management and adequate access routes can ensure that such fires do not do the damage recorded in recent years. Australian Taxation Office: Settlement Deeds (Question No. 1064) Ms Jackson asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 October 2002: (1) How many settlement deeds have been received by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in relation to the settlement offer issued by the Tax Commissioner for investors in mass-marketed taxeffective schemes, where investors were given until 21 June 2002 to take up the offer. (2) How many ATO staff have been allocated to process settlement applications. (3) What is the timetable set out by the ATO to process settlement applications. (4) When will the ATO process payments arising from accepted settlement deeds. (1) The Commissioner has advised me that approximately 51 400 deeds have been received by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in relation to the settlement offer announced on 14 February 2002. (2) There are currently 148 members of staff allocated to process settlement applications. However this number fluctuates according to demand. (3) The plan states that 90% of the deeds should be processed by 30 December 2002. This is dependent on taxpayers providing correct and full information. (4) The ATO is working on a priority basis so that people who have previously paid their debt will have their deeds processed first. The exact timing depends on when the ATO receives all the necessary information. Telstra: Staffing (Question No. 1066) Mr Bevis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 23 October 2002: (1) How many permanent staff did Telstra hire in (a) 2000, (b) 2001 and (c) 2002. (2) How many apprentices did Telstra indenture in (a) 2000, (b) 2001 and (c) 2002. (3) What funds has Telstra allocated for repairs and replacement of new equipment being installed in remote areas when that equipment comes out of warranty.
title: Phiac Private Health Insurance Administration Council

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(4) How many regional centres, staffed with experienced technical people, did Telstra have in September (a) 1999 and (b) 2002. (5) What was the staffing level of technical people in the Kununurra region of Western Australia in September (a) 1999 and (b) 2002. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: Based on information provided by Telstra. In 1998, Telstra introduced the single Customer Field workforce structure. Multiskilling that followed allowed for traditional technical and lines field staff to become multi-functional, resulting in the whole field workforce being able to work on and maintain the access network. Whilst Telstra has seen reductions in traditional field staff numbers as a result of contracting out installation/maintenance work, these external contractors employ their own staff to carry out this work. Having regard to the above, the following information is provided. (1) Telstra hired the following staff in: (a) 2000 3,402 (b) 2001 1,833 (c) 2002 1,111 (2) Telstra, in line with Australia-wide developments in industry training, now employs graduates from the various tertiary institutions around Australia rather than apprentices. Consequently, Telstra did not take on any apprentices during 2000 to 2002. (3) Telstra does not keep data on expenditure related to warranty issues. (4) (a) In September 1999, Telstra had a centralised structure, with seven regional centres serving specific geographic locations, ie Queensland, New South Wales North, New South Wales South, Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia/Northern Territory and Western Australia. (b) In June 2000, Telstra, to better meet the needs of people in rural and remote areas for reliable, up to date communications services, formed Telstra Country Wide (TCW). As of September 2002, TCW was based in 28 regional centres. (5) Telstra’s network is increasingly digitised and some types of service work can now be undertaken remotely. Moreover, Telstra has invested $20b over the last five years to upgrade the network to a world class standard making it more robust. Telstra’s strategic investment into the network means that fewer staff are required to maintain the network. (a) In 1999 the Kununurra region of WA was serviced by 34 technical staff . (b) In 2002, the Kununurra region was serviced by 31 technical staff. Defence: National Service Medal (Question No. 1072) Ms Jackson asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 November 2002: (1) How many National Service Medal applications have been received by the Medals Directorate of her Department. (2) How many National Service Medals applications have been received from applicants in the electoral division of Hasluck. Hasluck Electorate: Centrelink (Question No. 1073) Ms Jackson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 11 November 2002: (1) How many (a) activity test and (b) administrative breaches relating to the (i) Newstart Allowance and (ii) Youth Allowance were issued in 2001-2002 to Centrelink clients in the electoral division of Hasluck. (2) What is the total sum of penalties levied in 2001-2002 to Centrelink clients in the electoral division of Hasluck relating to the (a) Newstart Allowance and (b) Youth Allowance. (3) How many Centrelink clients in the electoral division of Hasluck incurred the penalty of having payments withdrawn for 8 weeks in 2001-2002. lowing answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Limitations exist in providing electoral level breach data using current management information systems. Data is only available by state, Centrelink Customer Service Centre and Centrelink Area Region. Breach data is not extracted and reported at an electoral level and a non conventional data extraction process would be an unreasonable imposition on Centrelink resources. (2) Centrelink is unable to answer question 2. See response to question 1. (3) Centrelink is unable to answer question 3. See response to question 2. Local Government Rangers: Service Medals (Question No. 1074) Mr Murphy asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 11 November 2002: Will he consider granting a fifteen year service medal to local government rangers similar to the fifteen year service medals granted to Police and Ambulance Officers and State Emergency Service and Rural Fire Service volunteers; if so, when; if not, why not. The National Medal is awarded for fifteen years diligent service to members of “service organisations” (police forces, the Australian Protective Service and those members of the following services who perform the primary function of the service: fire, ambulance, emergency and correctional services) and to members of certain voluntary search and rescue groups. New organisations can be considered for access to the medal if they meet the strict criteria laid down in the regulations. theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:similar to a service organisation because the primary function of the organisation is to enforce the law in order to protect persons or property and some or all of the members of the organisation are exposed to the risk of death, injury or trauma in the course of performing that function.” The Commonwealth is prepared to consider access to the National Medal for local government rangers. It is a matter for the state and territory governments to demonstrate that the medal criteria are met. Family Law Court: Disputed Property Cases (Question No. 1076) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 November 2002: (1) What is the present average time taken to settle a disputed property case in the Family Law Court. (2) How does this compare with the average time taken to settle a disputed property case in the Family Law Court in (a) 1995, (b) 1996, (c) 1997, (d) 1998, (e) 1999, (f) 2000, (g) 2001 and (h) 2002. (3) Are Family Law Court settlements being prolonged, inter alia, as a consequence of the property price boom, particularly in Sydney; if so, what are the details; if not, why not. I am advised by the Family Court of Australia that: (1) Disputed property cases in the Family Court of Australia can settle at a number of stages between filing of an application and a defended hearing. All cases pass through a resolution phase before moving to the determination phase. Only approximately 6% of all applications filed are determined by a judge after a defended hearing. Selected studies have shown that approximately 80% of cases filed are settled/resolved within six months of filing. The Court implemented a new case management system (Casetrack) throughout 2002. When this system has been implemented for long enough to ensure accurate data collection, the Court anticipates being able to provide more detailed information about the time taken to settle property disputes. In the meantime, it is able to give figures which relate to the small percentage of cases that proceed to a trial. The Court no longer measures averages, as the Portfolio Budget Statement outcomes are measured in percentiles. The 50th percentile for the 2001-2002 financial year for those cases that were listed for a final hearing is 13.5 months for property matters (from filing to settlement). This figure takes no account of the vast majority of cases which are not so listed. (2) The Court’s outcomes are measured in financial years. The following data is available as a comparison to the answer to Question 1. Again, this relates only to those matters listed for trial: 1998-1999: 12.7 months 1999-2000: 14.0 months 2000-2001: 12.5 months The Court adopted comprehensive electronic measurement of matters listed for final hearing in July 1998. Therefore, information for the periods prior to July 1998 is not provided because it would be either incomplete or misleading for the purpose of this question. (3) The Court is not aware of any impact which changes in property prices might have on the time taken to settle family law matters. Health: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (Question No. 1077) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 11 November 2002: (1) Has the Minister’s attention been drawn to the benefits for diabetic sufferers of the drug Glitazones. (2) When will the Government include Glitazones on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes. (2) Avandia (generic name, rosiglitazone), a drug sponsored by the pharmaceutical company GlaxoSmithKline and Actos (generic name, pioglitazone), sponsored by Eli Lilly are two new oral medi-
title: Phiac Private Health Insurance Administration Council

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:
title: Phiac Private Health Insurance Administration Council

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer tocations for the treatment of Type2 diabetes. They are substantially more expensive than other oral treatments for this condition listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). Each of these drugs have been recommended for inclusion on the PBS by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC), the Government’s advisory body on PBS listings, but only for use in a limited group of patients whose diabetes is difficult to control with other oral medications. There is considered to be a strong demand for both Avandia and Actos outside the patient group proposed by the PBAC and a real risk there will be major use on the PBS in the wider diabetic population. If this occurred, use of these drugs on the PBS would not be cost effective and there would be considerable Budgetary costs. The Government has not agreed to list Avandia and Actos on the PBS to this point. However, my Department is continuing to work with GlaxoSmithKline and Eli Lilly to try to find a basis for subsidising these drugs that acceptably limits the Budgetary risks to the Commonwealth. Trade: Automotive Imports (Question No. 1078) Dr Emerson asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 11 November 2002: (1) What revenue is raised annually from the 15 per cent automotive tariff? (2) What sum is derived from (a) imports of assembled vehicles and (b) imported components? Mr Ian Macfarlane-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) It is estimated that in 2001-02 tariff revenue raised on imports of automotive items rated at 15 per cent was $764 million. There are nearly 400 recognised customs tariff classifications that include automotive products, with the tariff rates on these items ranging from 5 to 15 per cent. Around 150 of these items incur a tariff rate of 15 per cent. The estimated tariff revenue is derived from data supplied by Australian Customs Service to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. (2) Of the $764 million, it is estimated that: (a) $496.5 million came from imports of assembled vehicles; and, (b) $267.5 million came from imports of automotive components. Public Sector Superannuation Scheme: Statements (Question No. 1080) tion, upon notice, on 11 November 2002: (1) Is it true that a computer programming or other administrative error caused the issuing of incorrect superannuation statements by the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme (PSS); if so, from what date were these statements wrong. (2) How many people are affected by the error. (3) Will this error result in all those affected having to do revised tax returns and having their tax reassessed; if so, what is the range of additional tax that would be payable by these retirees. (4) Is the Government considering waiving the additional tax payable; if not, who will pay any costs incurred by these retirees as a direct result of the error by the PSS. swer to the honourable member’s question: (1) ComSuper implemented a new computer system for pensions in May 2002. In migrating pensioner data to the new system, ComSuper identified pre-existing errors in the Undeducted Purchase Price (UPP) and Rebatable Pension amounts held for some PSS pensioners. A decision was taken in June 2002 to review the UPP and rebatable pension amounts of all PSS pensioners, to correct any errors found and to advise affected pensioners of the changes. The data was re-calculated from the date of exit for each PSS member. The revised UPP and Rebatable Pension amounts were provided back to 1994.

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following an(2) Revision of UPP and Rebatable Pension amounts was necessary in 1,723 instances. This affected somewhat less than that number of PSS pensioners as some pensioners had errors in both the rebatable and UPP amounts quoted them. 1273 cases involved errors in the rebatable pension amount (549 overstated and 724 understated). There was an additional 450 instances with errors in the UPP (184 overstated and 266 understated). (3) All affected pensioners were contacted in July and provided with revised information between July and September 2002. Though it is ultimately a matter for the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) to determine, the pensioners were advised of the potential need to contact the ATO for reappraisal of relevant tax returns. ComSuper has supplied the revised data to the ATO. ComSuper is unable to comment on how the ATO will consider these cases. The range of additional tax involving errors in the rebatable pension amounts is: 927 cases (73%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of less than $200. 306 cases (24%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of between $200 and $400. 40 (3%) cases are understood to involve a maximum annual tax variation of greater than $400. The range of additional tax involving errors in the UPP amounts is: 366 cases (80%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of less than $200. 42 cases (10%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of between $200 and $400. 42 cases (10%) are understood to involve a maximum annual tax variation of greater than $400. (4) This question should be referred to the Australian Taxation Office as it falls within their authority. ComSuper will, on request, reimburse reasonable expenses that are incurred by PSS pensioners in submitting amended taxation returns. Hunter Electorate: Centrelink (Question No. 1081) Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 11 November 2002: (1) Is the Minister’s Department planning to relocate Centrelink’s Records Management Unit from Cardiff, NSW. (2) If so, (a) why, (b) to where, (c) how many jobs will be lost in the Hunter, (d) what is the cost of the relocation and (e) will Hunter-based clients not experience delays when seeking decision reviews or pursuing appeal rights as a consequence of the move. lowing answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes. (2) (a) Area Hunter’s current Offsite File Storage facility at Cardiff has reached maximum capacity. Several options were explored in order to identify the most appropriate solution for servicing the Area’s records management requirements into the next decade. Options considered included: 1. Additional file storage racking installed to increase storage capacity of current facility. 2. Additional floor space leased adjacent to current facility (dependent on availability). 3. Relocation of files to Sydney Records Management Unit at Chullora. Based on an evaluation over 10years of information/projections in relation to: Capacity demand/supply. Cost one off/on-going.
title: Phiac Private Health Insurance Administration Council

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the folRelocation of the RMU to Chullora represented a significant saving to Centrelink of approximately $3 million over 10 years, as well as enabling future capacity. This option also aligned with Centrelink’s strategy to maximise economies of scale in relation to Offsite File Storage by having a number of large facilities that service several Areas within each state. (b) Sydney Records Management Unit, Chullora NSW. (c) There are currently 6 ongoing positions located at the RMU. Options for re-deployment to other Centrelink positions within the Hunter region are being investigated. Temporary (nonongoing) staff have been engaged on a needs basis. (d) The anticipated cost of transferring Area Hunter files to Chullora is $150,000. (e) The current records management unit at Cardiff have service-level agreements with each site in Area Hunter which prescribes request turnaround times. There are also courier contracts in place which contain agreed service standards to support the above agreements. As a result of the relocation, service level agreements will be established between the Sydney RMU and Area Hunter sites to maintain current turnaround times. Courier service contracts will specify overnight delivery services from Chullora, as is the current arrangements from Cardiff. Centrelink does not anticipate any reduction in the standard of service provision to Hunter-based clients. Building Rural Leaders Ravenshoe Transport and Regional Services: Staffing (Question No. 1087) 12 November 2002: Has the Minister’s Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices. family commitments. To meet this goal the Department offers a range of flexible working conditions and leave provisions, the support of an Employee Assistance Program and the facilitation of home based work arrangements. Personal Circumstances leave enables employees to better balance the competing demands of work and personal life, by offering a category of leave that can be interpreted broadly to cater more effectively for the wide diversity of individual needs of employees. In addition to a number of long-term flexible work practices offered to employees such as part-time work, extended band-width and annual leave at half pay, the department has incorporated into it’s 2002-2004 Certified Agreement a number of initiatives designed to complement existing provisions. Some examples include: The capacity for an employee to work more hours across fewer days, Employee funded breaks (enabling an employee to plan a long absence and continue to receive a salary while on leave), The capacity for two staff members to share the duties of one position (usually part-time), and The capacity for staff to access Maternity leave at half pay.
title: Phiac Private Health Insurance Administration Council

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister For Transport And Regional Services, Upon Notice, On
title: Dotars Recognises The Need For Employees To Establish An Appropriate Balance Between Work And

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:The Department has in place procedures to assist staff who have been absent from work for an extended period of time to better manage their return to the workplace. The DOTARS Home Based Work program enables employees to undertake duties from home on either a shortor long-term basis. A Carers room and Nursing Parents facility is provided for employees in the principal Canberra address. These facilities have been provided as an alternative to taking leave to care for a dependent in an emergency situation. An Employee Assistance Program provides a professional and confidential service to all DOTARS staff and their family regarding any work or non-work difficulties experienced. Defence: Staffing (Question No. 1090) 12 November 2002: Has the Minister’s Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so, what are those policies and or practices. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: Australian Public Service employees of the Department of Defence are covered by the Defence Employees Certified Agreement (DECA 2002-2003). One of the core principles of the Agreement is ‘assisting employees to balance their work and private commitments’. This is expanded in PartE of the Agreement ‘Balancing Work and Life’, a copy of PartE of the Agreement has been forwarded separately to your office. Below, is an overview of its provisions: Flexible working arrangements such as flexible working hours, flex time, home based work, part time work, job sharing, time off in lieu of travel undertaken outside of the normal working day; Flexible leave arrangements – annual leave with an option to purchase an additional four weeks per year; Christmas stand down; personal leave for illness and caring purposes; long service leave; leave without pay; maternity leave and miscellaneous leave for bereavement, parental, special and study purposes, and one leave day per year which can be taken for unspecified purposes. With agreement, employees may work on public holidays and substitute an alternative day off for their own cultural or religious commitments; Nursing mothers’ and family rooms for family responsibilities such as breast-feeding, short-term emergency dependant care. Family and nursing mothers’ rooms may also be used for medical treatment, religious purposes and a quiet space for meditation or reading; Access to Defence provided child care – centre-based and family day care; Groups are encouraged to introduce other child care initiatives such as vacation/holiday programs to meet regional needs; Reimbursement of dependent care costs when Defence places additional work demands on an employee and no other option but paid care is available; A Health and Wellbeing Strategy which incorporates work/life balance and health and fitness initiatives, to assist staff to develop resilience in times of change and crises. Participation of employees (APS) in Australian Defence Force (ADF) representative sporting, cultural or community activities an on-duty basis where appropriate; A Defence-wide employee assistance program to provide access to professional counselling services for all employees and their dependants; and Access to Defence amenities and facilities on an appropriate basis with Australian Defence Force colleagues. Since the implementation of the DECA 2002-2003, the focus is on marketing the availability of these policies and the appropriate ways of accessing them. Employees and supervisors are targeted through up-to-date web-sites, an information hotline, guides to the DECA principles and policies, and the publication of the Defence Workplace Relations Newsletter, which provides information on the policies and their implementation. Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs: Staffing (Question No. 1094) fairs, upon notice, on 12 November 2002: Has the Minister’s Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices.
title: Dotars Recognises The Need For Employees To Establish An Appropriate Balance Between Work And

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister Assisting The Minister For Defence, Upon Notice, On
title: Dotars Recognises The Need For Employees To Establish An Appropriate Balance Between Work And

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister For Immigration And Multicultural And Indigenous Af
title: Dotars Recognises The Need For Employees To Establish An Appropriate Balance Between Work And

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:The policies and practices that have been introduced into the department to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities are outlined in the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) Certified Agreement, the Workplace Diversity Plan and a message from the Secretary to all departmental staff on 27 September 2002 concerning work and personal life balance. The policies and practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities include: Flexible Working Arrangements The department offers its employees a range of flexible working arrangements to assist them in balancing work and personal responsibilities, including variable working hours, part-time work, job-sharing, home-based work and flextime. Balancing Work and Personal Life The department promotes workplace practices that assist staff to balance their professional and personal responsibilities. These include guidelines for managing meetings efficiently, strategies to manage information overload, time and workload and processes that encourage health and well-being. Flexible Leave Arrangements The department is committed to providing employees with streamlined leave arrangements which facilitate flexibility. Types of leave available to assist employees balancing work and family responsibilities include sick and personal leave, parental leave, maternity leave and purchased leave. The department also maintains a family leave pool for employees to access when they have carer and other family responsibilities. Employee Assistance Program The department provides its employees with access to confidential, professional counselling services to assist with work or personal issues. These services are also available to the family members of employees. Carers’ Room The department maintains a Carers’ Room intended for use by employees to cater for family or personal needs or emergency care situations. Attorney-General: Staffing (Question No. 1096) Has the Minister’s Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices. In July of this year, my Department implemented a new two-year certified agreement covering most Departmental employees. The agreement has a strong focus on work and life balance. Initiatives implemented under the agreement include: Home-based work options for either fixed or indefinite periods. Five days paid paternity leave and five days paid adoption leave. Up to 52 weeks unpaid parental leave. The ability for employees to extend the period of payment for maternity leave to a period of up to 24 weeks at half pay. Maintaining a carer’s room and facilities. Part-time work arrangements are available to all employees. An employee is also entitled to work on a part-time basis during any period within 3 years from the date of birth of a child or placement of an adopted child. Sick and carer’s leave which is not based on a leave credit system but which is managed on the basis of reasonable needs and trust. A variable 48/52 leave scheme which entitles employees to access additional paid leave by reducing annual salary. This is currently utilised by many employees who wish to take leave during school holidays.
title: Dotars Recognises The Need For Employees To Establish An Appropriate Balance Between Work And

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Attorney
theText: General, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:
title: Dotars Recognises The Need For Employees To Establish An Appropriate Balance Between Work And

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Christmas closedown providing employees with an additional two days leave over the Christmas period. Providing employees the option to observe a day of cultural or religious significance instead of a standard public holiday. Financial assistance for relocation expenses for a person who is relocating on engagement to and promotion to, or assignment with the Department. Reimbursement of whole or part of removal expenses for an employee who retires or for the dependants of an employee who dies. Extending the bandwidth of hours within which employees are able to work their normal hours to provide more flexibility to employees, particularly those with caring responsibilities. In addition, the Department provides employees and their families access to an Employee Assistance Program and conducts regular seminars on balancing work and life through the Department’s People Development Scheme. Underlining these initiatives, the Department is committed to and places importance on developing a working environment where employees are able to balance their work and personal responsibilities in a flexible and safe workplace. The Department recognises that employees need to balance their working life commitments with other competing interests such as family and community responsibilities and lifestyle choices. Finance and Administration: Staffing (Question No. 1097) tion, upon notice, on 12 November 2002: Has the Minister’s Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices? swer to the honourable member’s question: The Department of Finance and Administration (Finance) has an extensive program to cover work and home life balance. The principle objective of this program is: “To develop an environment where people can achieve high performance within a supportive, flexible and safe environment, whilst maintaining a healthy balance between work and home.” Work and home life balance is incorporated into both Finance’s business planning and performance agreement frameworks. A section of the Finance intranet site is dedicated to educating managers and employees on Finance’s work and home life balance program. Flexible working arrangements are provided for in the Finance Certified Agreement and in individual AWAs. They can also be arranged directly between employees and managers. Examples of flexibilities utilised include: Employees being able to elect to work part-time hours to enable them to study, care for children, or pursue other personal interests/responsibilities. Support for employees who need to work from home, for example, to care for sick family member, which may include provision of computer equipment and online access to Finance’s IT network. Finance has established an Early Childhood Centre, which opened on 22 July 2002. Employees are able to salary sacrifice their payments to the Centre. It also provides a Mother’s Room and has also entered an agreement with the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia to provide a Maternity Information Leave Kit (MILK) to employees commencing maternity leave. A Department-sponsored gym is located in Finance’s main building. Health services, including on-site annual flu vaccinations and first aid facilities are provided to all employees. In 2002, 339 flu vaccinations were given to departmental employees. An employee assistance program is supported by a confidential, independent and free counselling service for employees and their families.

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following anA dry cleaning collection and delivery service has also been established for employees. Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Work Practices (Question No. 1098) 12 November 2002: Has the Minister’s Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies or practices. The Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) Certified Agreement 2000-2003 outlines the Department’s commitment to providing employees with the flexibility to balance both personal and professional commitments and to plan and manage individual workloads to maximise productivity and balance work and personal commitments. The AFFA Certified Agreement 2000-2003 has provisions for employees to undertake home based work, part-time work or job sharing arrangements. It also provides employees with the flexibility to use Personal Leave provisions for personal illness or unanticipated short-term personal circumstances that may arise that requires absence from the workplace. Maternity Leave and Parental Leave provisions are also outlined in the AFFA Certified Agreement 2000-2003. Employees are entitled to 12 weeks paid maternity leave, with this entitlement also able to be paid over a 24 week period at half pay. Individual work plans and learning agreements allow for discussion between the employee and their supervisor about balancing work and family responsibilities. Other initiatives including the implementation of the Performance through People program in AFFA; access to an Employee Assistance counselling service for AFFA staff and their families; encouragement of Vacation Care and Holiday Programs for children of staff; the provision of a carer’s room in the Edmund Barton Building; and free seminars on planning for life after work. Family and Community Services: Work Practices (Question No. 1099) Services, upon notice, on 12 November 2002: Has the Minister's Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices. lowing answer to the honourable member’s question: “Building stronger families” is a key policy objective for FaCS, so developing family-friendly work practices provides FaCS as an employer with an opportunity to practice what it preaches. Considerable effort has been invested in raising awareness and understanding of work/life policies among staff by using the intranet, promotional activities, statements of support from senior executives, a lunchtime seminar program and an annual Health Expo. Including work/life balance initiatives in the FaCS Certified Agreement and Diversity Plan helps secure organisational and individual commitment to integrating work/life balance into the way the Department does business. A Work-Life Diversity Team is supported in the workplace by a network of contact officers in each Branch and State/Territory Office. Issues have been identified through annual employee surveys and consultations and negotiations for the Department’s Certified Agreement. Measuring and improving performance are also key goals and this involves data analysis and benchmarking work/life balance initiatives. The Department has implemented a range of innovative policies and practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities, including: flexible working arrangements such as access to single days annual leave, part-time, career breaks, time off in lieu, hours negotiated by employees and teleworking; unlimited personal leave (with supervisor approval and appropriate documentation);
