title: Dotars Recognises The Need For Employees To Establish An Appropriate Balance Between Work And

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: The Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the folpaid maternity leave (12 weeks), including access to part-time employment upon return; paid adoption leave (12 weeks, non-gender specific); Parental leave (52 weeks, non-gender specific); a network of family support rooms; family friendly meeting times for Senior Executives (9.30am start); a dedicated Work-Life Diversity team and a network of Work-Life Diversity contact officers; support for employees’ participation in corporate volunteering and a community work placement scheme; a free Work-Life Balance Information and Referral Service; a breast pump loan scheme for breastfeeding mothers; flexible working arrangements such as school term only work are available; Learning at Lunch seminars are held to promote issues such as healthy eating, parenting, dealing with teenagers, stress management and laughter therapy; annual organisation-wide family fun day; extra family care costs if an employee is required to be away from home outside of normal hours and a school holiday family care subsidy; a strategy to promote flexible and balanced working arrangements for Senior Officers; an older employees retention strategy and an Employee Mobility Program; an annual Health Expo for staff, a Health Promotion Program, Health Assessment Program, ergonomic workstation assessments and free flu vaccinations. In September 2002, the Department was recognised for its achievements in providing a family-friendly work environment by jointly winning a National Work and Family Award in the Large Business category run by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Health and Ageing: Work Practices (Question No. 1101) notice, on 12 November 2002: Has the Minister’s Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and practices. the honourable member’s question: Yes. The Department of Health and Ageing has implemented an extensive Health and Life Strategy to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities. The strategy is a commitment made in the Certified Agreement 2000 and is an overarching term used to describe what the Department does to support and help its staff to balance the high demands of their work with their private life. It also seeks to assist staff to improve their health and well being thus to remain productive and continue to add value to the organisation. Some of the existing initiatives include the Organisational Health Strategy, services offered by the Employee Assistance Program, flexibility in hours of attendance, working from home, part-time work, family care assistance and school holiday family care subsidy and the personal leave package. The new Certified Agreement expands the existing initiatives by offering: health and fitness screenings, funding for teams in fitness/health challenges, support for health/fitness week, a seminar series on a range of health and well being issues, support for volunteers and investigating information and support options for older workers. Veterans’ Affairs: Staffing (Question No. 1103)
title: Dotars Recognises The Need For Employees To Establish An Appropriate Balance Between Work And

speaker: Mr Mcclelland Asked The Minister Representing The Minister For Health And Ageing, Upon
title: Dotars Recognises The Need For Employees To Establish An Appropriate Balance Between Work And

speaker: Mr Andrews
theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to12 November 2002: Has the Minister’s Department implemented any policies or practices to assist employees to balance work and family responsibilities; if so what are those policies and or practices. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: The Department of Veterans’ Affairs (DVA) values the diversity of its employees and has employed a number of initiatives and conditions of service to enable employees with family responsibilities to better balance these responsibilities with work. The Department’s flexible workplace arrangements are integrated with all aspects of DVA’s people management policies and practices to enable employees to balance work and caring commitments which are of course subject to operational requirements. Options available to employees provided under the Department of Veterans' Affairs Enterprise Agreement 20022003, Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service Enterprise Agreement 2002-2003 and the Office of Australian War Graves (Field Employees) Agreement 2002-2003 include: flexible working hours; 18 days personal leave per year, an unlimited amount of which can be used for caring purposes; 12 weeks paid maternity leave is available; purchased leave of up to an additional 4 weeks is available to employees. This is particularly valuable to employees with school-age children; a Christmas shutdown, commencing this year, will be available for the first time to enable employees to have a substantial break with their families. Arrangements are being made to ensure that essential services to the Veteran Community are maintained throughout this period; part-time and job sharing opportunities are available to employees; an on-site family room is provided, so that employees can maintain caring responsibilities in emergency situations; home based work is available to employees if the requirements of their position can accommodate this arrangement. Home based work is not strictly available for caring purposes but can assist the employee to balance these commitments; and an Employee Assistance Program is also available to employees and their families should they need the support of professional, independent counselling services. Health: Lifetime Health Cover (Question No. 1105) Ms Hoare asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 12 November 2002: (1) Is the Minister aware of the hardship provisions of Lifetime Health Cover. (2) Did applications for consideration under the hardship provisions expire on 30 June 2002. (3) Did these provisions have a financial impact on the Government’s budgetary position. (4) Will the Minister consider allowing the reintroduction of the hardship provisions; if not, why not. the honourable member’s question: (1) Yes. (2) Yes. (3) No. (4) The hardship provisions will not be reintroduced as they were transitional provisions to assist a smooth introduction of the Lifetime Health Cover policy. The Government continues to monitor the effectiveness of Lifetime Health Cover and recently announced changes for new migrants and veterans. Other changes may be considered in the future if appropriate. Environment: Fleshy Footed Shearwaters (Question No. 1106)

theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer toMr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 12 November 2002: (1) Further to longline fishing and the threat abatement process for boats leaving Mooloolaba, Qld, what action is being taken to protect the Fleshy Footed Shearwaters. (2) Will the line below which bird mitigation is required be shifted from 30 degrees latitude to 20 degrees latitude. (3) Do any fishing boats fish below the current 30 degrees latitude without bird mitigation. (1) Longline vessels leaving Mooloolaba and fishing south of 300S must use the following seabird bycatch mitigation measures: bird scaring or tori lines which must be used at all times; longlines to be set only at night, when seabirds are generally less active; and no discharge of offal to occur when lines are set or hauled. No mandatory measures, other than the discharge of offal regulation, are in place for vessels operating north of 300S where potential bird by-catch is considered to be low. However, bird-scaring lines must be carried and used where necessary. The only exemption to setting lines at night is for scientific purposes. The Australian Fisheries Management Authority can issue scientific permits to operators where a technique of setting and hauling longlines which does not make the baits and hooks available to seabirds can be demonstrated, or is under investigation. (2) Commonwealth agencies are working to collect further data on bird by-catch north of 300S. An observer program, with high priority given to the area between 250S and 300S is intended to commence in early 2003, and will provide enhanced information. The program will take a further six months at which time the results will be reviewed by experts and government agencies. (3) Refer to (1). Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1109) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 November 2002: (1) Further to his replies to questions No. 678 (Hansard, 11 November 2002, page 8680), No. 861 (Hansard, 11 November 2002, page 8697) and No. 862 (Hansard, 24 September 2002, page 6877) and in light of the Director of Public Prosecution’s (DPP’s) recent decision to review the state of health of former Senator Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston in relation to his capacity to stand trial on the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts, will Dr Colston be exhaustively and thoroughly medically examined on this occasion by appropriately qualified and competent expert medical specialists who have never previously examined Dr Colston; if not, why not. (2) Further to his reply to part (3) of question No. 678, why did the DPP not request an up-to-date medical report on the state of health of Dr Colston between 9 February 2001 and July 2002. (3) Since1 July 2002, has Dr Colston been thoroughly and exhaustively examined by appropriately qualified and competent expert medical specialists in relation to his capacity to stand trial on the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts; if so, (a) what are the qualifications, competencies, disciplines and experience of the specialists who have examined Dr Colston; (b) did the DPP provide to the most recent examining doctors copies of the medical reports dated 14 May 1999 and 19 May 1999 by the previous independent expert eminent medical specialists who examined Dr Colston and opined in May 1999 that Dr Colston only had months to live; (c) did the DPP provide to the most recent examining doctors a copy of the taxpayer-funded motor vehicle and aircraft travel records of Dr Colston since 1 July 1999 reflected in the answer to question No. 862 and (d) on what dates did these medical examinations take place. (4) Is he able to say whether Dr Colston is terminally ill; if so, what is Dr Colston’s life expectancy. (5) What assistance can he give to Dr Colston to provide Dr Colston with the opportunity to clear his name and stand trial on the twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts. (1) Dr Colston is being examined by an expert medical specialist who has never previously examined Dr Colston.

Immigration: Student Visas (Question No. 1110) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 13 November 2002: (1) How many requests for ministerial intervention and exercise of his statutory discretions under sections (a) 48B, (b) 137N, (c) 345, (d) 351, (e) 391, (f) 417 and (g) 454 of the Migration Act has he received in each year from 1996 to 2002, inclusive. (2) Is he aware of any other statutory power under the Migration Act or any other Act that gives him discretionary power to substitute a decision of his Department or the Migration Review Tribunal or Refugee Review Tribunal with a more favourable decision of his; if so, what are those provisions. (3) Is he able to provide details of the number of successful interventions granted each from 1996 to 2002 inclusive against each of the statutory powers referred to in part (1) and to compare those figures against the number in which he declined to exercise his power. (1) to (3) Questions 1(a) and 3: Section 48B Note: Section 48B does not provide the Minister with a discretionary power to substitute a more favourable decision. Rather, the Minister may exercise his power under s48B to allow a person subject to the s48A application bar to make a further application for a protection visa. Australian Maritime Safety Authority (Question No. 1114) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 338 (Hansard, 19 August 2002, page 4922) concerning the appointment of Mrs Virginia Chadwick to the Board of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority and her appointment as Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority (GBRMPA), what salary is paid to Mrs Chadwick in her role as the CEO of the (2) Since her appointment, (a) what has she been paid in travel allowance, (b) what is the cost of air travel, taxi’s and hire car expenses incurred by her and (c) is she entitled to a mobile phone and motor vehicle. (3) Is he able to say whether Mrs Chadwick was a former Minister in the NSW Parliament for an extended period, including a period as President of the Legislative Council, and receives a generous pension from the NSW Parliament as a result. (4) Is it Government policy that where a former Senator or Member is entitled to a parliamentary pension, or a spouse or partner is in receipt of a pension, or holds an office of profit under the Crown, the pension may be reduced depending on the remuneration received for the holding of such office; if so, why is the policy position not applied to former State and Territory members of Parliament in receipt of parliamentary pensions. (1) As indicated previously, the position as Chair and Chief Executive officer of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority (GBRMPA) is a BandC PEO, which carries a total remuneration ranging from $170,000 to $286,200. The GBRMPA head office is in Townsville. (2) AMSA records the following payments to Mrs Chadwick for expenses since her appointment in April 2002: (a) $3,105. (b) $8,129. (c) No. (3) and (4) Mrs Chadwick was a member of the New South Wales Legislative Council. The Government has appointed Mrs Chadwick to the GBRMPA position for which she is remunerated and to the AMSA Board for which associated expenses are met. I am not in a position to comment on Mrs Chadwick’s private interests. Defence Integrated Distribution Systems (Question No. 1121) Mr Latham asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: (1) Further to the two Defence Integrated Distribution System (DIDS) tender processes, on the first occasion, was Toll-Tenix ranked fifth on the list of five tenders but subsequently moved into first position. (2) Did former Minister Reith cancel the first tender attempt at DIDS. (3) What reassurances can the Minister provide the House and the employees of DIDS that the second tender process will go through without interference when it is referred back to the Minister and Cabinet for approval. (4) Is the Minister able to say whether three days prior to the preferred tender announcement by Senator Hill, the shares related to the preferred tenderer jumped 16% if so, is the Minister aware of what led to the share price increase and has the Minister investigated this matter, if so what are the results. (5) Can the Minister assure the House that the employment of three high-ranking senior civilian members’ children at Defence Nation Storage and Distribution Centre (DNSDC) in Moorebank was based on merit; if not, what is the Minister doing to stamp out favouritism at DNSDC.

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s questions is as follows:(6) Has one of the DNSDC employee representatives of the Management Review Team for DIDS been placed in a position with no phone or computer access; if so, how can this person fulfil the duties appropriately. (7) Are departmental case managers restricting the type of training that displaced DIDS staff may choose; if so, what plans does the Minister have to allow these staff members the freedom to choose the type of training and re-skilling available. (8) Do the DIDS sessions on ‘Retraining, Redeployment or Redundancy’ vary dramatically in accuracy, content and duration, with some sessions conducted in 25 minutes whilst other sessions are conducted in 2.5 hours; if so, (a) why, (b) does the Minister plan to make appropriate provisions to assist the affected employees and (c) what information from Centrelink and ATO is being provided to these employees. (9) Given that families on low incomes need to predict future income for Family Assistance from Centrelink, what advice does the Minister’s Department provide for low-income families unable to predict their future income. (10) What strategies are used by the Minister’s Department to combat low morale due to the employment insecurity at DNSDC Moorebank. (11) Will the Minister provide compensation for the DIDS employees who have had to endure employment uncertainty for the past 4 years. Mrs Vale-The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The original tender process was set aside by the Government on 9 July 2001. In accordance with the usual Government practice, the respective rankings of participants in confidential tender processes is not disclosed. (2) It was a Government decision to cancel the original tender process. (3) Final selection of the successful tenderer will be conducted in accordance with Government procurement guidelines and Department of Defence procedures. (4) No. (5) The staff selection of the three individuals referred to in the Member’s question was based on merit in accordance with current departmental policy. (6) The Management Review Team for DIDS has, with the announcement of the preferred tender, completed its work. Staff have returned to their normal work locations. (7) The current policy for staff impacted by DIDS is that they are entitled to access training that maximise their redeployment opportunities within the Department and the wider Australian Public Service; or where appropriate, to equip them for employment in the private sector. Case managers are adhering to that guidance. (8) (a) The content of all presentations given to DIDS staff has been the same across all sites. The length of the presentations has varied due to the number of staff attending each session and the number of questions posed by the staff. (b) All briefings accord with the provisions of the Defence Employees Certified Agreement. (c) Australian Taxation Office (ATO) and Centrelink fact sheets are made available at briefings, during one on one financial briefings affected staff are encouraged to contact the ATO or Centrelink where appropriate. (9) All staff whose jobs are impacted by DIDS are in the process of receiving one on one financial advice. This includes estimates for redundancies, if applicable, and lump sum payouts for accrued entitlements. This advice includes, where relevant, contact details for organisations such as Centrelink. (10) All staff impacted by DIDS are managed under a comprehensive Human Resources plan produced specifically for the DIDS project. Within the framework of this Human Resources plan all staff have had one on one briefings from dedicated Human Resources case managers. Staff at each affected site are regularly briefed by unit management and many locations produce regular newsletters. All of these communication and information avenues are used to ensure that staff are informed, thus improving morale. (11) No. Roads: Deer Park Bypass (Question No. 1123) Mr Brendan O’Connor asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 November 2003: (1) Has his attention been drawn to claims by the Victorian Liberal Party that if elected it would work to persuade the Federal Government to construct the Deer Park Bypass as soon as possible. (2) Given that he has previously indicated that funding for the bypass would not be possible for a number of years, can he confirm (a) that the construction of the Deer Park Bypass is not dependent on the result of the Victorian election and (b) when the Deer Park Bypass will be built. (1) Comments in the press during the Victorian election have suggested this. (2) (a) Yes. (b) All Federal road funding in Victoria is heavily committed to several other large projects including the Craigieburn Deviation ($306 million), the Geelong Road ($120 million) and the Scoresby Freeway ($445 million). The scope for funding for the Deer Park Bypass may not be available for a number of years. Melton: Medical Services (Question No. 1124) Mr Brendan O’Connor asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: Given that another medical centre in the town of Melton, Victoria, has declared it will no longer bulk bill patients on Medicare, will the Minister support the Victorian Government’s submission that Melton should be declared an area of high medical need. the honourable member’s question: I have supported the Victorian Government’s submission that Melton should be declared an area of high medical need by classifying the Melton area as a district of workforce shortage. Melton: Medical Services (Question No. 1125) Mr Brendan O’Connor asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: Given that the Victorian Department of Human Services has declared the town of Melton an area of high medical need, will the Minister provide relief for the area by utilising the doctors of the Rural Workforce Agency. the honourable member’s question: I have provided relief by classifying Melton as a district of workforce shortage. However, it is extremely unlikely that the doctors of the Rural Workforce Agency of Victoria will be able to be utilised, as the recruitment programs that it manages are restricted to rural areas and Melton is classified as a metropolitan area. Melton: Medical Services (Question No. 1126) Mr Brendan O’Connor asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: Given that the Victorian Department of Human Services has declared the town of Melton an area of high medical need, will the Minister help relieve the pressure by giving provider numbers for overseas and locally trained doctors with restricted registration.

Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1128) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: (1) Was my letter, dated 27 October 1999 addressed to the then Minister for Justice and Customs on behalf of a constituent regarding her concerns about the competence of the doctors who examined former Senator Malcom Arthur Colston prior to his retirement from the Senate, referred to him for reply. (2) Did his Adviser, Mr Paul Bolster, write on his behalf, to me on 25 November 1999, indicating, inter alia, that, where a person’s health is very poor, the Director of Prosecutions (DPP) may consider that the person is not fit to stand trial, even though the person is still a sitting Member of Parliament. (3) Did Mr Bolster attach a copy of the DPPs’ media statement titled “Prosecution of Mr Malcolm Colston”, dated 5 July 1999 which details the procedure that the DPP adopted in order to evaluate the application that was made by Dr Colston’s solicitors to discontinue the prosecution because of the alleged terminal illness. (4) Did Mr Bolster advise that, in addition to the medical reports of the two eminent and independent medical specialists who examined Dr Colston in May 1999, the decision by the DPP not to proceed ston’s solicitors. (5) In addition to the two eminent and independent medical specialists who examined Dr Colston in May 1999, (a) how many other medical reports relating to the state of health of Dr Colston were provided to the DPP up to 5 July 1999, (b) how many of these reports were provided to the DPP by Dr Colston’s solicitors, (c) how many of these reports indicated that Dr Colston was terminally ill, (d) were any other medical reports on the state of health of Dr Colston provided to the DPP up to 5 July 1999 not provided by Dr Colston’s solicitors; if so, how many and what caused these reports to be provided to the DPP. (6) Excluding the two eminent and independent medical specialists who examined Dr Colston in May 1999, how many other doctors examined Dr Colston and reported on his state of health up to 5 July 1999, for the purposes of the consideration of the DPP. (7) Excluding the two eminent and independent specialists who examined Dr Colston in May 1999, what are the qualifications and competencies of each of the doctors and senior medical specialists who examined Dr Colston and whose reports were taken into consideration by the DPP in reaching his conclusion in July 1999 that there was no prospect of Dr Colston being fit to stand trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts. (8) Did any of these doctors also express the view that Dr Colston was terminally ill; if so, how many. (9) Did any of these doctors express the view that Dr Colston might be fit to stand trial; if so, how many and what did the DPP do to test those views. (1) Yes. (2) Yes. (3) Yes. (4) Yes. (5) (a) 9 (b) 9 (c) 9 (d) No. (6) Dr Colston’s solicitors provided reports from 7 doctors. (7) Surgeon, Oncologist, Consultant Physician, General Practitioner, Interventional Radiologist, Gastroenterologist, Surgeon.

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(8) Yes, 7. (9) No. Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1129) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: Further to the reply to part (2) of question No. 1154 (Hansard, 9 May 2000, page 16100), why did he believe that there was insufficient public interest to justify the release of the medical reports of the two eminent and independent medical specialists who examined former Senator Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston in May 1999 in relation to his fitness to stand trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts. My decision to refuse release was based on the following considerations. The medical reports contained sensitive personal information about Dr Colston. The medical reports were in the possession of the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions which was subject to the provisions of the Privacy Act 1988 in relation to any disclosure of personal information. The Act also applied to me in my capacity as a Minister. The Information Privacy Principles contained in the Privacy Act provide that personal information, subject to certain exceptions, should not be disclosed. The Privacy Act included an exemption which would allow disclosure with the consent of the subject of the information but it was improbable that Dr Colston would give his consent. Other Privacy Act exemptions relating to protection of the public revenue and law enforcement were inapplicable. The reports could have been considered for release under the ‘authorised by law’ exception in the Privacy Act (as the release would be covered by Parliamentary privilege) but that exception did not compel disclosure. On balance the public interest did not weigh in favour of public release of the reports. Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1130) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: Further to his reply to parts (2)(b), (3) and (4) of question No. 1573 (Hansard, 30 August 2000, page 19795) and in light of the flawed conclusions reached in May 1999 by the two eminent and independent medical specialists who reported on the state of health of Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston for the purposes of the Director of Public Prosecutions, will he now make public the content of those reports for the purposes of the public interest or for the purposes of protecting public revenue; if so, when; if not, why not. The Information Privacy Principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988 provide that personal information should generally not be disclosed. Accordingly I am not able to disclose the personal information contained in the reports unless one of the exceptions in the Principles applies. The Privacy Act includes an exemption which would allow disclosure which is reasonably necessary for the purpose of protecting the public revenue. However, it is not reasonably necessary to publicly disclose the reports in this case there are other measures in place to protect the public revenue in relation to the use of official government travel entitlements. The reports could be considered for release under the ‘authorised by law’ exception in the Privacy Act (as the release would be covered by Parliamentary privilege) but that exception does not compel disclosure. A decision whether or not to release the reports subject to parliamentary privilege involves a balancing of competing public interests. The public interest is not established because something is “of interest to the public” a higher standard is required, something that is of serious concern or benefit to the public rather than merely of individual interest. I accept that two considerations to be weighed in the balance in this case are the public interests in the proper administration of justice and in the scrutiny by Parliament of the decisions and actions of the DPP. In arriving at a balance of public interest in a particular case, it is necessary to consider whether the public interest considerations in disclosing the information outweigh the public interest in government agencies protecting the privacy of sensitive personal information in their possession. In this instance the balance favours a decision to refuse public release of the reports.

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1131) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: Further to the reply to part (7) of question No. 1925 (Hansard, 2 November 2000, page 22122) that it was of major importance that the public’s confidence in such basic institutions as the Parliament and the courts be a paramount consideration in the Director of Public Prosecution's (DPP's) decision to decline to proceed with the prosecution of Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston in July 1999, how can the public’s confidence in the Parliament and the courts be now restored, particularly in light of the numerous media ston and the DPP’s handling of this matter since 1999. The DPP has indicated previously that it would, if necessary, review the matter and is presently conducting a review. Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1132) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: (1) Further to the replies to part (19) of question No. 2376 (Hansard, 22 May 2001, page 26749) and part (12) of question No. 2622 (Hansard, 25 September 2001, page 31446) and in the knowledge of the flawed conclusions of the two eminent and independent medical specialists who examined Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston in May 1999, will the Director of Public Prosecutions now obtain copies of all of the medical tests, reports and clinical notes associated with all of the admissions for medical treatment afforded to Dr Colston at Wesley Private Hospital, Brisbane since 1999; if not, why not. (2) Will the DPP obtain copies of all Dr Colston’s medical records held by doctors and institutions who have treated him since July 1999; if not, why not. (1) The independent experts retained by the DPP have assessed medical tests conducted on Dr Colston. (2) See (1). Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1133) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: (1) Did he see a report by Scott Emerson on page 1 of The Australian on Wednesday, 13 November 2002 titled “Snappers and salad keep Colston going”. (2) Did he see where Mr Charlie Economou, Manager of Kenmore Plaza Seafood confirmed that former Senator Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston regularly walks, talks and drops into Mr Economou’s fish and chip shop and that Dr Colston’s regular fare is Greek salad and two snapper and that either Dr Colston or his sons pick up a phone order made to Mr Economou’s shop. (3) Will the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) interview Mr Economou with a view to obtaining more information that may be helpful to the DPP in establishing the level of activity of Dr Colston in relation to his visits to Mr Economou’s shop since July 1999 and Dr Colston’s capacity, or otherwise, of standing trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts; if not, why not. (1) Yes. (2) Yes (3) The DPP assessment will be on the basis of people qualified to give expert advice, and if necessary, evidence about Dr Colston’s fitness to stand trial.

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Health: Motor Neurone Disease (Question No. 1136) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: (1) Is motor neurone disease a fatal degenerative neurological condition affecting nerve cells which control muscles which in turn enable human beings to move, speak, breathe and swallow. (2) With the progress of motor neurone disease, do the nerve cells eventually degenerate and die. (3) Is the average period between diagnosis and death from motor neurone disease approximately three years. (4) Is Rilutek the only disease-modifying drug licensed for the treatment of motor neurone disease. (5) Is the Minister able to say whether more than 50,000 patients worldwide have been treated with Rilutek to date, with the latest data showing a life-extension of up to one year for sufferers of motor neurone disease. (6) Does Rilutek cost patients suffering with motor neurone disease approximately $900 per month. (7) Is the Minister able to say whether the Motor Neurone Disease Association of Victoria Inc. has been told that most sufferers of motor neurone disease cannot afford the cost of Rilutek. (8) Will the Minister do everything possible to have Rilutek listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme immediately so that motor neurone disease sufferers can afford to use the drug and, as a consequence, increase their life expectancy; if not, why not. the honourable member’s question: (1) and (2) I am advised that the term ‘motor neurone disease’ refers to a group of degenerative neurological conditions of which amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (or ALS) is the most common form and arguably the most devastating of these disorders. The progression of ALS involves damage to, and death of motor neurones, leading to weakness of the muscles, eventual paralysis and death. (3) The illness is progressive, with a median survival of three to five years. (4) Rilutek is currently the only drug registered for the treatment of ALS. (5) I have received correspondence from the Motor Neurone Disease Association of Victoria Inc. containing this information. (6) Yes. (7) The Motor Neurone Disease Association of Victoria Inc. has indicated that most of its patient members are unable to afford this drug. (8) Proposed new listings of medicines on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) are assessed by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC), the Government’s independent expert advisory group on PBS listings. A medicine cannot be subsidised via the PBS unless the PBAC makes a recommendation to do so. In assessing an application for listing an item on the PBS, the PBAC is required to take into account the medical effectiveness, cost-effectiveness and safety of the medicine concerned compared with other available treatments for the condition. An application to list Rilutek on the PBS was considered by the PBAC at its meeting held on 5-6 December 2002. Details of the positive recommendations made by the PBAC are normally made available on the Department of Health and Ageing’s website within 16 working days of each meeting. Defence: National Service Medal (Question No. 1138) Ms Jann McFarlane asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 November 2002: (1) Did her predecessor and the Prime Minister both issue press releases on 26 April 2001 announcing the Anniversary of National Service 1951-1972 Medal (ANSM) and stating that Australians who elected to complete their national service obligations as members of the Citizens Military Force (CMF) under the 1965-1972 national service scheme would be eligible for the medal.

theText: The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to(2) Is she aware that the ANSM section has told people who served in the CMF that they are ineligible for the medal. (6) Will people who were notified by the ANSM section that they were ineligible for the medal prior to 30 October 2002 because there were no guidelines on CMF service, be notified that they will now receive the ANSM; if so, when. (7) Why did it take so long for the regulations to be introduced. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) Yes. (2) Yes. (3) There have been around 130,000 applications received for the medal, but to research the exact number of CMF applications would require diversion of resources now utilised to process applications. (4) None, they were all put aside pending the Regulation to include CMF service to be eligible for the ANSM. (5) Yes. (6) No. However, their applications will now be processed expeditiously. (7) The matter did not arise until about May 2002 when it was discovered, while assessing the first of the CMF applications received, that CMF service could not be included for the award of the medal under the existing regulations. Parliamentarians: Personal Computers (Question No. 1141) Mr Andren asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: (1) Do (a) government Departments and (b) the offices of Members of Parliament have a choice about the personal computers that are provided to them for their daily use? (2) Were (a) Amiga, (b) Atari, (c) Be, (d) Linux, (e) Macintosh, (f) OS/2 and Windows 98/98/NT2000 computer operating systems considered for ordinary day-to-day use by staff members of Members of Parliament and in government departments? (3) Were (a) AppleWorksOffice, (b) Corel Office/WordPerfect, (c) Lotus SmartSuite, (d) Sun StarOffice, (e) Microsoft Office/Works or other software packages considered for ordinary day-to-day use by staff members of Members of Parliament and in government departments? (4) Which operating system was shown to have the lowest total cost of ownership? (5) What security issues were considered and which operating system was shown to be the most secure? (6) Is the operating system that was selected susceptible to viruses and what costs were factored in to manage this issue? (7) How significant was user productivity in the choice of personal computers and which ease-of-use studies were used to inform this decision? (8) Are government offices able to request personal computers with alternative operating systems to those supplied? swer to the honourable member’s question: (1) (a) Commonwealth departments are individually responsible for determining the infrastructure and operating systems that they use. Procurement decisions of departments are their respon-
title: Gbrmpa And Where Is She Located To Perform These Duties

speaker: Mr Costello
theText: The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following ansibility and take account of their business requirements, which vary considerably across the Commonwealth. (b) No. The information technology arrangements in the Electorate Offices of Members of Parliament are provided by Finance through an outsourced arrangement with Computer Sciences Corporation Australia Pty Ltd (CSC). The Department leases the Electorate Office IT equipment from CSC under the terms and conditions of the contract. This equipment is selected from a limited range specified by CSC and is refreshed on a regular basis. Information technology services provided to Members of Parliament while based in Parliament House are provided by the relevant Parliamentary Departments. (2) Not all systems listed were considered as the requirements of Members of Parliament in both their Electorate Offices and Parliament House are complex and as a result the Commonwealth was required to provide a system that could demonstrate value for money whilst also meeting the needs of both these environments. The IT environment is based on a configuration that utilises a highend industry standard, providing a significant degree of compatibility and functionality. Selection of non-industry standard systems would increase costs for the Commonwealth in terms of capacity, security and maintenance. (3) Yes, however, to meet the diverse needs of the Electorate Offices, software packages must be compatible with the Parliamentary computing environment. Hence the selection of software must provide the necessary levels of security and flexibility, as provided for in high-end industry standard software. (4) A total cost of ownership analysis for each system listed in (2) was not completed as not all systems met the business needs of Electorate Offices. Factors such as compatibility, ease of use, security, and technical support must also be considered. In addition, there is a requirement on the Commonwealth to observe government procurement policies when sourcing IT products. (5) When selecting an operating system, the Commonwealth is required to abide by the security standards set out in the Commonwealth Protective Security Manual produced by the Attorney General’s Department, and all other relevant legislation, including the Australian Communications-Electronic Security Instruction 33 (ACSI 33). (6) No computer system is free from virus attack. The Commonwealth upholds the policies as defined by the Commonwealth Protective Security Manual in the management of its IT environment. The Department evaluates all software to assess its vulnerability to attack prior to installation. Risk mitigation strategies are developed to minimise virus attacks and these costs are factored into overall system support and are difficult to separate. (7) When assessing the software and hardware requirements of Electorate Offices, consideration is given to both the business needs of Electorate Offices and its users. In recognising the importance of user productivity, the department provides training appropriate to the Electorate Office IT environment. (8) See (1) (a) above. Aviation: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport (Question No. 1146) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: Further to the reply to question No. 494 (Hansard, 16 September 2002, page 6308), how soon after 31 December 2003 will the figures relating to forecast air-traffic movements to and from Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport be made public. Under the Airports Act 1996 (the Act) the Sydney Airports Corporation Limited (SACL) is required to submit a draft Master Plan (MP) for Sydney Airport to the Minister by 31 December 2003. The Act requires SACL to make the preliminary draft Master Plan available for public comment 90 days prior to submission to the Minister.
title: Gbrmpa And Where Is She Located To Perform These Duties

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1149) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: (1) Further to the reply to part (2) of question No. 861 (Hansard, 11 November 2002, page 8697), is the nature of the advice being sought by the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) on Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston related to establishing his capacity to stand trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts; if not, why not. (2) When was that advice first sought and from whom. (3) What caused the DPP to seek that advice. (4) What specific questions were asked by the DPP of the person or persons to whom that advice was sought. (5) Has Dr Colston agreed to co-operate fully with the present review by the DPP; if not, why not. (6) Has the DPP asked Dr Colston whether he will voluntarily submit himself for fresh medical assessment; if so, what was the date of this request and was it made in writing or oral; if not, why not. (7) Has Dr Colston agreed to submit himself for fresh medical assessment; if not, why not. (8) Has Dr Colston refused to submit himself for fresh medical assessment; if so, why. (9) Has Dr Colston, his lawyers, treating doctors or anyone else, attempted to place any conditions on the DPP in relation to Dr Colston’s preparedness, or otherwise, to be medically assessed afresh by competent medical specialists who have never previously examined him; if so, what are those conditions. (10) Have any medical appointments been arranged for Dr Colston to be examined by competent medical specialists who have never previously examined him; if so, what are the dates on which these new medical appointments are to take place; if not, why not. (11) Has any person from the office of the DPP conducted a face-to-face interview with Dr Colston since 1 July 1999; if so, on what dates and what were the outcomes of the interviews. (12) Why is the review of Dr Colston’s case by the DPP taking so long to finalise. (13) When does the DPP expect to make a decision on whether or not Dr Colston is fit enough to stand trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts. (14) Will the review of Dr Colston’s case by the DPP since July 2002 be concluded before January 2003; if not, why not. (1) Yes. (2) In July 2002. From an independent medical specialist. (3) The DPP considered that given the passage of time a further review should be carried out. (4) The DPP requested an assessment of Dr Colston’s fitness to stand trial. (5) The DPP requested that Dr Colston attend to be examined which he has done. The medical assessment is not completed and the DPP has requested Dr Colston’s further co-operation. (6) In July 2002 the DPP requested in writing that Dr Colston attend for an independent examination. (7) See (5). (8) See (5). (9) Dr Colston’s solicitors raised a number of matters in relation to the DPP’s request, including as to arrangements for Dr Colston’s attendance, which the DPP considered and responded to. (10) Dr Colston was examined on 10 October 2002 and on advice the DPP has requested that he attend for a further examination. (11) No. (12) See (10). (13) On receiving the independent specialist’s assessment.
title: Gbrmpa And Where Is She Located To Perform These Duties

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(14) The DPP does not expect the review to be completed before January 2003 as it is not expected that the specialist’s assessment will be completed by that date. Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1150) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: (1) Did the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP), in providing evidence to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on 20 November 2002 concerning the progress of the DPP’s third review of the case of Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston’s capacity to stand trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding the Commonwealth through travel rorts, state, inter alia, that the reason the matter was discontinued around April 2001 was the considered opinion of a number of medical experts that Dr Colston was not fit to stand trial, not that Dr Colston was about to die. (2) Did the DPP further state that there were some pessimistic prognostications but the fundamental basis for the advice and the opinions which caused the decision to be made around April 2001 was Dr Colston’s fitness to stand trial, not his pessimistic outlook. (3) What was the nature of the medical or other evidence that came to light around April 2001 that ston only had months to live. (4) What changed the DPP’s mind around April 2001 that Dr Colston was not about to die. (5) What specific prognoses in relation to Dr Colston’s fitness to stand trial led the DPP to discontinue proceedings against Dr Colston. (6) What is the relationship between the prognoses of the hitherto terminal illness of Dr Colston and his fitness to stand trial. (1) The DPP discontinued the prosecution of Dr Colston on 5 July 1999 and stated that it was the assessment of all the specialists that Dr Colston had a terminal illness and his condition was such that he was unfit to stand trial and there was no prospect that he would be fit to stand trial in the future. The DPP’s review of this matter in 2001 confirmed this was the case. (2) This statement related to the decision to discontinue in July 1999 and its subsequent review in 2001. (3) See (1). (4) See (1). (5) The assessment that Dr Colston was unfit to stand trial and there was no prospect that he would be fit to stand trial in the future. (6) See (1) and (5). Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1151) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: (1) Further to his reply to question No. 862 (Hansard, 24 September 2002, page 7159), did the Director of Public Prosecutions, in providing evidence to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on 20 November 2002 concerning the taxpayer-funded travel since July 1999 of former Senator Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston, state, inter alia, that one must draw the distinction between someone sitting in a plane seat and travelling and someone being able to sit in a court from 10 o’clock in the morning when the court starts, with a break in the middle of the day, and finishing at four o’clock and being able to concentrate on the evidence, give instructions to the instructing solicitor and counsel and being able to concentrate through that period of time for the estimated duration of the trial. (2) In light of Dr Colston’s proven capacity to (a) undertake very numerous hours of taxpayer-funded motor vehicle and aircraft travel, (b) run his company Janfern Pty Ltd and (c) concentrate on legally certifying his company returns to the Australian Securities and Investments Commission, will the DPP, in assessing Dr Colston’s fitness to stand trial on twenty-eight charges of defrauding

speaker: Mr Williams
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:the Commonwealth through travel rorts, consider allowing such a trial to proceed which would only require Dr Colston to attend Court for short periods of time; if not, why not. (1) Yes. (2) Sitting hours are a matter for the court conducting a trial, not the DPP. Social Welfare: Age Pensions (Question No. 1152) Mr Murphy asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: Further to the reply to question No. 920 (Hansard, 14 October 2002, page 7551), will the Howard Government review the assets test as it impacts on pensioners who own their own home and also own only one modest investment property; if so, when; if not, why not. lowing answer to the honourable member’s question: There are no plans at present to review the assets test as it impacts on pensioners who own their own home and also own investment property. A pensioner’s own home is exempt from the assets test. The net asset value of an investment property is assessed as an asset, consistent with other types of investment, that is the market value of the property, net of any loan secured against the property. The assets test is designed so that people with substantial assets, apart from their home, use the assets (either directly or to produce income) to meet their day-to-day living expenses before calling on the social security system for support. Centrelink provides a free and independent Financial Information Service (FIS) to assist pensioners in better understanding social security payments and provisions and the broader investment market. Pensioners can make an appointment by telephoning Centrelink on 13 23 00. Environment: Dolphins (Question No. 1154) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: (1) What is the Government’s stance on the issue of dolphins being harvested for food. (2) What action has the Government taken to protect dolphins in Australian waters from fishing. (3) What action has the Government taken internationally to protect dolphins from fishing. (4) What representations has Australia made to (a) Japan and (b) the International Whaling Commission regarding fishing for dolphins in Japanese national waters. (1) The Government is strongly opposed to the harvesting of dolphins for food, and does not condone it in any circumstances. (2) The Government has established the highest level of protection for all cetacean species (whales, dolphins and porpoises). The Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act) established the Australian Whale Sanctuary in the Australian exclusive economic zone. The EPBC Act protects all cetaceans occurring in the Australian Whale Sanctuary from threatening processes that include some fishing practices. The EPBC Act makes it an offence to kill, injure, take, trade, keep, move or interfere with a cetacean within the Australian Whale Sanctuary. Under the EPBC Act, all Commonwealth fisheries and State fisheries with an export component are required to employ methods to avoid killing or injuring protected species such as dolphins during fishing operations. The Government requires all major Commonwealth fisheries to implement bycatch action plans to address this issue. The plans will require fishers to take all reasonable steps to ensure that cetaceans are not killed or injured as a result of fishing and that fishing activities do not, or are not likely to, adversely affect their survival or recovery.

speaker: Dr Kemp
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Under the Natural Heritage Trust, the Government has provided over $140 000 over the past three years to develop further methods of preventing the incidental capture of marine mammals. The results of this research, which is investigating the effectiveness of acoustic ‘pingers’ in warning marine mammals (particularly threatened dolphin species and dugongs) of the presence of potentially hazardous nets, should inform future efforts to protect dolphins in Australian waters. (3) Internationally, Australia leads the campaign for better protection of whales and dolphins in our region. Australia recently initiated discussions with our South Pacific neighbours to develop a South Pacific Arrangement on Marine Mammals under the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (the Bonn Convention). The first meeting to develop the Arrangement will be convened by the South Pacific Regional Environment Programme in Apia, Samoa from 3-5 March 2003. The Arrangement will have as its aim the protection and conservation of marine mammals such as dolphins, and their habitats in the region, through actions nominated by South Pacific nations themselves. Furthermore, Australia was instrumental in banning driftnet fishing, which posed the single greatest threat to dolphins (resulting in the hundreds of thousands of deaths annually). (4) (a) Japan In December 2002, I asked Australian delegates who were meeting with Japanese officials to raise our concerns about the treatment of whales and dolphins. While the Japan Fisheries Agency, which has direct responsibility for cetacean matters in Japan, did not attend the meetings, key environment and foreign affairs officials were left in no doubt about Australia’s commitment to the full protection of whales and dolphins. (b) International Whaling Commission (IWC) The Government believes that the IWC, as the body responsible for cetaceans, is the appropriate forum to discuss the welfare of dolphins internationally. We have called on all members to honour Resolution 1991-5 (calling for information on small cetacean stocks subjected to significant directed and incidental takes), and Resolution 2001-13 (urging Contracting Governments to provide such information to the Scientific Committee and to respond to recommendations for action to conserve small cetaceans). Japan has not complied with these requests, on the basis that in its view, the IWC has no competency over small cetaceans. The world’s largest direct kill of any cetacean (whale, dolphin or porpoise) is the annual harpooning of up to 18,000 Dall’s porpoises off Japan. Australia has consistently voiced our opposition to this hunt. In 2001, at the IWC’s 53rd annual meeting, Australia strongly supported a resolution which urged the Government of Japan to halt the directed takes of Dall’s porpoises (pending a full assessment by the Scientific Committee). At the 54th meeting in May 2002, Australia joined other IWC members in criticising Japan for continuing the mass slaughter of Dall’s porpoises in defiance of the IWC resolutions, and for refusing to submit data on the hunt to the Scientific Committee. United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (Question No. 1156) Mrs Crosio asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: (1) Further to the Minister’s letter to me regarding the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women on 25 November 2002, otherwise known as White Ribbon Day, has the Government reconsidered its opposition to the signing of the Optional Protocol to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. (2) Have 75 states signed, and 47 states ratified, the Optional Protocol; if so, what are the reasons behind the Government’s decision to not sign the Optional Protocol, considering the role Australia has played historically in fighting for the improvement of women’s rights globally. (3) Was Australia a member on the UN Commission on the Status of Women (CSW) from 1983 until 1990 and again from 1993 until 1996; if so, why has Australia not been a member of the CSW since 1996. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women is as follows: (1) The Government has not reconsidered this decision. (2) These figures are correct as at 18 October 2002, as stated on the UN website. Between March and August 2000, the Government undertook a review of Australia’s interaction with the UN treaty committee system. On 29 August 2000, the Government announced it would not sign the Optional Protocol to CEDAW while its concerns with the treaty committee system remained. (3) Australia was a member of CSW between 1983 and 1990 and from 1993 until 1996. The Government reviews its membership of UN committees on a regular basis. Seeking membership of a UN committee requires a ‘whole of government’ resource commitment and must be balanced with competing priorities. Australia will shortly take up membership of the Commission on Human Rights and this will be a major focus for Australia’s engagement with the UN committee system. Job Placement Education and Training Program (Question No. 1157) Mr Fitzgibbon asked the Minister for Children and Youth Services, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: (1) Has the Newcastle based Centacare Job Placement Education and Training (JPET) program been defunded following a recent tender process. (2) Was a proposal for a Centacare JPET program based in Maitland also unsuccessful despite the fact the area has high unemployment. (3) Is the process of evaluation of all tenders throughout Australia for the JPET program to be reviewed; if so, (a) how will tenders be assessed during the process and (b) will tenders be judged on evidence of past achievements or what the agencies say they would do. (4) Has the number of placements decreased in the recent tender process; if so, by how many. (1) and (2) Negotiations are still being undertaken in relation to the provision of JPET services. Until the process has been completed we are not in a position to provide further details as to the successful or unsuccessful applicants. (3) (a) (b) As the result of a complaint, a review of the process was announced on Friday 8th November and will be completed by 31 January 2003. The review is not about reassessing all the applications but investigating the specific complaints made about the business allocation process. (4) A similar number of young people will continue to be serviced by JPET services. Veterans: Gold Card (Question No. 1158) Ms Hoare asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: (1) Does the Government plan to merge her Department with Centrelink. (2) Is she aware of the unique status of veterans. (3) What is the future of the Gold Card. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) No. There are no plans to merge the Department of Veterans’ Affairs with Centrelink. (2) Yes. I, with the Government remain committed to those who have served and currently serve in the defence of Australia. The unique status of veterans is recognised and preserved by the work of the Repatriation Commission, which, through the Department of Veterans’ Affairs, serves members of Australia’s veterans and defence force communities, their war widows/widowers and dependants through programs of care, compensation, commemoration and defence support services. (3) The Government is committed to the future of the Gold Card and has no plans to reduce its status in the Australian community. The Gold Card is issued to Australian veterans, war widows/widowers and dependants, who under the Veterans’ Entitlements Act 1986 are entitled to the full range of health care services funded by the Department of Veterans’ Affairs.
title: Gbrmpa And Where Is She Located To Perform These Duties

speaker: Mr Anthony
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Veterans: Gold Card (Question No. 1159) Ms Hoare asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: (1) How many Gold Card holders are there in Australia. (2) How many services have been provided to veterans in 2002. (3) What percentage of services to Gold Card holders were bulk billed in 2002. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) 282,017 (as at 30 September 2002). (2) The total number of services for all treatment types paid by the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) on behalf of the Department of Veterans’ Affairs (DVA) for the 2001-02 financial year was 17,297,046. This is comprised of the following: Gold Card treatment (veterans) 10,841,804 Gold Card treatment (war widow/widowers) 6,005,917 White Card treatment (veterans) 449,325 The figures above represent services by all providers (general practitioners, specialists, private hospitals and allied health providers) but do not include public hospitals. (3) The term bulk billing is not normally used in describing a feature of the DVA/HIC system of payment for medical and allied health providers. When a veteran or a dependant Gold Cardholder receives treatment, the client’s details are recorded on a claim form which is forwarded to HIC, which pays the provider, on behalf of DVA. The Department’s registered Local Medical Officers receive 100% of the Medical Benefits Schedule fee for medical services. General practitioners who are not registered to DVA receive 85% of the Medical Benefits Schedule fee, plus 60 cents. Similarly, when the holder of a White Card receives treatment for an accepted war/service caused condition, the provider is paid by HIC for that treatment on behalf of DVA. This is the method by which the Department pays for the vast majority of services provided to veterans by medical and allied health providers and would represent over 99% of payments. Immigration: Woomera Detainees (Question No. 1160) Dr Lawrence asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 2 December 2002: (1) What action is being taken regarding allegations of abuse by three former Woomera security guards accused of assaulting and bashing thirteen year old Afghani, Zihar Sayed. (2) Have the three men in question been found since failing to appear in court on 5 September 2002. (3) Is he able to say whether the (a) Australian Federal Police or (b) Director of Public Prosecutions is responsible for locating the men. (4) Is he also able to say whether the men are still employees of Australian Correctional Management. (5) What measures has the Government put in place to ensure children in detention are protected from physical and emotional abuse. (1) I can confirm the charges against two of the officers were dropped at the proceedings on Monday 25 November 2002. However the charges against a third officer remain. A warrant for his arrest was issued by the Magistrate on 25 November 2002. (2) Although charges were laid by the AFP, summonses were not served on the three officers. As the three men had not been served with the summons, they were not required to attend the hearing in September 2002. (3) The AFP is responsible. (4) One of the officers for whom charges were dropped remains employed with ACM. (currently not working at an Immigration Detention Facility).
title: Gbrmpa And Where Is She Located To Perform These Duties

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(5) The Department takes it duty of care to all detainees, including child detainees seriously. The Immigration Detention Standards specify that “9.2.1 Unaccompanied minors are detained under conditions which protect them from harmful influences and which take account of the needs of their particular age and gender 9.3.1 The special needs of babies and young children are met 9.4.1 Social and educational programs appropriate to the child’s age and abilities are available to all children in detention 9.4.2 Detainees are responsible for the safety and care of their child(ren) living in detention 9.4.3 Where necessary, help and guidance in parenting skills is provided by appropriately qualified personnel 9.5.2 Arrangements are made, wherever practicable, for children to be born in a hospital outside the detention facility. If a child is born in a detention facility this is not recorded on their birth certificate 9.5.3 Where a nursing infant is with its mother in detention, provision is made for the child to be cared for by the detainee.” While in the detention environment, parents retain the responsibility and primary care role for their children. They are supported in this regard by the program and welfare services provided by the Detention Services Provider which are available to parents. Incorporated into this support is the development of a case management plan for each child. Both Departmental and Detention Service Provider staff monitor children in the detention environment and report to the relevant Child Welfare Authorities any incidents or situations that may place a child at risk. In addition, both the Department and the Detention Services Provider are required to comply with any State/Territory Child Welfare laws. The Department works cooperatively with welfare authorities where any investigation is to be undertaken. DIMIA signed an MOU with the South Australian Department of Human Services on 6 December 2001. The Department is currently negotiating MOUs on child welfare matters with NSW, SA, WA and Vic. The Northern Territory has also expressed an interest in having an MOU. Defence: Visiting Warships (Question No. 1162) Mr Kerr asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 December 2002: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether a visit of a US nuclear powered warship proposed for the port of Hobart in or around late December 2002 has been postponed or cancelled. (2) Has there been any recent review of security issues relating to the visit of US warships to Australian ports since the (a) attacks in the USA on 11 September 2001 and (b) targeting and bombing of Australians in Bali on 12 October 2002. (3) Have those events or other events of a similar nature affected the assessment of risk associated with such visits; if so, what is the new assessment of risk. (4) Given Australians’ heightened security concerns since those events, if visits proceed will the docking arrangements remain the same as those applying in the past; if not, what will be the new arrangements. (5) Will the exclusion area around any visiting vessel be the same as in the past; if not, what exclusion area will be established. (6) Will the arrangements for monitoring any exclusion area remain the same as in the past; if not, without disclosure of the detail of operational security matters, what different arrangements will be made. This question falls within the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Justice and Customs. theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) Further to questions Nos. 1161 to 1163 asked by the member for Denison, will the arrangements for shore leave for the crews visiting Hobart remain the same as for recent past visits; if not, without disclosure of any detail relating to operational security issues, how will the arrangements change. (2) Will additional measures be taken that will have an impact on the ordinary activities of residents and visitors to Hobart during any future visit. (3) If so, what will those measures entail and what activities will they affect. (4) Has there been any recent assessment of the availability of appropriate infrastructure and resources to deal with an actual or threatened major terrorism incident directed towards such vessels, or the crew of such vessels on shore leave while the vessels are visiting Hobart; if so, what were the conclusions of the assessment; if not, will an assessment be undertaken. This question falls within the portfolio responsibilities of the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Justice and Customs. Colston, Former Senator: Criminal Proceedings (Question No. 1169) Mr Murphy asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 3 December 2002: Further to his reply to parts (3) and (4) of question No. 678 (Hansard, 11 November 2002, page 8680), did the medical report of the state of health of the former Senator Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston, dated 9 February 2001, indicate that Dr Colston was terminally ill; if so, (a) was the medical condition from which Dr Colston suffers and reported on in the report the same medical condition that the independent expert eminent medical specialists reported on in their reports of 14 and 19 May 1999 and (b) did the 9 February 2001 report indicate (i) any improvement in the state of health of Dr Colston; if so, to what extent; if not, (c) was the medical condition reported on in the 9 February 2001 report another medical condition which developed since May 1999 and (d) is this medical condition a terminal illness. Yes. (a) Yes. (b) (i) No. (c) No. (d) See (c). Car Industry: Federal Approach (Question No. 1172) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 3 December 2002: (1) Is he able to say whether the Minister for Finance and Administration represented the Government at the opening of Holdens V6 engine plant in Port Melbourne on 30 October 2002. (2) Is he able to say whether the Minister for Finance and Administration echoed the sentiment of the Victorian Premier in congratulating the construction workers for building the plant on time and on budget. (3) Is he also able to say whether the Minister for Finance and Administration told the 800 people gathered at the opening of the new plant that this kind of cooperative relationship between workers and management would send a message to car headquarters in Detroit and Tokyo. (4) Does he agree with this approach and will he rule out introducing divisive industrial caveats into federal assistance for the vehicle building industry where cooperation, not coercion, has resulted in the highest ever levels of exports, employment and productivity. The Minister for Trade did not attend the event cited in the question and is therefore unable to provide an answer to the points raised in the question. Total 16579 5538 22117 * Due to systems issues, the citizenship of some applicants is not recorded Regional Flood Mitigation Program (Question No. 1176) Mrs Crosio asked the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 3 December 2002: (1) What is the definition of an outer metropolitan area as used in the Government’s Regional Flood Mitigation Programme (RFMP) to assist in providing funds for flood mitigation works in rural, regional and outer metropolitan areas. (2) What levels of funding have been received under the RFMP by (a) Hawkesbury City Council, (b) Penrith City Council, (c) Blue Mountains City Council, (d) Camden City Council, (e) Wollondilly Shire Council and (f) Wingecarribee Shire Council in (i) 1999-2000, (ii) 2000-2001, (iii) 20012002 and (iv) 2002-2003. (3) Has funding from other programs been received by these councils for flood mitigation works for (a) 1999-2000, (b) 2000-2001, (c) 2001-2002 and (d) 2002-2003. (4) Has Parramatta City Council received funding under (a) the RFMP and (b) any other program for flood mitigation works. (1) There is no set definition of an outer metropolitan area under the Regional Flood Mitigation Programme (RFMP). As many Councils have significant demographic variations within their boundaries, the Commonwealth Government has advised States and Territories that it is a matter for their assessment processes to determine outer metropolitan boundaries as part of their project assessments and application processes. (2) The RFMP programme guidelines provide for the relevant State Minister to advise the priority projects for which it seeks matching funding. I am advised that RFMP funding has been allocated by the Federal Government to the following councils as indicated: Council 1999-2000 2000-2001 2001-2002 2002-2003 Hawkesbury City Council $0 $0 $0 $0 Penrith City Council $0 $0 $0 $0 Blue Mountains City Council $0 $0 $0 $0 Camden City Council $0 $0 $0 $350,000*
title: Gbrmpa And Where Is She Located To Perform These Duties

speaker: Mr Tuckey
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Council 1999-2000 2000-2001 2001-2002 2002-2003 Wollondilly Shire Council $0 $63,000 $45,000 $25,000 Wingecarribee Shire Council $0 $0 $0 $0 *Included in a NSW statewide voluntary purchase scheme allocation of $350,000. Final allocation to Camden City Council alone has yet to be finalised by the State Government. (3) The RFMP is the only dedicated Commonwealth flood mitigation programme. The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry– Australia (AFFA) has advised my Department that none of these councils have received funding for flood mitigation works under the Natural Heritage Trust since 1999-2000. I am advised that there are no other Commonwealth Government programmes that have provided funding for flood mitigation works since that time. (4) (a) I am advised that Parramatta City Council has received RFMP funding as follows: 1999-2000 2000-2001 2001-2002 2002-2003 Parramatta City Council $0 $0 $120,000 $950,000* * Included in a NSW statewide voluntary purchase scheme allocation of $950,000. Final allocation to Parramatta City Council alone has yet to be finalised by the State Government. (b) The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry– Australia (AFFA) has advised my Department that Parramatta City Council has not received funding for flood mitigation works under the Natural Heritage Trust since 1999-2000. I am advised that there are no other Commonwealth Government programmes that have provided funding for flood mitigation works since that time. Industry, Tourism and Resources: Funding (Question No. 1189) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 4 December 2002: (1) Which organisations received Backing Australia’s Ability initiatives funding in (a) 2001-2002 and (b) 2002-2003 under the categories of: (i) Premium R&D Tax Concessions, (ii) Rebate for small companies, (iii) R&D Start, (iv) Major Research Facilities Program, (v) Pre-Seed Fund, (vi) Innovation Access Program, (vii) Commercialising Emerging Technologies Program, (viii) Centres of Excellence for Biotechnology, Information and Communications Technology, (ix) Biotechnology Innovation Fund, (x) New Industries Development Program, (xi) Australian Research Council Competitive grants, (xii) Research Infrastructure Block Grants, (xiii) University Infrastructure, (xiv) Additional 2000 University Places, (xv) Online Curriculum Content and, (xvi) National Innovation Awareness (2) What is the physical location of each funded organisation. (3) At what physical location will or did the research take place. (4) Which organisations are attached to a university or research organisation. Mr Ian Macfarlane-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: A number of initiatives identified are the responsibility of the Education, Science and Training (iv, x-xv) and Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (viii pt2) portfolios. Requests for information on funding provided under those initiatives should be referred to the responsible Ministers. In relation to those programs administered by my department, the relevant information is set out below. It should be noted that the information provided relates to all funding decisions made in 2001-2002 and 2002-2003 for new grants and does not include progress payments on existing grants. In addition in a number of cases, (R&D Start, COMET, Innovation Access and Biotechnology Innovation Fund) BAA extended and increased funding provided for existing programs. In the circumstances some grantees have received funding through BAA while others drew on existing program funds. Premium R&D Tax Concession & Rebate for Small Companies The confidentiality restrictions contained in Section 47 of the IR&D Act preclude me from providing the information requested in relation to these programs.
