Biotechnology Centres of Excellence Year Funding Physical Location of Physical Location of Organisation Awarded Organisation Activity Peter Wills Bioinformatics Centre, Gar2001/02 Garvan Institute, Sydney Garvan Institute, Sydney van Institute National Stem Cell Centre 2001/02 Monash University, same Melbourne (central node) with likely additional participating organisations in other states The Garvan Institute is a medical research institute affiliated with the University of New South Wales and St Vincent’s Hospital, Sydney. The National Stem Cell Centre was announced by the Prime Minister as the successful applicant for the Biotechnology Centre of Excellence on 30 May 2002. The Deed of Agreement between the Commonwealth and the Centre has not yet been finalised, and no Commonwealth funding has been provided at this stage. The Centre’s central node is planned to be located at Monash University, Melbourne. Likely additional participating organisations in Victoria, Queensland, New South Wales, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory will act as nodes of the Centre. The details of the participating organisations will be finalised in the Centre’s Business Plan as part of negotiations on the Deed of Agreement. The National Stem Cell Centre will itself be a research organisation. Immigration: Visitor Visas (Question No. 1192) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 2002: (1) How many visas have been issued to visitors from Saudi Arabia each year over the last 10 years. (2) How many of those visas have been issued to individuals who expressed an intention to teach religious studies in Australia. (3) Have any visas been denied to such individuals; if so, on what grounds. (4) Were any of the applicants for visas known to be supporters or teachers of extreme Wahabi-ist, alQaeda, or JI doctrines; if not, were any background checks done to establish this. (5) Is he able to say for how many Muslim (a) institutions and (b) religious schools in Australia the Saudi Government provides funding. (6) Is he able to say what conditions are attached to the funding; if so do any of the conditions relate to the content of the teaching. (7) Is he aware of any Australian Islamic Schools that receive Saudi funding and that mandate the teaching of the radical Wahabi-ist, al-Qaeda, or JI, doctrines rather than other moderate forms of Islam. (8) Is he aware of any teachers who have received visas and who teach radical Wahabi-ist, al-Qaeda doctrine in Australia. (1) Detailed records of persons granted Visitor visas by citizenship prior to 1996-97 are not readily available. Since 1996-97 to 30 September 2002, 8,237 persons from Saudi Arabia have been granted Visitor visas. The breakdown by program year is as follows: 1996-97 907 1997-98 837 1998-99 996 1999-00 1040 2000-01 1730 2001-02 1746 2002-03 (YTD) 981 (2) Since 1996-97, religious worker visas (subclass 428) have been granted to two persons from Saudi Arabia. The religious worker visa is granted to applicants who are sponsored by a religious organisation in Australia that directly serves the religious objectives of the organisation. The role undertaken by such visa holders may involve teaching or more of a pastoral care role. (3) Data on this is not readily available. (4) Persons who apply for visas to enter Australia as religious workers are required to provide information on their backgrounds and skills relating to the approved sponsorship. This information is checked and confirmed prior to a visa being granted. All applicants are required to meet public interest criteria, which includes being assessed by the competent Australian authorities as not being a risk to Australian national security.
title: Hksar Of The Prc 589 170 759

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:On the basis of information provided and background checks conducted, my Department is not aware of any of these applicants being known to be supporters or teachers of extreme Wahabi-ist, al-Qaeda, or JI doctrines. (5) Information on this matter is not generally held by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA). (6) Information on this matter is not generally held by DIMIA. (7) Information on this matter is not generally held by DIMIA. (8) No. Veterans: Entitlements (Question No. 1193) Mr Bevis asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 2002: How many former employees of Qantas Empire Airlines engaged in forward operations in World War II have had their service accepted as qualifying service for service pensions or other veterans’ benefits. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: Staff employed by Qantas who were appointed to the Royal Australian Air Force Reserve during World War II have eligibility for disability compensation pension coverage under the Veterans’ Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA). Those who served overseas or incurred danger from the hostile forces of the enemy between 3 September 1939 and 15 August 1945 have qualifying service and would be eligible to apply for the service pension and other benefits. The number of veterans involved is not readily available, as my department’s database does not identify Qantas employees as a specific group. Additionally, some Qantas former staff may have enlisted for full-time service in the Australian Defence Forces during World War II. They likewise enjoy normal veteran entitlements but again, my department’s database does not identify former Qantas employees as a specific group. Immigration: Transit Visas (Question No. 1198) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 5 December 2002: (1) Are seafarers applying for, and are eligible to be issued, a transit visa to enter Australia to join their ship at an Australian port; if so, how many transit visas have been granted for this purpose in each of the past 10 years. (2) When were transit visas first introduced and under what legislation or regulations. (3) Were seafarers immediately eligible for this visa for ship crew changeovers. (4) What visa did seafarers access for ship crew changeovers before transit visas were introduced. (5) What was the stated purpose of transit visas. (6) Who is eligible to apply or be issued with a transit visa and what is the cost of obtaining a transit visa. (7) Which other visa categories are available with no cost to lodge an application. (8) What arrangements does his Department have in place for seafarers to apply for transit visas. (9) Are transit visas in an electronic form; if so, how does Customs identify them at the airport for clearance purposes. (10) Are foreign crew leaving Australia by air required to apply for visas upon departure; if so, under what visa category. (11) Does his department process these applications and what criteria are applied to assess applications. (12) What checks, if any, does his Department carry out before issuing these transit visas and do they include a check against his Department’s Movement Alert List; if not, why not and are there any other visas for which these checks are not required. (13) How do Customs officers at the airport determine that the transit visas are for seafarers and what additional documentation, if any, are seafarers required to prove that they are joining a ship. (14) Do the transit visas for this purpose have any conditions and what, if any, checks are carried out by either Customs or his Department to determine that the conditions of the transit visa have been met. (15) Do seafarers require a passport to apply for a transit visa. (16) What measures, if any, does his Department, or any other Department or agency, have in place to ensure compliance with the transit visa requirements that the seafarer join their ship within 72 hours, and how many times has this requirement been breached in each of the past ten years. (17) What is the penalty for breaching the visa requirement and are visas cancelled as a result; if not, why not and which other visas are exempt from cancellation for breaching the conditions. (18) What visa category is the seafarer on when they board their ship and what is the process for receiving that visa. (19) If a seafarer leaves their ship in an Australian port, what visa are they on and how long are they eligible to be on that visa while away from their ship. (1) Yes. Seafarers may apply for a transit visa to join their ship, and providing they meet the criteria for the grant of a transit visa as set out in the Migration Regulations, will be eligible. The table below shows the total number of transit visas granted since 1994/95 (earlier data is not available). The figures include transit visas granted to persons wishing to transit Australia to another country as well as seafarers joining their ship. I do not have a breakdown of the data. 2002/03 up 1994/95 1995/96 1996/97 1997/98 1998/99 1999/00 2000/01 2001/02 to 31/11/02 Total grants 17757 20976 20281 19478 23111 25656 30975 34408 17872 (2) Transit visas were prescribed by legislation in the Migration Regulations 1989, although the transit visa regime existed in one form or another prior to these Regulations coming into effect. (3) Prior to the commencement of the Migration Regulations 1989, seafarers were able to access transit visas for ship crew changeovers. Their eligibility for the visa would be assessed against the criteria or policy that existed at the time. (4) A transit visa regime has existed in one form or another since Australia introduced migration controls. Prior to the existence of the current transit visa, seafarers accessed transhipment visas or endorsements for ship crew changeovers. (5) Transit visas are temporary visas permitting the holder to travel to and enter Australia on 1 or more occasions and to remain in Australia no longer than 72 hours on each occasion. The visa is granted to persons intending to enter Australia : (a) to pass through Australia in transit to another country; or (b) to pass through Australia in order to join a non-military ship as a member of its crew. (6) All non-citizens are eligible to apply for transit visas. A transit visa will be granted if all the criteria set out in the Migration Regulations are met. There is no cost involved in lodging an application for a transit visa. (7) Several other visa categories do not attract a visa application charge. These include, but are not limited to, certain ETAs, certain student visas, certain bridging visas, border visas, emergency visas, confirmatory visas and offshore humanitarian program visas. (8) Seafarers requiring a transit visa may apply at the nearest Australian High Commission or Embassy. (9) Transit visas are electronically recorded. The evidence of the visa is provided as a paper label affixed to their passport. They can be identified on arrival at an airport by the visa label. (10) No. Foreign crew signing off their vessel for repatriation by air will have a “sign-off” stamp placed in their passport by the Customs clearance officer as they leave their ship. This identifies them as departing crew at the airport on departure. They continue to hold their Special Purpose Visa for the period specified in the maintenance letter signed by the master of the vessel (to a maximum of 30 days). (11) Not applicable, see answer to 10 above.
title: Acyte Biotech Pty Ltd 2001 02 Sydney Nsw Sydney Nsw

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(12) All applicants for transit visas are checked against DIMIA’s Movements Alert List, and nationals of selected countries are further checked for security purposes. In addition, checks are made that the applicant is a genuine seaman seeking to join a ship in Australia as a member of crew. (13) When applying for a transit visa and on arrival in Australia by air, it is a legislative requirement that seafarers present a valid passport or seafarer’s identity document. Further, it is a policy requirement that on application and on arrival at an airport the seafarer also present the following details as provided by the shipping agent: the names of the persons joining the vessel as crew; the names of the persons they are replacing; the name of the vessel; the date of arrival in Australia of the persons to be visaed; the port and date they are expected to join the vessel; and if they are not the vessel’s owner, a copy of the request for crew from the vessel’s agent in Australia which contains the details of the crew members applying for visas. On arrival in Australia, seafarers must also present their transit visa as evidenced in their travel document, and complete an incoming passenger card. (14) The following conditions apply to all transit visas: The holder must enter on or before the date specified by the Minister for the purpose and Conditions 8101 (the holder must not engage in work in Australia) and 8201 (while in Australia the holder must not engage, for more than 3 months, in any studies or training). Any one or more of conditions 8501, 8514 and 8516 may also be imposed. Condition 8501 requires that the holder must maintain adequate arrangements for health insurance while the holder is in Australia. Condition 8514 states that during the visa period of the visa, there must be no material change in the circumstances on the basis of which it was granted. Condition 8516 states that the holder must continue to be a person who would satisfy the primary or secondary criteria, as the case requires, for the grant of the visa. (15) No. Under current legislation transit visas can be evidenced in Seafarer’s Identity Documents when the holder is travelling to Australia to join their vessel. (16) There are no specific measures to ensure seafarers join their ship within the validity of their transit visa. As with all visa holders, if seafarers overstay the validity of their visa they become unlawful non-citizens liable for detention and removal. My Department does not maintain separate statistics on how many seafarers fall into this category. (17) If any of the visa conditions are breached, the visa may be liable for cancellation. (18) Seafarers may arrive in Australia by air as holders of transit visas. They then have 72 hours to sign-on to their vessel, at which time they are taken to hold a Special Purpose Visa by operation of law. Australian Customs Service (ACS) Officers attend vessels where such a crew change occurs to verify the seafarer’s identity and ensure his or her details appear on the crew manifest. (19) If a seafarer leaves their ship in an Australian port without the permission of the master of the vessel they are considered to be a deserter and their Special Purpose Visa ceases at midnight of the day on which they desert. If a seafarer permanently leaves their ship in an Australian port with the permission of the master they continue to hold their Special Purpose Visa for the period specified in the maintenance letter signed by the master (to a maximum of 30 days). If such a seafarer wishes to remain longer in Australia for tourism or other purposes, they are required to apply for the appropriate visa. Environment: Australian Greenhouse Office (Question No. 1202) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 5 December 2002: (1) Further to his reply to part (1) of question No. 931 (Hansard, 16 October 2002, page 7904) regarding the cost of implementing the Kyoto Protocol, (a) what are the (i) highest and (ii) lowest estimates of the implementation costs, (b) how were the estimates derived and (c) what are the Government’s assumptions about the nature of international climate change action post 2012. (2) Further to his reply to part (2) of question No. 931 regarding a strategy intended to ensure cuts to Australia’s greenhouse emissions, (a) which State governments, local governments, business groups and community groups have the Government worked with in recent months to develop this strategy and (b) has the development of the strategy been completed; if not, why not; if so, what is that strategy and when will it be implemented. (1) (a) The Government estimates that the annual costs of implementing the Kyoto Protocol range from a low of 0 to a high of 0.4 per cent of GNP at 2012. These estimates are based on economic modelling undertaken by Warwick McKibbin (McKibbin Software Group) and the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics; (b) the assumptions underpinning these estimates are fully documented in reports by both modellers and are published on the AGO website http://www.greenhouse.gov.au; (c) the nature of international climate change action post 2012 is inherently uncertain, and the Government makes no assumptions about the nature of action post 2012. (2) (a) In developing the Climate Change Forward Strategy, the Government is working with all State and Territory Governments, a wide range of business and industry groups and the National Environmental Consultative Forum representing peak environmental organisations. The Government will also be consulting with the Australian Local Government Association and other relevant groups as necessary. An attendance list of the initial government-business dialogue meeting was attached to my media release of 20 August 2002 and can be viewed on the AGO web site. As noted in my reply to part (2) of question No. 931, which was provided in mid October 2002, the forward strategy is currently being developed. Progress on development of the Strategy is documented in media releases, articles and information on the AGO website. Immigration: Migrant Resource Centres (Question No. 1206) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 5 December 2002: (1) Since March 1996, how many Migrant Resource Centres or Migrant Service Agencies have had their core funding withdrawn by his Department. (2) In respect of each centre, what (a) was the name of the centre, (b) was the date of effect of the withdrawal of funding, (c) were the local government areas previously covered by the centre, (d) was the federal electorate division in which the centre was located and (e) are the details of alternative service delivery arrangements, if any, put in place by the his Department. (1) Three Migrant Resource Centres (MRCs) have had funding withdrawn. Core funding of two other MRCs will cease early in 2003. (2) The details for each Centre are outlined below. (i) Cairns Migrant Resource Centre Service Agreement ceased 31 March 1998. Covered the Local Government Areas (LGAs) of Cairns, Mulgrave, Johnston, Cook, Mareeba, Eacham, Tully North, Cardwell, Douglas, Atherton, Atherton tablelands, Etherage and Herberton. Federal electorate of Leichhardt. Migrant Settlement Services (Centacare Cairns), a new Migrant Service Agency (MSA), was established. A Service Agreement was signed with the new agency in June 1999. In the interim period before the MSA was established, the Community Settlement Services Scheme (CSSS) grant to Cairns Migrant Resource Centre continued to be funded, to ensure continued service delivery in the Cairns area. (ii) Brisbane Migrant Resource Centre Service Agreement ceased 30 June 1998. Covered the LGAs of Brisbane City, Ipswich, Redlands and Pine Rivers. Federal electorate of Brisbane. Multicultural Development Association, a new MSA, was established. A Service Agreement was signed with the new agency in June 1999. In the interim period before the MSA was established, the Australian Red Cross and the Multicultural Pastoral Care were funded to provide services, to ensure continued service delivery in the Brisbane area.

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(iii) Inner West Migrant Resource Centre Service Agreement ceased 30 June 2002. Covered the LGAs of Ashfield, Burwood, Concord, Drummoyne, Strathfield and Leichhardt. Federal electorate of Grayndler. Anglicare, Auburn MRC and Chinese Australian Services Society are funded to provide services until 30 June 2003, to ensure continued service delivery in the Inner West. The Department is currently developing a long-term strategy to determine the most effective method of settlement service delivery in the Inner West. (iv)Migrant Resource Centre of Central Australia Service Agreement for MRC core funding will cease 31 January 2003. Covers the statistical sub-divisions of Barkly and Central. Federal electorate of Lingiari. From1 February 2003, the MRC will re-constitute itself as Multicultural Community Services of Central Australia (McSCA) and will receive funding until 30 September 2003. This will ensure continued service delivery in the Alice Springs area. The McSCA will have the opportunity to apply for funding in the next CSSS round which will be advertised early next year. (v)Northern Metropolitan Migrant Resource Centre Service Agreement will cease 1 March 2003. Covers the statistical sub-divisions of Hume and Moreland. Federal electorate of Wills. Migrant Resource Centre North East and Migrant Resource Centre North West will receive additional funding to provide services to migrants in the Hume and Moreland areas. The Department is currently developing a long-term strategy to determine the most effective method of settlement service delivery in the Hume and Moreland areas. Veterans: Home Care Program (Question No. 1207) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Veterans’ Affairs, upon notice, on 9 December 2002: Will she include regular lawn-mowing services under the Veterans’ Home Care program for veterans who are in receipt of a 100% General Rate disability pension; if not, why not. Mrs Vale-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: The Veterans’ Home Care (VHC) program is not an entitlement based program like most other veterans’ programs, but a fixed budget program like the Home and Community Care program. Pension rate is not a determining factor in the assessment for services, as VHC services are provided to Gold and White cardholders based on need that is assessed by the VHC Assessment and Coordination Agency. Funding levels are set in order to assist a greater number of veterans and war widows/widowers with essential low level support to meet their basic living needs. The focus of VHC home and garden maintenance is to minimise environmental health and safety hazards that impact on the veteran. It is intended to address one-off safety hazards rather than provide routine home and garden maintenance activities. Although some VHC Assessment Agencies approved regular lawn mowing during the first year of the program’s operation in 2001, the approval of this service is not within the scope of the VHC guidelines. Veterans are expected to maintain their current arrangements with family members, social networks and private providers. It is not intended to interfere with these arrangements, or to substitute for private service provision. Australia Post: Security (Question No. 1211) Mrs Crosio asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 9 December 2002: Has his attention been drawn to the comments of the Prime Minister regarding a proposal, for security reasons, for people to produce photographic identification when posting parcels; if so, how will the Government implement the proposal, given that a large proportion of the community do not have access to photographic identification. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question based on advice received from Australia Post: Australia Post has advised that from Monday, 16 December 2002, as a result of a direction from the Department of Transport and Regional Services (DOTRS), customers will be required to provide proof of identity when lodging overseas mail. This is to meet newly introduced DOTRS cargo security requirements. Identification can take the form of a photo ID such as driver’s licence, passport or a signature that can be verified by a credit, debit or social security card. In addition, confirmation that the individual concerned and his/her work or home address are personally known to Australia Post staff will also be an acceptable form of ID for lodgement purposes. Articles lodged in street posting boxes or over the counter without proof of identity may be subject to security delays. Letters and other enveloped items weighing no more than 500 grams are exempt from the identification requirements. Aviation: Laser Anti-missile Defence System (Question No. 1212) Mr Danby asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 10 December 2002: (1) Has his attention been drawn to recent reports of a new laser anti-missile defence system developed for commercial airliners. (2) Is he or his Department making any inquiries about Qantas and other Australian commercial airlines acquiring such a system; if not, why not. (3) Is the government considering purchasing this type of system; if not, why not. (4) Is the government considering requiring commercial airliners to purchase such a system; if not, why not. (1) Yes. (2) My Department liaises with specialists in the Department of Defence and with Qantas on such matters. (3) Yes. (4) The purchase of such equipment is a matter for the airlines whilst the Government’s aviation security regime does not mandate the deployment of such technology. The threat environment for Australian aviation is kept under constant review by the Government, in consultation with airlines and airports. Environment: Kyoto Protocol (Question No. 1222) Dr Emerson asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 11 December 2002: (1) Does it state in the Government’s action agenda for the renewable energy industry titled “New Era, New Energy” that another significant opportunity for the industry would be provided if the Kyoto Protocol is ratified and an emissions trading system implemented.

theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts
title: Acyte Biotech Pty Ltd 2001 02 Sydney Nsw Sydney Nsw

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(2) Is it the case that the Government’s refusal to ratify the Kyoto Protocol means that the Australian renewable energy industry cannot be part of such a trading system, denying it job-creating opportunities. (3) Is it also the case that Australian firms in the renewable energy and environment industries are looking to relocate offshore to other countries which have ratified the Kyoto Protocol, such as New Zealand, to be part of such an emissions trading system. Mr Ian Macfarlane-The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows: (1) No, there is no such statement in the Renewable Energy Action Agenda “New Era, New Energy”. (2) Until the Kyoto Protocol comes into force, it would be premature to assess the impact of nonratification on the Australian renewable energy industry. The Government already provides significant assistance to the renewable energy industry via the Mandatory Renewable Energy Target, and through the funding of some $377 million for programs to support the commercialisation and deployment of renewable energy technologies and related industry development. These measures are driving the rapid growth of our renewable energy industry and creating many jobs in urban and regional Australia. The Mandatory Renewable Energy Target alone will stimulate a 60% increase in renewable electricity generation over a decade equivalent to two Snowy Mountain Schemes. The Target has already stimulated $200 million of investment in new renewable energy projects, as well as the upgrading of existing generators. An estimated $2-3 billion of additional investment in renewable energy will be stimulated over the life of the Target. (3) I am not aware of any Australian firms that have decided to relocate offshore because of the Government’s decision not to ratify the Kyoto Protocol yet. The Government’s Mandatory Renewable Energy Target is actually attracting foreign firms to establish operations in Australia, as demonstrated by the decisions of leading international wind turbine manufacturers such as Vestas and NEG-Micon to invest over $100 million to establish local manufacturing facilities in Tasmania and Victoria. Environment: Australian Greenhouse Office (Question No. 1230) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 11 December 2002: (1) Has his attention been drawn to comments by the former head of the Australian Greenhouse Office (AGO), Ms Gwen Andrews, that the Government’s own economic studies show that promising to meet the Kyoto target while not ratifying the Kyoto Protocol was not an optimal policy position because it shuts Australia out of the trading mechanism and opportunities which the Protocol establishes. (2) Will the Government accept the advice of the former head of the AGO. (1) and (2) It is wrong to infer that the economic studies released by the Government show that the Government’s position on the Kyoto Protocol is not an optimal policy decision. Those studies show that, while the overall economic costs to the Australian economy of ratifying the Kyoto Protocol and meeting the 108% target could be relatively small, the longer-term impacts beyond 2012 are important to the overall assessment of the Protocol. These have been particularly relevant to the Government’s decision not to ratify Kyoto at present. The Kyoto Protocol creates obligations for Australia that are not imposed on many of our competitors. If these arrangements continued over the longer term, industries could be driven overseas by competitive pressure. Since the industries concerned would be seeking to avoid the costs of the greenhouse constraints they would face in Australia, the global environment would be unlikely to benefit. The costs to the Australian economy and Australian jobs could be considerable. The real issue is how Australia is positioned over the next twenty to thirty years to respond to a carbon-constrained world. Through its forward strategy on climate change, the Government is mapping out the optimal transition path and in doing so providing longer-term certainty to indus-
title: Acyte Biotech Pty Ltd 2001 02 Sydney Nsw Sydney Nsw

speaker: Dr Kemp
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:try. This strategy will ensure that Australia maximises opportunities to build competitive advantages in emerging technologies, while minimising costs associated with stranding existing assets. The Government is also engaging in a dialogue with business to examine how we can secure convenient access for Australian business to carbon credit projects under the Protocol and promote Australia’s greenhouse technologies and expertise. Environment: Australian Greenhouse Office (Question No. 1231) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 11 December 2002: (1) Has his attention been drawn to comments by the former head of the Australian Greenhouse Office (AGO), Ms Gwen Andrews, that the most recent figures show greenhouse emissions are now projected to exceed 1990 levels by 14%, which is 6% more than the Kyoto target and double the blowout predicted in August. (2) Do these projections show the Government’s strategy to curb greenhouse gas emissions to be a failure. (3) Has Ms Andrews’ position as Chief Executive Officer been advertised since she left the AGO in May 2002. (4) When will the Government replace Ms Andrews. (1) The comments attributed to Ms Andrews are not correct. Greenhouse data released by the government in August 2002 projected Australia would increase emissions to around 111 per cent of 1990 levels by the end of the next decade. Without greenhouse actions being taken by the government emissions would grow to 122 per cent of 1990 levels, and even more without reductions in emissions from land use change. These emissions projections were based on analytical work conducted in 2001 and 2002. Emissions projections are being updated with the next edition planned for late 2003. Draft updated analyses for the stationary energy and fuel production sectors have been provided recently to stakeholders for comment. The aggregate picture for the next edition of greenhouse emissions projections can only be assembled once analysis have been completed for all relevant economic sectors. (2) No. The latest projections indicate that Australia remains on track to save 60 million tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions annually by the end of the decade. (3) and (4) No. Mr Howard Bamsey is serving as Chief Executive of the AGO Comcar: Employees (Question No. 1234) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 11 December 2002: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1116 (Hansard, 4 December 2002, page 9560), has Comcar undertaken any meetings in the NSW Southern Highlands in 2002; if so, (a) what was the purpose of the meeting, (b) when and where was it held, (c) who attended the meeting and (d) what was the total cost. (2) What security checks are made on individual drivers employed by companies providing contract driving services to Comcar. ourable member’s question: (1) Yes. (a) COMcAR undertook a planning, review and training workshop. (b) The workshop was held at Sutton Forest, NSW in July 2002. (c) Twenty-three Department of Finance and Administration staff attended the workshop including three drivers, three regional supervisors, three State support staff and 14 staff from the ACT. (d) $14,818.18 (or $644 per participant). (2) Standard industry practice is that Police checks are done on all hire car drivers prior to engagement.

theText: The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honRoads: Calder Highway (Question No. 1242) Mr Gibbons asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 December 2002: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 967 (Hansard, 9 December 2002, page 9751), (a) what is the distance still to be covered in road work required for completion of the duplication of the Calder Highway after the present work being done on the Carlsruhe upgrade is finished. (2) What is the estimated total cost of the work still remaining to be done and what cost would be incurred by the Federal Government if it paid 50% of the cost. (3) Is the Federal Government committed to meeting 50% of the remaining cost of completing the Calder Highway duplication. (4) Is the Calder Highway the only Roads of National Importance project which the Federal Government maintains is a State arterial road and for which the Federal Government maintains the completion date is solely a responsibility of the State Government. (5) Given that in the answer to question No. 967 he specified the sums the Federal Government is committed to in regard to the Craigieburn Bypass, the Scoresby Freeway, the Geelong Road and the Murchison East Deviation, why has a similar sum not been specified as a Federal Government commitment to the continuation and completion of the Calder Highway duplication. (1) The planning estimate for the remaining duplication works, between Kyneton and Ravenswood, is a distance of approximately 43kms. (2) The Victorian Government’s estimate of the remaining total cost is $330 million. (3) The Victorian programme is fully committed at present and there is little scope to commit additional funding in the near future. Should additional funding become available in the 2003 Budget, funding for the Calder Highway will be considered in the context of the whole National Highway and Roads of National Importance programme. (4) The decision to complete the duplication of the Calder Highway from Melbourne to Bendigo by 2006 was a unilateral decision made by the Victorian Government. While the Federal Government will assist Victoria in meeting its funding strategy, through the Roads of National Importance programme, the Calder Highway nonetheless remains a State arterial road and, as such, the responsibility for meeting the duplication strategies rests solely with Victoria. (5) Victoria receives a favourable share of Federal road funds. Funding committed to Victoria by the Federal Government for 2002/03 was directed to those projects that were identified by the Victorian Government as those with the highest priority, taking into account current commitments, budget constraints and competing national demands on Federal road revenue. Aviation: Australian Airports (Question No. 1251) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 December 2002: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 671 (Hansard, 14 October 2002, page 7532), was the fact that Australian national airports are strategic assets considered as a factor prior to the direction for the scoping studies for the sale of those airports. (2) If so, what was the briefing given by the Commonwealth Government to those persons responsible for the scoping study and ultimate sale of Sydney Airport and other airports with respect to security impacts, including risk to management exposure in the management of counter-terrorist measures. (3) What will be the impacts on the operation of Australian national airports with respect to the administration and implementation of counter-terrorist measures within those airports. (4) Were the partial sales of Telstra to Singapore Telecom and Qantas to Singapore Airlines equally prevented due to perceived security risks.

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) Yes. The decision to privatise Australia’s Commonwealth-owned airports was taken by Cabinet, and a broad spectrum of stakeholder issues were considered in that process. All Commonwealth Departments, including the Department of Defence, contributed to the decision making process. (2) & (3) Australia’s privatised airports remain strategic assets. The Commonwealth retains ownership of them, with the sale being over their operating lease only. The obligations of airport owners and operators, including aviation security and counter-terrorism measures, are imposed by the Airports Act, Air Navigation Act, and subordinate Regulations and apply regardless of ownership. The Commonwealth Government has established a legislative package providing for a series of minimum standards for the security of civil aviation from, to and within Australia. The Commonwealth’s role derives from its ratification of an international treaty, the “Chicago Convention”, concluded on 7 December 1944. (4) Questions relating to the sale arrangements and processes that applied in the privatisation of Telstra and QANTAS should be directed to the Minister for Finance and Administration. Immigration: Pre-Qualified Institution Program (Question No. 1257) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 12 December 2002: (1) Which education providers have participated in the Pre-Qualified Institution (PQI) program each year. (2) How many places were allocated to each education provider for each participating country each year. (3) How many PQI visas were issued for each education provider for each participating country each year. (4) How many overseas students from the participating countries who are not sponsored under the PQI program were enrolled at each of the participating education providers each year. (5) How many student visa applications that were given PQI status for each participating education provider were rejected each year. (6) Were any sanctions sought from an education provider where the provider did not meet the agreed performance standards contained in the Memorandum of Understanding; if so, what sanctions were sought and from which education providers. (1) A list of education providers who participated in the PQI Program from its inception as a pilot program in 1999 until the expiry of the 2002 MoUs on 30 November 2002 is provided at Attachment A. (2) The number of places allocated to each education provider for each participating country for each year of the PQI program is provided at Attachment A. Allocations are provided by country and by education sector. Some education providers are eligible for PQI in more than one country and education sector. (3) The number of visas issued for each education provider by sector and by country in 2001 2002 is provided at Attachment A. The number of visas issued for each provider is not readily available for 1999-2000. However, as an indication, the number of applications lodged by each provider for each participating country for 1999 and 2000 is provided at Attachment A. (4) The number of overseas students from the PRC, India, Pakistan and Vietnam who were enrolled at PQI-eligible education providers, but who did not enter under the PQI program, is not readily available from departmental systems. (5) The number of PQI student visa applications that were refused during the 2002 and 2001 PQI program years is provided at Attachment A. Refusal data for the 1999 and 2000 PQI program years by provider is not readily available. (6) During the 1999 Pilot of the PQI Program, training and assistance was given to education providers and no sanctions were issued. The MOU was amended in 2000 to allow for a PQI provider who breaches the conditions of their MOU to either have their PQI status suspended or cancelled.
title: Acyte Biotech Pty Ltd 2001 02 Sydney Nsw Sydney Nsw

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Clause8 sets out behaviour, which may lead to the suspension of PQI status: incomplete PQI applications exceed 2 in number, or 5 per cent of the allocated quota; or more than one PQI application is lodged containing fraudulent or misleading documentation; or the number of refusals for PQI applications exceed 10% of the quota allocation; or the on-shore student visa cancellation rate is equal to, or more than, half the average for all providers; or the non-compliance notices issued rate is equal to, or more than, half the average for all providers; or a student is cancelled for breach of a student visa condition relating to attendance or academic performance, where a non-compliance notice for that student was not previously issued by the provider; or the provider exceeds more than once, the number of sponsored applications they are permitted to lodge in accordance with their allocated quota. Under clause 9 of the MoU, a PQI provider may have its PQI status cancelled if: a second breach under clause 8 of the MoU occurs; or a provider, or its nominated agent, has, in Australia or any other country, advertised or marketed itself, or suggested or implied that it had the formal approval of DIMIA or the Minister or that it has special government or Commonwealth approval of any kind or in any other way suggested that it is an organisation that has formal ties with the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia; or its CRICOS registration is lost or suspended; or it has provided false or misleading information with regard to its application for PQI status. 2000 PQI Pilot The following education providers failed to achieve the benchmark 90 per cent of sponsored applicants being assessed as bona fide and had their PQI status withdrawn from the 2000 PQI pilot. Six providers were in the Secondary Schools sector, two in the ELICOS sector and two in the VET sector: ACT Department of Education and Training; Australian School of Tourism and Hotel Management; Griffith University English Language Institute; Ivanhoe Grammar School; John Paul College; Kingswood College; Martin College; NSW Department of Education and Training; St Joseph’s Nudgee International College; and the Sydney English Language Centre. 2001 PQI Program In the 2001 PQI program, two ELICOS providers had their PQI status suspended for lodging more than one application that contained fraudulent documentation and one provider had its PQI status cancelled as a result of advertising the PQI program. The providers were: Melbourne Language Centre status in the PRC was suspended (reinstated on 27 September 2001); Billy Blue Schools status in the PRC was suspended (reinstated in April 2002); The University of Newcastle had its PQI status for PRC cancelled in December 2001. Agents with a connection to the provider had advertised the provider’s PQI status. 2002 PQI Program During the 2002 PQI program, Alexander Language School had its PQI status suspended for 6 months, commencing in April 2002. The provider had lodged more than 1 application that was refused on the basis of fraudulent documents. The provider was invited to re-join the program in October 2002. In 2002, the Kooralbyn International School had its PQI status cancelled as a result of its closure. During 2002, 11 providers were under investigation for lodging more than one application containing fraudulent or misleading information. However, suspension proceedings ceased with the expiration of the 2002 MoUs. 0 0 Martin College 20 4 1 NSW Department of Education and Training 25 0 0 RMIT University 10 1 0 Swinburne University of Technology 20 0 0 31 889 70 4 Fuel: Ethanol (Question No. 1260) Mr Murphy asked the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 12 December 2002: (1) Further to the answer to part (3) of question No. 984 (Hansard, 14 November, 2002, page 9042), could he provide figures as requested for a range of engines that would be typical for the Australian fleet. (2) Further to the answer to part (6) of question No. 984, what average fuel consumption for Australian vehicles does the Government regard as achievable in (a) 5 years, (b) 10 years and (c) 20 years. (3) What measures will the Government adopt to achieve these targets. (1) As I advised in my original responses, carbon dioxide emissions in vehicles are a product of the efficiency of the engine and the greenhouse intensity of the fuel. This is regardless of the specific engine technology used. The 2001, CSIRO/RMIT report ‘Comparison of Transport Fuels’, available on the Australian Greenhouse Office website, provides a discussion on this issue. (2) Targets for national average fuel consumption for passenger vehicles are currently under negotiation with industry. (3) Government has a range of initiatives underway to reduce national average fuel consumption. These include: voluntary fuel consumption targets with motor vehicles producers, fuel consumption labelling on new vehicles, and annual publication of a fuel consumption guide. In addition, the post-2005 automotive assistance package announced on 13 December 2002 includes a $150 million R&D fund specifically for vehicle manufacturers investing in new and innovative technologies. Education: Scholarships (Question No. 1270) Mr Andren asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 12 December 2002: How many tertiary students received scholarships, including Commonwealth scholarships, in Australia for the 2002 academic year and what is the breakdown of this number according to the per annum amount of scholarship received. My Department does not collect data on institutional and other scholarships for tertiary study. DEST only collects data on Commonwealth-funded scholarships. Final data for 2002 as reported by the universities through the Higher Education Student Statistics Collection administered by my Department is not yet available. The following numbers of students, with details of scholarship amounts and provisions, received Commonwealth-funded scholarships in 2001 as calculated on the basis of the maximum scholarship tenure:

speaker: Dr Nelson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Australian Postgraduate Awards (APA) – 5,425 students in 2001. Full-time APA students received a stipend of $17,609 in 2001 and are eligible for other allowances. An APA scholarship can be held for a maximum of three and a half years. International Postgraduate Research Scholarships (IPRS) – 1,200 students in 2001. IPRS students receive a tuition-fee waiver scholarship to cover the cost of their annual course tuition fee for a maximum of four years, with tuition fee levels varying by academic discipline. Merit-Based Equity Scholarships – 1,640 students in 2001. These scholarships provide recipients with a HECS exemption for an undergraduate course to the maximum duration of that course. Immigration: Managing Migration Kit (Question No. 1272) Ms Gillard asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 12 December 2002: (1) Why was a decision taken to produce the “Managing Migration” kit recently launched at Parliament House. (2) Who made the decision. (3) What were the costs of production and distribution of all the materials in the kit. (4) To whom will the kit will be distributed. (5) What were the costs of staging the launch itself, including refreshments. (1) My Department suggested to me that there would be benefit in preparing an information kit about managing migration and border control issues which could be used by Federal Parliamentarians in their electorate and Parliament House offices when responding to inquiries from their constituents. It would also be useful information for foreign diplomats in Australia when briefing their home governments. (2) I approved its production. One thousand copies were produced and I am pleased to inform the House that the kit has been very well received as an exceptionally useful information resource. (3) The kit was written and produced by my Department. The cost of production was $39,508.70. Distribution was handled in-house by my Department. Those kits sent to my Parliamentary colleagues were hand delivered to Parliament House, and incurred only the cost of $68 for a courier between Belconnen and Parliament House. Distribution to other addresses cost $572. The contents of the kit were translated into Spanish, French and German, incurring a cost of $47, 460.60 for translations. (4) The kit has been distributed to all Commonwealth Members and Senators and all Ambassadors of foreign missions based in Canberra, the Premiers and Chief Ministers of all States and Territories, members of the Ministerial Council on Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, other committees and Tribunals associated with my portfolio. In addition, a number of refugee advocacy and lobby organisations received copies, ensuring that they had accurate and timely information to hand. Copies of the kit have also been sent to offices of my Department in Australia and overseas through normal government channels. (5) I was pleased to launch the kit on 12 November here at Parliament House. The total cost of staging the launch was $5042.75, comprising $3835.50 for catering for 150 people and room hire, and $1207.05 for the technical support. International Organisation for Migration (Question No. 1275) Ms Gillard asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 12 December 2002:
title: Total 85 5 1 Total All Sectors

speaker: Mr Ruddock
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:(1) Has the Government allocated $75.4m to support international organisations, such as the UNHCR and the International Organisation for Migration (IOM), for the detention, processing and subsequent removal of people in transit countries. (2) It is reported in The Advertiser on 2 October 2001 that an IOM spokesman confirmed that IOM never used force to effect removals; if so, what does “subsequent removal” mean. (3) What is the purpose of these funds. (4) What is the nature of the arrangements that have been made with the IOM. (1) In the 2002-03 Budget, the Government committed $75.4m over four years to combating illegal migration and people smuggling through the interception of illegal movements in transit countries. This measure is aimed at: increasing the capacity of authorities and international organisations in transit countries to detect and intercept illegal people movement ($16.2 million); and providing support to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) and the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) for accommodation and processing of people who have been intercepted en route to Australia ($59.2 million). (2) In accordance with its Charter, the IOM facilitates removals only if they are voluntary. The reference to “subsequent removal” is that voluntary removal by IOM occurs only after any matters that arise related to refugee protection have been dealt with by UNHCR. Under the informal regional cooperative arrangements in place with several countries in the region, the IOM assists those who volunteer to return to their country of origin or country of prior residence. Australia funds IOM for the cost of their voluntary return. (3) As stated in my response to question (1), the purpose of the funds is to: provide assistance to increase the capacity of authorities and international organisations in transit countries to detect and intercept illegal people movement; and provide support for IOM and UNHCR for accommodation and processing of people who have been intercepted en route to Australia. (4) The arrangements in place between Australia and the IOM for dealing with those intercepted in transit countries are: the IOM takes responsibility for the movement (where required) of detainees, their accommodation and sustenance and their health and welfare needs. Australia funds the IOM for these activities; where a detainee raises protection concerns, the IOM refers the case to the UNHCR for assessment; the UNHCR assesses any such claims and if the UNHCR finds the person not to be a refugee, or if no protection claims are raised, the IOM assists those who volunteer to return to their country of origin or country of prior residence. Australia funds IOM for the cost of voluntary return. Immigration: Overseas Posts (Question No. 1278) Ms Gillard asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 12 December 2002: (1) Is his Department examining ways to cut costs at Australia’s overseas posts; if so, which posts and programs are being examined for reductions. (1) In recent years a number of electronic and business redesign initiatives across a range of visa programs have been introduced to improve client service outcomes and the cost effectiveness of my Department’s overseas operations. This includes processing of Skilled, Business Skills, and Parent migration applications in Adelaide and Perth. New technology and service delivery arrangements have significantly reduced the need for clients to attend Australian visa offices in many countries and have all but eliminated the need to continue with over-the-counter services at some Australian missions. In addition, some resources have been redirected to high risk environments to enhance integrity of entry programs. The Department has progressively been reviewing its overseas operations. This review is examining current and future resourcing requirements to best deal with the impacts of the above service

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:delivery initiatives. In August 2002, visa operations ceased in Stockholm and in October 2002, in Dublin. I have recently decided to move resources from Los Angeles, close the DIMIA office, and consolidate visa operations in Washington, which will occur over the next six months. New Australia-based positions have been established in Dhaka and Dubai. Reviewing overseas operations is an ongoing process and I will be looking at the case for resource changes at other overseas posts as business methods change and work pressures and priorities shift.
